Highly Recommended: A Flawless Victory for the New Era.

The core combat has been polished to perfection. MK1 feels faster and more fluid than its predecessors, rewarding creativity and quick thinking. The biggest game-changer is the Kameo system. These assist fighters add an incredible layer of strategic depth, allowing for mind-blowing combo extensions, defensive breaks, and setup opportunities that drastically change how you approach every matchup. Mastering your main fighter and their Kameo partner provides hundreds of hours of satisfying experimentation.

If you're looking for a fighting game with a world-class story, deep and customizable combat, and visuals that will drop your jaw, look no further. MK1 is a spectacular entry, and the Kameo system ensures that competitive play stays fresh and exciting for years to come. Get Over Here! (And buy this game =p

Mortal Kombat 1 can absolutely be fun, and the gameplay itself is solid. The story isn‚Äôt particularly interesting, but it‚Äôs told in a way that kept me engaged.

Unfortunately, the game is heavily dragged down by microtransactions and a thick layer of forced ‚Äúwoke‚Äù themes that feel out of place in the MK universe. Almost all female characters were deliberately redesigned to look completely unattractive, which for me goes so far that it almost feels disrespectful toward women rather than the opposite.

On top of that, the visual tone has shifted from dark and brutal to bright, colorful, almost ‚ÄúFortnite-like.‚Äù This change kills the atmosphere and even makes some Fatalities look unintentionally silly instead of shocking or dramatic.

There is a good game underneath all this. But the artistic direction and ideological polish suffocate much of what made Mortal Kombat unique.

Been a fan and player of MK since the release of the first game in arcades. While MK X and even 11 had bumpy starts, they turned out to be okay maybe even good depending on how you look at things. MK 11 certainly had a lot of options and nice additions. I picked up MK 1 on release via console and played it for several seasons though it was a terrible release lacking a lot of standard features.

After picking the game up on sale for pc I was amazed to see how much didn't change, it's been over a year since I played this game. The "contacting MK servers" and errors accompanying that are still there and occur a lot especially when trying to get items or unlock mastery. I've had matches end, usually when trying to get awards, abruptly such as fighting Floyd! Invasions is a complete joke, maybe even worse than when the game first launched. The talisman thing was broken early on but you could make some powerful stuff and it really helped leveling up and beating bosses. The devs made the game not only grindy but took away a lot of the tools to aid in it. Shops have basically nothing of use (keys once were in at least one shop at different stages as an example). Limits and nerfing have been placed on creating talismans, lack of item slots, useless map (worst map I've seen in a modern game), boring as hell is the best way to describe "invasion".

The graphics are decent, especially tweaking the settings though it's odd the game has updated to account for a gtx 5080 giving a message talking about a 3080ti (I've never seen that in a modern game). Actual gameplay vs the computer or against a second player locally doesn't glitch or hesitate but game menus, selecting skins/items/characters has some terrible lag and delay. It probably has something to do with everything on servers but MK 11 doesn't have this issue.

Overall, MK 1 screams nrs didn't listen to fan feedback or the community. A lot of popular features and characters were not part of the game and nrs created a game that paywalled a lot of stuff. The game feels as if it is a pay-to-play moblie game with how invasions works and the slop items. Even the stances for characters are all the same (every kitana skin has the same stance as an example). The kameos are useless, take away fatality options from their playable character, lock out favorites from being playable (sonya, jax, etc), and feels as if it was an unfinished idea. Another big issue is changing characters for an agenda (cyborgs, "cage") which no one asked for but fans did ask for.

As a long time fan of the series I hope Mortal Kombat can get back to what made people love the game and a dev team who cares about the community gets involved.

This game sucks on all fronts and I don't know where I should begin. 
It's 2025 and this game has:

1. Gameplay feels stiff and inferior compared to Street Fighter 6 and Tekken 8. Animations still feel janky 
2. OGs like Sektor, Cyrax etc are NOT playable 
3. Poor UX/UI, specifically on stage selection. Like what the hell??? The stage background is blurred out
4. Limited customization!!! Weird predefined color pallets to choose from!!! 
5. And my main gripe: you can only pick ONE outfit!!! You can only edit one outfit. There are no other outfits to pick from in the character selection! No slots for custom outfits, no other outfits to pick from in general. Like what the hell??? 
6. Despite all the things mentioned above, NRS and WB charge a significant amount for DLCs

However, story is solid. Presentation is good. Fatalities etc can be fun and satisfying and that is about it unfortunately. I also own MK X and 11. I prefer those over MK 1 any day. Fundamentally, gameplay wise, mechanics, spacing, customization and overall quality - SF6 and T8 are way ahead.

I‚Äôm honestly stunned. If you (like me) have been listening to the doom-and-gloom crowd and staying away from this, let me tell you right now...they couldn‚Äôt be more wrong.

I fired up Mortal Kombat 1 for the first time yesterday (grabbed the Definitive Edition for eighteen bucks on Fanatical), and I‚Äôm honestly sitting here wondering what in the hell people have been complaining about.

I‚Äôve been with this series since day one...since the arcades...since the sticky buttons, cigarette burns, and the magic of hearing ‚ÄúFinish Him‚Äù echo through a crowd...and I can tell you right now, Mortal Kombat has finally...fully...arrived.

This game is beautiful. The graphics are unreal. The animations are so fluid and natural that it feels like you‚Äôre watching martial arts cinema unfold in real time. The attention to detail is staggering...the character models, the light, the choreography, the sound of impact...everything feels handcrafted with purpose.

It‚Äôs like the franchise has matured into something extraordinary...aged and refined over decades...a vintage wine finally uncorked. You can taste every era in it, but it‚Äôs smoother, richer, and more deliberate than ever before.

And yet...I come online and all I see is people whining.

‚ÄúCyrax isn‚Äôt the same.‚Äù
‚ÄúScorpion feels neutered.‚Äù
‚ÄúRaiden‚Äôs not a god anymore.‚Äù

Yeah...that‚Äôs kind of the point. Liu Kang rebuilt the timeline. The characters are different now. Their roles, their destinies...their relationships have shifted. That‚Äôs not betrayal of the lore...that‚Äôs evolution. It‚Äôs storytelling. It‚Äôs what keeps a thirty-year-old franchise from becoming a fossil.

People begged for a new direction for years...and now that we have one, they‚Äôre mad that it‚Äôs not just MK11 with a new paint job. Unreal.

MK1 isn‚Äôt MK11-2. It‚Äôs something else entirely. It‚Äôs cinematic...it‚Äôs expressive...and it‚Äôs finally found that perfect balance between classic brutality and modern flow. Every match feels alive. Every strike feels deliberate. It‚Äôs fast, but not frantic...fluid, but still weighty. You can tell NetherRealm has been tuning this craft for decades, and MK1 is where it finally all came together.

Even the story mode is a work of art. It‚Äôs not afraid to take risks or make bold choices with legacy characters. It actually explores what it means to rewrite fate...and how even gods can‚Äôt escape the cycle of conflict. For longtime fans, that‚Äôs powerful stuff.

And don‚Äôt even get me started on the production quality. The facial animation alone puts most triple-A games to shame. The sound design...the cinematography...the direction of each cutscene...this is world-class. It‚Äôs absurd that people look at all this and still cry ‚Äúlazy‚Äù or ‚Äúrushed.‚Äù There‚Äôs nothing lazy about this. You can feel the hours, the sweat, the passion, and the technical mastery that went into every single frame.

It‚Äôs honestly hilarious watching the same people who were probably toddlers when MK9 dropped try to tear this apart because it doesn‚Äôt spoon-feed them nostalgia in the exact flavor they wanted. Some folks just don‚Äôt know how good they have it.

As someone who‚Äôs seen this series evolve from blocky digitized sprites to what it is now...this feels like the moment Mortal Kombat reached full artistic and mechanical maturity. It‚Äôs finally confident in its own skin. It doesn‚Äôt need to prove anything anymore.

So yeah...say what you want about missing features or roster choices, but from where I‚Äôm standing, this is the most visually refined, fluidly animated, and thoughtfully built Mortal Kombat game ever made. It‚Äôs the first time the words fighting game and art form can sit in the same sentence without irony.

For eighteen bucks, I‚Äôm sitting here absolutely blown away by the craftsmanship...and I honestly can‚Äôt relate to the constant negativity surrounding this masterpiece.

Mortal Kombat 1 isn‚Äôt just another sequel...it‚Äôs the culmination of everything this franchise has been trying to become since 1992.

So maybe...just maybe...stop nitpicking long enough to appreciate what‚Äôs actually in front of you. Because this isn‚Äôt a failure...this is an arrival.

Mortal Kombat 1 | Liu Kang, the ‚ÄúChino de Mierda‚Äù Chronicles
Ayo, lemme tell ya ‚Äî Mortal Kombat 1 is straight heat. Beautiful chaos, crisp punches, and enough gore to make your controller flinch. Pure art, bro.

But man‚Ä¶ that Liu Kang. Every damn session, my buddy ‚ÄúEl Comisario‚Äù picks him like it‚Äôs a sacred ritual, and I‚Äôm there, yelling ‚Äú¬°Chino de mierda!‚Äù while this dude teleports, kicks, and flexes his god powers like he‚Äôs the CEO of pain. Calm down, Kung-Fu Jesus.

Still, the game? Absolute banger. The visuals go crazy, the combos feel smooth, and every match turns into a masterclass in friendly destruction. It‚Äôs the perfect excuse to beat the hell outta your friends and laugh about it right after, ‚Äòcause that‚Äôs what real gaming‚Äôs about.

So yeah, Mortal Kombat 1: play it, shout at Liu Kang, and keep the squad strong ‚Äî one fatality at a time.

We WUZ Mortal kombat n sheeeet. If i were to summarize MK1 into 3 words it would be laziness, disappointment and greed.

Story:
Story is slightly better than in MK11 however after halfway its same shit as in MK11. Timeline go BRRRRRRRR. The best way how to continue story when you have lost all creativity and ideas is  Timeline/Multiverse and sheeeet. Chapter 15 is MEME, i dont know why developers have to put this zoomer humor into every fucking serious franchise. MK isnt fucking Street Fighter for kids. DLC story was ok only because of Havik however you have been forced to play 2/3 of story as the most disgusting character in the game (Tanya).

Characters:
All female characters except the black one, looks like that disgusting bitch from Ghost of Yotei. Raiden and Kung Lao models are same, Scorpion and Sub-Zero models are same. Developers forgot why is Megan Fox famous and i can tell you its not Acting/Voice Acting. Customization is far worse than in MK11. Race and Gender swap for Cyrax and Sector,

I remember my grandmother saying to me "I dont care what they tell you in school"  Cyrax was black woman. As it was not enough they gave her the most generic "African tribe" accent. There are only few characters which kept their design from previous game unfortunately most of them are cameo characters which you cannot play.

Content:
Towers with modifiers are ok however they are extended with TYM event which is doing nothing despite of your success or failure. Krypt has been replaced by Invasions which was the biggest mistake. I finished one invasion and i have had enough. When i bought this game i expected fighting and not fucking pinball/zombie/arcade minigames. When you expect me to do combo trials 100 times with character i have never ever played before, at least remove that fucking stage loading and "YOU LOSE" animation.

Cameo system:
During fights you can call your cameo (second character)  fighter to perform some moves which can extends/fuck up your combos or can give you some additional effects like armor and so on. I dont understand why developers havent finished them and not gave them full move set and made them playable as it was in MK9. Is it too much to ask for?

Conclusion:
Netherrealm studios made Mortal Kombat franchise from game which you turned on when you wanted to play against other people on Friday night to full time daily job where you have to farm character levels to unlock Fatalities/Brutalities and Skins in stupid minigames but dont worry you can visit their Microtransaction shop to make it less painful. I strongly hope that they will let MK rest in peace and move on to butcher another franchise.

Great story line, great gameplay

Same 1v1 fights with friends are fine ‚Äî the combat still has that classic MK punch, and the cameo system is somewhat refreshing (mostly because Madame Bo is funny as hell ‚Äî hope it doesn‚Äôt return in future titles though). The graphics are solid too (except for the new outfits... God forbid they show anything, huh). But that‚Äôs about all the good I can say.

The whole thing is way too focused on online play and grind. Hiding extra fatalities or any non-cosmetic character features behind grind or paywalls is just a huge dick move. Ever since MK9, every new entry has been getting worse. The guest characters this time? What a joke. T-1000 and Ghostface are cool, sure ‚Äî but the rest? Really? Really?

Another rebooted storyline.  Everywhere you look ‚Äî microtransactions. It honestly feels like NRS is trying to sell us a demo just so they can charge full price later for ‚Äúbonus‚Äù DLC characters. They‚Äôre turning into EA at this point. This starts to become a trend in fighting games too, unfortunately, but I hate this trend - if I buy a game I want to get the full game, not having to grind forever for each character separately to just get the full experience of that character, when I'll be bored as hell with playing the character.

But the worst part of all? The complete rewriting of iconic characters.
Liked Scorpion? Surprise ‚Äî it‚Äôs not Hanzo Hasashi anymore, it‚Äôs Sub-Zero‚Äôs brother.
Raiden? Just a regular guy now.
Shang Tsung? Basically a wandering con artist.

You just don‚Äôt do that. You don‚Äôt butcher the characters people have loved (and loved to hate) for decades and just turning them into completely different characters. That‚Äôs the real fatality here.

I could forgive all of the rest  but this? Turning Mortal Kombat into a grindy, microtransaction-infested mobile app on PC? That killed my love for the series. It's even worse than the change part of characters into some zombies in MK11.

I‚Äôve been a diehard MK fan since the very beginning. I survived MK4, I survived the Game Boy version, I survived Jarek instead of Kano and even Hsu Hao. But this time... I‚Äôm out.
NRS performed a perfect, cruel fatality ‚Äî on my fandom. I'm afraid this is goodbye, it's time to change franchises for me.

I mean a month after a I purchased the base game, the definitive edition came out at just slightly over the price I paid, then surely the upgrade should reflect that price difference? Nope, essentially you are paying pretty much the same price for the upgrade as someone coming in without a copy previously. Seems they want to really gouge the early adopters which makes no sense since early adopters form their core customer and loyalty  base. Seems short-sighted. I can also imagine it must be extremely aggravating for those who purchased all the individual characters, skins, and expansions...Corporate greed once again ruins what could otherwise be a pretty fun game. If you really need an MK fix I would just play MK11 when it goes on special for like 5$ (which is often btw).

Fun to play, especially if you're coming from MK11, holds up pretty similar but with a few new features, the addition of a kameo character (which is also a fun way to make a nod to characters that would otherwise not make the roster) and the characters feel familiar yet still fresh and changed up. Story is decent enough, entertaining, love seeing Liu Kang's new timeline and the final mission in the story mode (no spoilers) is pretty fun tbh with how they made the "new characters". Only downsides i'd say overall is that some of the characters aren't as fun as before, to me Scorpion doesn't feel as fast as he used to in 11, and the story is nice, but feels like it almost could've been a DLC of mk11, if abit long. Also, Jax is missing from the roster and is only there as a kameo, which is disappointing, but I don't play Jax so that is only a issue if you main him. Either way, the game handles well (given that it even runs on my POS pc) and I really like how the characters are remade and reimagined, and most of the outfits feel on point. I got it on a sweet sale, but id say its definitely worth what I got it for. Overall, fun game, and I can't wait til the series continues next (hopefully with a new course? love the multiverse thing and time stuff, but we've done it now)

I'm an old-school MK fan, ever since Mk2 on Sega I've been playing every game in the series. With Mk1, looking at its release quality and the predatory monetization practices they implemented soon after, I decided to wait a while and only recently picked it up on sale.

The game looks gorgeous, I kinda enjoyed the story mode (not the DLC part though, it's horrible beyond any words), I like the roster, I don't mind the grind and the customization system is fine by me. But no matter what I do I just can't have fun with this game at all, which is pretty sad and frustrating. And the issues this time are not so much on the surface, so it took me a while to figure it out why it feels so bad to play MK1 for me.

[b]I came to a conclusion that the game is just... too hardcore for me, and not in a fun way[/b]. With thousands of online matches in MKX and MK11, I just can't get a grasp on this one, and most importantly I don't want to cause it doesn't feel rewarding.

All the mechanics that currently piled up in the game, and the way they're implemented, and all the long-standing issues, they all together smothering me as a player from all sides. It's like I'm mostly fighting against the game rather than my opponents. I mean, how in such a dynamic game am I supposed keep in mind:
[list]
[*][b]Cameo moves and their shitty delayed inputs
[*][b]Move enhancements
[*][b]Fatal blows
[*][b]Cameo fatal blows
[*][b]Desperate moves
[*][b]Perfect blocks and upward blocks
[*][b]Extra-mechanics of every character on the roster [/b](stances, cancels, trap-setups, portals, you name it)
[/list]

All of this + remembering your regular combo strings and specials.
All of this + your attack won't hit cause the game has no actual hit/hurt boxes and uses cheap solution in form of polygon mesh collision instead.
All of this + sloppy online connection.
All of this + some stings in combos don't schedule for no clear reason and require absurdly precise input timings after the character recovery.
All of this + bdf/bfd/dbf... specials that are difficult to pull off consistently. 


[b]NOW AT WHAT POINT CAN I ACTUALLY FOCUS ON JUST PLAYING AND ENJOYING THE GAME?[/b]


When between all that cognitive load do I have a window to actually think about my opponent's actions, about my or their mix-ups, about zoning, and everything else that fighting games are about? How many hundreds of hours do I need to learn all of the above on the muscle memory level and switch my mind to something that is actually fun in the game?

And then I'm comparing this to previous games, MKX and MK11, where it took just a fragment of these efforts to consistently pull off beautiful satisfying combos that involve several different specials and basic attacks.

I remember how I used to main Erran Black and there was a not so hard string that includes almost all the character gimmicks - shooting, acid, rifle butt strikes, slides. Or MK11 Geras string that I used to spam online that had bed of spikes, time freeze and sand portal in it - all you wanna see from your boi.

Now in MK1 it feels like you have to do twice the effort, and the string you get would be something like "punches combo, legs combo, one special that basically looks and feels like a normal attack, more punches, same special". Make it twice as long by slapping a cameo extender after learning its unintuitive timing by heart.


It just doesn't feel worth it to learn all of it to start having fun, not for me at least.

My favorite Mortal Kombat game so far.

+ Some of the most complete character looks in the franchise.
+ Breathtaking next-gen graphics.
+ Super refined gameplay.
+ Incentives to keep playing with rewards and seasons.
+ The best Mortal Kombat story to date.
+ The music is excellent.
+ The return of the Animalities.
+ The much-talked-about character partnership doesn't bother me at all, it's something different, a breath of fresh air.
+ It's perhaps the best-looking fighting game of this generation.

- The Krypt is missing, something iconic that should be present.

I recommend it to all beat 'em up lovers.

A VERY EPIC STORY!!!!

Before you consider playing Mortal Kombat 1, I would highly recommend that you play Mortal Kombat X and 11 (including the Aftermath DLC story for MK11) for the full experience! If you still own a PS3 or Xbox 360 console then I would also include MK9 AKA Mortal Kombat (2011). 

Now onto the review itself; 

This is the most cinematic Mortal Kombat game to date! The visuals are incredibly stunning, the designs are far more vibrant compared to any other MK games. The voice acting was top notch in my opinion and the story is just captivating. This was truly a love letter to the entire Mortal Kombat franchise, especially if you had played the older games in the PS2 era. I will not say anything about the story because this is something you should play blind like I did. 

The gameplay was butter smooth! The developers implemented a "Kameo" system where you can call a companion to attack your opponent with one strike to help escape an intense combo attack from the opponent or to simply support your attack momentum! A very small feature yet it feels refreshing and WOW the fatal blows (x-rays) and fatalities are insane as always!  The character roster is great, the sound effects is amazing, the soundtrack is amazing and what is more to say???

If you really want to know what the flaws are, I can only say that some characters did feel a bit sluggish but that is a me thing like obviously some characters are a learning curve to master their move sets. This time around unfortunately there are no stage interactions but it is forgivable with the amazing smooth gameplay. 

Once again, this was a love letter and a Komplete experience! I cannot wait to play the Khaos Reigns DLC story now, highly recommend this game! Please play the previous Mortal Kombat games at the very least MK11 and the Aftermath DLC.
MORTAL KOMBAT FOREVER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Mortal Kombat 1 ‚Äì The Perfect Example of Sitting on Two Chairs and Falling Between ThemMortal Kombat 1 tries so desperately to please everyone that it ends up pleasing absolutely no one. It‚Äôs not Mortal Kombat anymore ‚Äî but it‚Äôs not Fortnite or Foamstars either (thank God, I guess). The tragedy? It can‚Äôt even reach the chaotic brilliance of Concord, which now feels like divine design compared to this confused reboot.They wanted to ‚Äúmodernize‚Äù the franchise but ended up neutering it instead. The game bends over backward to be edgy and ‚Äúinclusive,‚Äù gritty and sanitized, nostalgic and progressive ‚Äî all at once. The result? A Frankenstein of tone, half a fighting game and half a corporate DEI brochure.There are still too many men (though, thankfully, almost no white ones ‚Äî small mercies). But don‚Äôt worry, we‚Äôll ‚Äúfix‚Äù that soon: make Janet Cage the main character, turn Johnny into her cameo, gender-swap Liu Kang, Raiden, and Kung Lao into lovers, and replace Sub-Zero, Smoke, and Scorpion with three first-year ‚Äústrong and independent sisters‚Äù from the ‚ÄúFreeze, Burn, and Shatter the Patriarchy‚Äù clan. Let‚Äôs remove Fatalities entirely and replace them with Equalities ‚Äî Babality and Friendship for everyone!Because that‚Äôs what this new ‚Äúbroad audience‚Äù wants, right? Spoiler: no, it doesn‚Äôt. The mythical, mass-market audience the managers dream of doesn‚Äôt exist. And even the real casual audience ‚Äî unless they‚Äôre coming straight from Candy Crush Saga ‚Äî also wants something visceral, stylish, and authentic. Something that feels like Mortal Kombat, not a PR experiment.So congratulations, NetherRealm. You‚Äôve managed to turn one of gaming‚Äôs most unapologetically brutal and iconic series into a confused, soy-flavored spectacle of self-censorship and misplaced ideals.Welcome to Mortal Kombat 1 ‚Äî the game that forgot who it was, and in trying to become everything, became nothing.

I played MK11 on Xbox, been moving to pc and saw this was on sale so I thought I'd pick this up. It's a lot of fun, just like the previous games. Keeping that in mind it is VERY taxing on your hardware. I personally play on a Laptop (I'm a broke college student don't judge me) and if I'm not using an external cooling fan it will definitely overheat. There is some lag even just on the campaign but I'd assume that's because of my hardware. If your planning to utilize krossplay be aware both me and my friend on Xbox have experienced lag and some missed inputs. However, we are still able to play and have fun, I wouldn't recommend any sort of competitive play utilizing krossplay. 

TL;DR 
I'd recommend, just make sure your hardware can handle it.

I can't believe not even mortal kombat was safe from this rainbow carebear stare that keeps ruining everything. Like Seriously the game was this close to saying 'the real fatality is the friends we made along the way'.

this whole thing is so sacharine, such a tame calm disney level story I swear I kept thinking it was the avengers.  

The infinite race and gender swapping is actually okay with the way the multiverse works you will see some incredible and inoffensive amalgamations of all you favorite characters, It actually really fits here better than almost anywhere else I  have seen it implemented. 

But its the story man, I played for over 10 hours before someone died, And the game flat out refuses to make any judgement call about any act. No one is really a bad guy, its like saturday morning cartoons, where all the badguys were just misunderstood and given a chance and made friends with the good guys, and no one ever does anything bad or wrong (until the expansion but even then its very tame). 

Gameplay wise its ok, middle of the road some better some worse, I don't think its as fun as x or 11, it feels like an intentional step back. Itsw gonna be a matter of taste here.


If you are playing for the story, I honestly say don't waste your time, not even for $5. If you can get the whole collection with all the dlc for 10 or less, then its worth it for the game play.

I'll start by saying that I really wanted to like this game but just couldn't. MK1 has easily been the quickest to put down compared to MK11 and MKX. I was just not having fun anymore. I'll ignore the usual MK launch shenanigans which plagues all MK games. You can go read about them online, it was literally unplayable when released. Took ages to matchmake with someone, no crossplay, desyncing issues, audio desync, etc.

Invasions sucks. Krypt should be a staple in all MK games.
Kameo system is interesting but not fun. It's boring to press the same button and do the same moves again. Also to pay for some Kameos is an absolute joke. At best they should've been unlocked through game progressions.
DLC being ¬£40 is laughable.
Crossover characters were the focus in the DLC. Base characters were forgotten and not so polished.
Story is just bad. As expected when going down the road of timelines and alternative universes.
Graphics were great, hopefully they keep this level for their next game.

Afraid won't be returning to this game anytime soon.

Man, this game hits hard.
From the first punch to the last fatality, MK1 feels slick. The visuals are insane, the hits feel heavy, and those slow-motion bone-crunching moments still make me grin every single time üòà

Story mode? Short but cinematic as hell. Liu Kang really out here playing God and rewriting everything.
Kameo system? Honestly a cool idea ‚Äî adds variety and some wild combos once you get used to it.

Yeah, balance isn‚Äôt perfect, and online sometimes feels like I‚Äôm fighting the Wi-Fi instead of the opponent üòÖ
But damn, when it works, it works.

MK1 proves again that no one does brutal fighting like NetherRealm.
If you love MK, this one‚Äôs a must. Just... prepare to lose a few friendships in versus mode üòè

Overall:
I definitely consider this my favorite Mortal Kombat game so far. It has the best skins and the story is overall also not so bad. 
The gameplay is alright, the Kameo system is something new, but it's quite alright in my eyes.
The music is also great, along with the new fighting stages.

My recommendation:
Buy the Definitive Edition, when it gets a discount, and then log in with your Warner Bros Account, and when you play the PlayStation version for example, you can use the same account to log in and get all your stuff over to the other platform, as everything is synced.

Shop:
The main currency are Dragon Krystals, they are not synced at the same time on all platforms, they are stored on the platform, where they were originally bought from, and can be used to buy Premium skins or Accessories, and the best part: the items you buy, are directly synced to the account cloud, so you can use them on any platform you play, a big plus.

Skins:
But as a long fan of the MK-franchise, I am very happy to see, that for some fighters, skins from the older games have been brought back to the store, which shows, that the developers care about the older games and are bringing parts of them back to the newer generation.

Performance:
I play MK1 mainly on the PS5, because in my opinion, the PS5 shows the best graphics qualities and it runs better.
The Steam version is just as good, there are some minor issues, but I prefer the console port overall.

More:
And I'm glad we finally got a proper look at Outworld )

Okay so this review is coming from a long time MK fan but a Kasual fighter gamer. I am recommending it but only at a discount like what I got it at.

I enjoyed the story (Part 1 and its fun finale), the slower pace of the fights took some getting used to but its okay, the graphics are very nice.
The plot was pretty entertaining and I do like the overall lore of the MK games. Its just something I enjoy. I do like SOME of the updated designs like Liu Kang. I do appreciate theres lots of skins but I wont be grinding them out or buying them.
But thats all the positives really. The main reason I recommend it, is for the Story. I treated it like an 8 hour story game and thats it.

Now for the negatives. I hate the Kameo system. Truly. Its repetitive and feels clunky. The Kameo characters are utterly pointless, badly made and I engaged with it as little as possible. The designs and flat out redesigns of some characters is baffling. Some characters look flat out awful now or at best no longer even are who they are supposed to be. And a lot  look rather bland or generic. The part II Khaos story was boring and I find myself wishing it would end. Which is in contrast to the Part 1 which I enjoyed immensely. Also as a side note, apparently 'Khaos' basically means having a mohawk, bad skin and utilising ugly colours in your skins. I do not enjoy the invasion board game thing at all. Its slow and monotonous and I gave up half way through the first one after the tutorial. The crypt is also completly absent.

As others have stated this is I think this is just inferior to MK11 in almost every single way. I bought this game at a STEEP discount and thats the only reason I enjoyed it and recommend it. Im glad I waited 2 years to play it. It was not worth full price. I will now uninstall it and never touch it again most likely.

[b]A Fresh Start That Delivers the Brutal Goods [/b]

After 6 hours with Mortal Kombat 1, I can confidently say NetherRealm has successfully rebooted the timeline without losing what makes this franchise iconic.

 [b]The Good: [/b]
The graphics are genuinely impressive. Every bone-crunching fatality, every facial expression during story cutscenes, and the environmental details all showcase how far the series has come. The gore looks sickeningly good (in the best way possible), and the character models are some of the best I've seen in a fighting game.

What really surprised me was how well the story integration works. Instead of feeling like an afterthought, the narrative gives context to why you're fighting and makes you actually care about the roster. The timeline reset opens up interesting character dynamics and relationships that feel fresh, even for longtime fans. It's not just "here's a ladder mode with some cutscenes" - there's genuine effort to make the story matter.

[b]The Recommendation: [/b]
If you enjoy fighting games with actual substance beyond just the combat, or if you're a returning fan curious about where the series goes after MK11, this is absolutely worth your time. The combination of satisfying gameplay, visual spectacle, and a story that respects your intelligence makes this an easy recommendation.

 [b]Verdict:  [/b]MK1 proves you can teach an old franchise new tricks while keeping its spine-ripping soul intact. Recommended.

i like it

I stopped playing Mortal Kombat 1 a while ago, but I still felt like I needed to leave a review.

The story mode was a highlight. It was over the top in the best Mortal Kombat way and did a good job reimagining familiar characters in this new timeline. Fights felt intense and flashy, and landing brutal combos or finishing moves never really got old.

Positives. The combat system is fast and fun, with a lot of depth if you want to put in the time to learn it. The new Kameo mechanic adds variety and makes matches feel fresh. The visuals and presentation are excellent, and the story is entertaining enough to keep you engaged from start to finish.

Negatives. The online experience is where the game started to drag for me. Too many matches came down to people spamming the same combo or move over and over, which got frustrating instead of fun. It sometimes felt less like testing skill and more like testing patience. Balance could also be inconsistent depending on the characters you faced, and matchmaking did not always feel fair. Also, some of the post launch content and balance decisions were mixed and it felt like the game struggled to find its footing after release.

Overall, Mortal Kombat 1 gave me plenty of good moments, especially in the story and casual play. But the online side of things made me step away sooner than I expected. I still think it is worth playing if you enjoy the series or fighting games, but be prepared for the online environment to be hit or miss.

This is one of the worst Mortal Kombat games I have ever played. As someone who usually plays the single player modes in MK games, I am absolutely baffled by the insane difficulty of the Invasions/Towers of Time modifiers. Especially the super armor for every single attack given to bosses with multiple health bars while you only get one health bar and no super armor. I get that the intended way to balance this out was to use the Talismans and Relics to buff yourself up, but after over 20 hours of playing through Invasions, I still don't have anything to help me break through super armor. Maybe I have the materials to craft one, but I don't know how to craft anything because the game never explained it in an understandable way.

Oh yeah, and the story sucks, but that's kind of par for the course for NRS titles at this point.

[h1] Horrible at launch, but a Kombat well worth it in 2025 [/h1] 

I do not want to shine with my playtime here, I only want to provide credibility for the fact that I am a rather experienced MK player and, in fact, not a Noob [spoiler] Saibot [/spoiler] 
I have a total of around 500 hours on this game, previously played on PS5 and now PC. Also, I have over 5000 hours on MK11 on PS4/5 as we speak. As someone who has been playing the game at launch and now again after the Khaos Reigns DLC, I fundamentally disagree with the general opinion of most diehard Mortal Kombat fans about this game being worse than 11 or X, even though I felt the same way at launch, so let me take a deep dive into: 1. The controversial woke genderswap DEI Cyrax and Sektor situation + the controversial story ending (no spoilers) 2. Netherrealms supposed greed (spoiler: its WB, their publisher) and the kameo feature 4. the current state of the game (for both online and solo players)

Oh boy, lets start with the most controversial one: Cyrax and Sektor (previously being badass ninja robots) are now females in nanosuits, one is of african origin and one is chinese. Let me be straight forward: They could have just added in their previous variants and we would have all been okay with that nonetheless woke af move, but they did NOT deliver, they made it even WORSE!! by adding in their previous variants for the KAMEO VARIANTS OF CYRAX AND SEKTOR I AM NOT JOKING! However, here is the real problem, which is our perspective of everything: would we, as a 12 year old boy who just started this game. really have cared about stuff like that at all? Nope, we would have had an amazing time. Of course its woke and trust me I am annoyed too, but anyone not familiar with this movement or simply from a generation below us simply does not see things the same way we do, and we have to accept that I guess. I feel like this game and MK11 suffer the fate of Star Wars Episode 3. (for those who do not know what I mean, that movie was seemingly hated by most and presumably worse than 4,5 or 6, when in reality, all of the children absolutely loved Episode 3 more than anything else, they were just too young to express themselves. About 8-10 years after the release the movie (and the actor of Anakin) were finally given the praise and love they deserved.

About the ending: It was an absolute pleasure to see the story end up being a huge nod to all the oldschool fans, and I absolutely loved it. Please do not listen to others and have your own opinion is all I want to say here.

2. I do not intend to sugarcoat anything here: this game was being sold as a HUGE cashgrab over the years, waiting for the DLC characters and gatekeeping so many skins to have them added into the ingame store later on - horrible to say the least. But now in 2025 with the definitive edition out, this game is finally komplete enough to be enjoyable. The tutorial of this game is hands down the best tutorial of any fighting game ever made, so even though the learning curve is still crazy (especially playing ranked), the devs REALLY cooked with this one. My friends (who have never touched a fighting game before) joined me after kompleting the tutorial and now we are beating each other in King of the Hill matches every evening (KotH is a gamemode in which the player who wins keeps on fighting other kombatants, essentially being the "King" of the lobby.), and while they are having the time of their lives hitting their first kombos (the kameos help new players a lot which is not a bad thing in my opinion as a tryhard will instantly kick your sh** in as soon as you do unsafe stuff anyway lol), I am having the time of my life learning new characters and making my friends rage. For MK beginners: This will be the most rage inducing game you will ever play, and you will love it after getting ur first wins. 

[spoiler] EDIT: I HAVE BEEN PRACTICING FOR 10 HOURS TO GET BEAT THE FCK UP BY A GUY NAMED "uWuBoy2009" IT LEAVES STAINS ON UR MENTAL HEALTH [/spoiler] 

The kameo feature, which has been absolutely HATED by most of us at launch (including me) is now really fun to play around with and negate some of your main characters weaknesses. Yes, it should have been either a tag team game or just a normal MK, hell, there is so much wasted potential in the franchise as a whole and the kameos are proof of that: why give us "kameos" instead of fully playable characters? Now, nobody cares about how ur kameo looks because you rarely even see it and even if you do, you would have to be concentrating on the enemy and not their kameo. To come to an end: The kameos are additional attack inputs for your main you can use to start,extend (or drop) combos, or play mind games with your enemy, nothing else. You could go online without ever using them and kick ass just because you know your character.

4. the current state of the game: As of 09/19/2025, Cyrax, Havik, Noob Saibot and Ermac are undoubtedly the top 4 characters in the game, which obviously does not mean you are a noob for playing them (try hitting a kombo on Noob even ONCE) or that you will instalose against them. In this game, knowledge beats anything, and while you may think during your journey that the enemies are using OP or unblockable stuff on you, it is in fact a huge skill issue and you just need to learn how to outplay all the characters. If you are a kasual player, MK11 was definitely a lot easier than this game, but nonetheless you have an (now fun, back in the days annoying af) invasion mode, and towers of time in which you can unlock over 322 skins as we speak and get your reps with your main in. 

For online players: As a Noob, prepare to get wrapped up like a burrito and 
[spoiler] EMBRACE KHAOS! [/spoiler] embrace the rage you will feel while playing this game online. You will catch up with the people. Give it time, give it practive and dedication and you will be hooked to Mortal Kombat for the rest of your life.

This game could have been something great. A shame to see it fall short with fans. Gameplay can only do so much, it was fun but the story was all over the place. I'm a new fan but grew up with cousins that enjoyed the previous installments, I figured I could link up with them and enjoy a fresh story. Boy, what a story. I think it's unfortunate that so many of us are tired of the Multiverse plotline. Marvel at least took the time to set up some of their movies before executing the idea. Right out the gate this game does multiverse shenanigans that continue into their DLC content. I feel like had the writers took their time, somethings could have been better realized. 

Something that was interesting (and later flopped) was the different takes of the same characters. I thought it was neat and refreshing but then confusing when you have legacy characters like Hanzo (Scorpion) being swapped for Kuai Liang (Sub Zero). Some motives were funky. I havent played the DLC yet and, honestly, with how much the fandom enjoyment has dwindled, I'm not in a rush to purchase it.

That being said, I do enjoy looking hotties in any videogame. Whoever designed the Lin Kuei brothers, I need those models naked on my desk PRONTO.............no particular reason.
Just leaving a PSA/reminder to try capping your framerate at 60 via some external method (Nvidia Control Panel, etc.) if fights aren't running smoothly despite your hardware or settings.

In a few words, it lacks content. There is nothing to do in this game, besides grinding the same towers/invasions for the same outfits (with different colours, they refer to them as palettes). Different skins/outfits are there to unlock, but too far and few. All the good stuff is locked behind their premium currency, which you need purchase with real money. 

Once you play through a season and finish all the invasion maps, basically that is when the game ends. If you like to grind, then you'd enjoy it. If you don't, then I suggest skipping this one or waiting for a sale big time.
Absolute PEAK

What can I say?

The gameplay sucks. But honestly, that's usually the case with NRS games, they just have this stiff, wooden feel that isn't super fun. That said, the basic systems in this game do make it pretty easy for even a masher like myself to do some half-arsed juggles, which is nice.

The really unfortunate part is the plot. Yeah, I know, no one expects the plot in an MK game to be fine art but one does expect it to be enjoyably cheesy. Unfortunately in the case of this game it's just poorly written in a way that isn't particularly fun. There is a lot of yapping and most of it does not flow very well.

Beyond that, the voice acting is quite atrocious. Most characters get their chance to utter a line or two that sound completely off-tone for the scene at hand but only Nitara, voiced by the "illustrious" Megan Fox, manages to sound like a poor quality text-to-speech system from a decade ago 100% of the time. Rather unfortunate since I like her gameplay (mainly due to having an airdash. Yes, I play anime fighters and love my airdashes. You should too).

Other than that, what else to say...

Modern american triple A gaming in a nutshell:

1. Pay full retail price
2. immediately see greyed out features and options behind a paywall
3. "Unlock each of these features for 30 shlongobongo coins" 
4. Purchase 29 shlongobongo coins for 5.99USD! 

(OR a one time purchase of all bonus content for 1.7X the price of the actual game)

Mortal Kombat is no different.
The content you guys produce is high quality, but you diminish the integrity of your product with so many crappy guest characters and paywalled OG characters.   

I'm telling you in advance that when "MK2" comes out I will NOT be purchasing the Outworld Archie bunker or Tarkatan Stephen Urkel Kharacter pack DLKs.  Also....you let sweetbabyinc bully you into giving them money to ruin your game?  

Do you honestly need THAT much help on good direction and storycrafting?  You want me to give you guys a hand with that?? I'm being serious here....

Anyway,  I give this a 7/10.  A decent title hampered by scuzzy modern marketing tactics and focus group pandering.

A well-made Mortal Kombat game! Apart from minor annoyances from the DLC and DLC's characters, it's amazing. Game looks beautiful, the main story is good. DLC story is meh. Gameplay is proper MK.
Game's very enjoyable with friends locally/online/stream remote. Playing online is... sometimes frustrating because a lot of people learn one combo and spam it in-game and unless you know the counter you're kinda screwed. I also recommend learning one fighter character fully if you want to give online a shot, because that will increase your chances of winning dramatically, even against sweats and one-combo spammers, regardless of you knowing the match-up in full, or just your own fighter. It's better to play kasual mode instead of ranked, ranked has way more one-combo sweats.
I recommend this to any MK fan or anyone who wants to get into fighting games.

Sadly, I cannot recommend this game. As a long-time fan of the series, I have played every Mortal Kombat game that has been released on PC. I have over 1,000 hours in MK11, and I bought this one right after its release.

Bringing back characters that weren't in the previous installment of the game like Ermac, Ashrah, Li Mei or Havik was a great idea, the graphics are really decent and the gameplay would be fine too, however, a few key changes make the game drastically lose its value.

Firstly, the Kameo characters ‚Äì I understand the idea behind this, but it completely doesn't fit the Mortal Kombat playstyle. I often found myself completely ignoring the existence of these characterss, both solo and ranked, despite the advantages they offer. From what I understand, the game was originally intended to be Injustice 3, which didn't happen for reasons unknown to me. While this idea could have worked in Injustice, here it's a completely unnecessary addition that poorly justifies the lack of more iconic characters like Kano, Sonya, or Goro.

Secondly, there's a lack of any solo play content. In the previous installment, we had the Crypt and Towers of Time, which easily sufficed for hours of gameplay. There was grinding, that's true, but it was rewarded with cosmetic items. In MK11, we could customize our weapons, masks, and even our character's intro/outro, which provided a unique customization for every player. In this game, everything was hidden behind greedy monetization, with time-based called "Invasion" events that were incredibly boring with stupid and frustrating puzzles and the rewards were maybe one unique skin, while the rest were recolors of the base skins. Overall, compared to MK11, this installment feels completely neutered. Even MK10 had more to offer.

The final issue is the discontinuation of support for the game after the release of the first and last DLC, which was unsustainably expensive for its content, leading the studio to complain that the add-on sold poorly.

I hope the next Mortal Kombat will be more thoughtful. It's okay to play occasionally, but there's nothing here that will keep players engaged for enough long time.

It's a decent Mortal Kombat game. I wouldn't say it was the best... The story drags a bit and there is WAY too much focus on Johnny Cage, who they somehow managed to make into even more of an insufferable douche than before. The Fatal Blow Mechanic seems a bit... broken, if not entirely unfair... the fact you could be absolutely dominating a fight and then suddenly lose the whole thing from one cheap squeeze of the triggers is just outrageous. There's a decent mix of characters, though I do wish we could actually play as some of the Kameos... I really miss the days where you could unlock CHARACTERS by playing through the game... I mean, that was a HUGE part of the enjoyment of playing these kinds of games... But no... everything has to be paid DLC these days... and who designed some of these costumes? a blind toddler?
My biggest problem though... the game CONSTANTLY crashes... sometimes I can play for a couple of hours, some times I can only play for 20 minutes, but you can GUARANTEE that every time I play this game it WILL crash... and I know it's not my machine since I can run this on max settings without breaking a sweat.

Me not recommending this doesn't mean I think it's bad on its own or that I didn't have a good time. But compared to other games in the series, it's definitely the weakest for me.

Weakest story arc of the series (and this is coming from cheezy B-movie like stories of other games). Overall atmosphere feels kind of toned down from the heavier, more grave, atmospheres of other games to more of a bright one - almost kids-friendly, shallow and naive. Has some good moments, but overally meh. On the other hand, visual presentation is almost breathtaking - good graphics, cinematic AF, amazing animations, detailed facial expressions.

Kameo system I did not like that much, felt forced kinda. With that said, fighting is fun, animations great and fluid. Goodbye Krypt grinding, which is both good and bad.

Anyway, you're not missing out that much if you skip it until it's on sale 90% off.

i haven't played this in quite a while due to the insane amount of storage required (like 200gb) and sadly i do not have much more than that on my laptop... but it is AMAZING. i love it, so much. i could go on for hours about it but i will only talk about the important things, you're welcome in advance.

the character designs are all incredible, arguably all the characters best designs out of all the games (save for cyrax, love him in mk9), voice actors did an amazing job (except megan fox voicing nitara... stick to acting girl you CANNOT put emotion into this? or else she just didn't try...) because they have so much life, the combos are so fun and i'm so glad we have another _ality feature!!! (in this game it's animalities, we've also had friendships and babalities!!) it runs very well imo, not much lag for my computer that has a hard time running things, amazing story pacing and lots of content,, so mad i don't have the expansion pack :( absolutely love the cameos because they're all so good as per usual!! i also LOVE hearing johnny as my announcer, it's so perfect.. heh

only thing i'm sad about besides the insane storage required is that there is no krypt.. sigh,, one of my favourite features in the games D: thought don't get me wrong, invasions is SO FUN!!! i know everyone has bad things to say but i literally don't care it's so good. i got it for like 80 AUD and i do not regret it one bit. i just regret not having enough storage.. smh.

Maybe the game itself could be enjoyable to play. But I can't tell - because I spent 90 minutes trying to play at least one match without lags.

Here is what my experience is:
1. Shader compilation for almost an hour (idk what this game compiles that long)
2. Launching auto graphics setup
3. Waiting for a few minutes to load into match
4. Quit the match to go change settings
5. Settings are now set to the lowest
6. A few minutes of scrolling youtube shorts while waiting to start a match with the bot
7. Even though I have 60 fps all the time (basic limit because I don't need more), game freezes at random points of time

Summary: 
I've waited almost an hour to see the main menu. 
I had to go watch some youtube shorts to get into match with AI.
Even though I had game automatically set me High quality level, game freezes even at the lowest settings while periodically just showing black screen

MK 11 ran smooth and lag-free on high graphics settings while this one takes eternity to get into the laggy main menu.

So, I take back what I said before, MK1 is actually a pretty good game once you get deeper into it. At first, I was kinda meh about the combat, but after playing more and actually learning how it flows, I have to admit it‚Äôs solid. The combos feel way more satisfying once you get the hang of them. Kameos? Honestly, they‚Äôre still kinda unnecessary in my opinion, but I can‚Äôt deny they add some fun and variety. If you‚Äôre into experimenting with playstyles, they‚Äôre actually a nice addition. Story-wise‚Ä¶ nah, my opinion hasn‚Äôt changed. Still not a fan of how they handled it, but hey, if you‚Äôre buying MK1 for the story, you‚Äôre doing it wrong. This game shines when it comes to fighting.
Oh, and yeah, I‚Äôll just say it straight up: I simp for Kitana. Get it, guys?
Overall, if you want sharp combat and a solid fighting experience, MK1 delivers. Just don‚Äôt expect the story to blow your mind.

It's astonishing how NRS can make game this fun and manage to ruin with so much dump shit and greediness. The core gameplay is my favorite of any MK game. Originally I didn't think I'd like the kameo system at all, but it quickly grew on me. Making/developing combos has never been more fun though kameo system does have problems especially concerning balance. Still the gameplay styles are lot more diverse than in previous MK games where everyone spammed the same 1 or 2 combos per character.

Also I love that this game has proper air combos. 

So the gameplay is really great, graphics are amazing and I also enjoyed the story more than in previous installments. It was nothing mind blowing, but I enjoyed the new spins on the characters.  I didn't enjoy the multiverse aspect of it, but I understand why they lean into it.

Sound design in this game is also probably one of the best from any games. The sounds feel real but extremely satisfying and the amount detail they put into it is astonishing.

So what went wrong then? Firstly they added so much dump stuff all across the game. Both of invasions and towers of time would be great gamemodes if it weren't for extremely infuriating mini games and game designs like the element system that has no place or purpose in a fighting game like MK. Most of the modifiers are only annoyances that disrupt the core gameplay. Also both Tower of time and invasion are ridiculously easy even the very hard towers unless you get a character boss that has your weakness element meaning you deal abysmal damage and their shields do more damage to you than you do with constant long combos.  Not to mention the extra moves that are both unblockable and undodgeable. There is nothing fun about it. If you want to make bosses in a game like this then just give them more health and make the AI harder. Some of these problems would be easily fixed by simply giving extra option for hard and very hard mode for all towers and removing the whole element system and reworking how the bosses work.

Also towers of time or invasions doesn't have character intros which is straight up idiotic. What's the point of hiring voice actors if you never hear them?

So only proper singleplayer fun you can get is from the story mode and the classic towers which do not have any dump modifiers and you can set preferred difficulty. Sadly classic towers do not contribute to invasion season points so if you want skins you need grind invasion matches or towers of time.

Multiplayer can be lot of fun, but can also be toxic as hell. I had some problems with desyncing, but noticeably less than in MK11. I would like to see in the future that you could make custom matches/lobbies with modifiers which affects both or only one player. This way even unevenly skilled friends can play and both have fun.

Second major gripe is the customization that got massive downgrade from MK11 and Injustice2 which was one of my favorite aspects of those games. Getting  most skins in this game is not rewarding and it's plagued with greedy monetization. Overall the skins are mixed bag, but it mostly comes down to personal preference. Still overall more good than bad. Some of the redesigns I do not like and others are literally some of the best skins ever. Still I would have preferred to actually have some customization options instead of picking premade skins.

I really would've liked to give this game a positive review despite it's controversies, but the amount of idiotic features, designs and minigames infuriates me way too much. Still if you enjoy these types of games I would recommend to give it a try though only get it during sale and not full price.

Mortal Kombat 1 is a bold reboot of the iconic fighting franchise ‚Äî delivering brutal combat, stunning visuals, and a fresh timeline twist that breathes new life into the MK universe.

The story mode is cinematic and engaging, with high production value and a creative reimagining of classic characters. Gameplay is smooth and responsive, and the addition of the Kameo system adds new layers of strategy to fights without overwhelming newcomers.

Visually, the game is absolutely gorgeous. From the detailed character models to the insanely over-the-top Fatalities, everything feels polished and intense. Online performance has improved since launch, though some matchmaking and netcode issues can still pop up occasionally.

The only major downside? The monetization. Premium skins and grind-heavy unlocks can make the experience feel a bit commercialized, especially for a full-priced title..

For added context, I have played all the previous MKs for years now and even engaged in some tournaments AND have multiple hundred of hours on PS5

I feel very conflicted about this game. I REALLY dig the graphics and the stages (they are ABSOLUTE work of art). Fatalities are back to the core of quick, brutal and efficient contrasting with MK11's longer and more cinematic ones. A LOT of returning characters from older titles which will put a smile on veteran's faces and finally, a few of the GREATEST collab characters in MK history (CMON, Homelander and Omni-man? That shit slaps!)

However, things do fall off rather quickly when it comes to the rest. The pace is at a perfect middle ground within the slow and punishing MK12 and the break neck speed that was MKX. The new KAMEO system I think is pretty good, you can get very wacky with the combos. The problem of this games comes from Netherreal themselves, not the game.

The garbage balancing killed this game. I am not kidding when I say that in one PRO tournament, 98% of the competitors were all using the same character due to how broken it was (Peacemaker), I had never seen something so atrocious in years. The game is INSANELY poorly optimized and they didnt even bothered to compress it (over 118 GB for a fighter, are we serious?). 

The story start up decent and then offs itself near the middle to morph into the overused "multiverse" trope and completely fails to use it on top of it

All of this combined with the base price, the crazy amount of dlcs and the fact that they confirmed that support for this game will end up soon, I think its safe to say that I cannot recommend this game. Maybe get it during a HUGE sale but other than that, stick with MKX or MK11

I am done with Mortal Kombat!

Let me explain...
I was a big fan of Mortal Kombat! Although not being able to have the full experience with the 3d games and those before 
NetherRealm Studios, I played a lot and respected the new ones as much as I could. After the release of MK11, things started to change. The story began to deteriorate, the devs decided to be scummy with their prices overall the new products and DLCs; too expensive and they rarely give us a worthy sale!

The quality of the new releases are also bad because the community has high expectations, but all they release are either fan services which its by overall straight up repetition all over with rarely anything new!

By short, when they decided to add timelines to this series, basically showed us the lack of actual potential of being creative and they kept giving us Marvel style garbage slope; although I must agree that the story was getting to an end and making a new one was probably smart, but poorly managed!
The story DLCs and the character DLCs are also not worth it of how bad and short they are!

Now by gameplay wise, the experience can be either stable or the game could be full of lag despite reducing its resolution and other settings.

You can agree if you want, this was only my own perspective through these years, but if you're really into MK still and you love the new games, I would highly recommend you to wait for a sale instead of buying it at a full price; if not then don't! 
This is where my chapter with this series ends!

It's Mortal Kombat, a very solid fighting game as always! The introduction of Kameos, though met with mixed feelings, is very fun! Though if what you are looking for is a good continuation from the story of the last game, I would not recommend! 10/10

this game is fun. One of the good MK game but there are still things that could've done better. This game better is than MKX in character model and graphics bur remaining things like story, combat etc... MKX wins!!
my rating for this game is 6/10.

POSITIVES:
1. starting with graphics, the graphics is done so well, all the character models and their clothing are detailed and designed well.
2. The world is so beautiful and vibrant.
3. Very good optimisation, as far as i played there's no glitch or bug but there are some mis-inputs.
4. Visual effects, the particle effects and the animations are improved a lot while comparing to the previous games also the arenas are well designed and vibrant.
5. The game has introduced interesting guest characters but i still miss Kratos. 
6. The cameos introduced it this game balances the characters, like if the main character doesnt have projectiles you can choose the cameo with projectiles for fight. 

NEUTRAL:
1. Story is good but  could've been better, players can easily predict what happens next and some twists can be easily guessed.
2. Brutalities are good but could've been improved as many look similar. Same goes for Fatalities too.
3. Combat is not as good as MKX. MKX had a really very good and snappy combat.

NEGATIVES:
1.  The blood look like paint, also the bone breaking are not that much snappy as it was in MKX.
2. The game introduced Cameo system, i feel its dumb. Previous games had interactive objects during fight which made the fight more interesting but this game ruined it. Timing and planning the attacks based on the environment was more interesting.
3. The arenas look beautiful and vibrant but whats the point? As i mentioned that earlier games had interactive objects unique for each arena made the every arena unique and interesting but here every arena feels the same.
4. I feel the crypt is much more interesting than this invasion mode introduced in this game, initially the invasion more felt interesting but its grinding, after a few minutes of playing invasion mode, it feels so annoying.
5. Customisation is so nice but only if you, i hate the palette system too, also players cannot change the customisation in the selection menu, players should change the armours and clothes only in customisation.
6. Online is WORST.

If you can over look a very bad story and an extreme amount of woke crap including gender swapping and race changing to push a political agenda and you are a big Mortal Kombat fan then. Yes I can recommend this game to you. But as soon as the new Mortal kombat comes out Jump ship to that game.

I was really hyped for this game and bought it as pre-order. But from the first week of release its all gone. Story was bad, I mean really bad. They did not bother anything to explain why? For example how did Kuai-Liang got his scorpion powers? Why  there is a Tournament at all if neither of realms attacked each other? There is so many B.S events in this "Liu-Kang Era". 

Then the gameplay. This game is not for a casual player. If you play this game, you have to master both main and the cameo characters. In the old MK games if you want to play Mileena just practise Mileena combos. In this game if you want to play Mileena you need to practise both Mileena and Cameo characters. For example, to get max damage Mileena+scorpion, for defence Mileena+ Sub zero, for zone control Mileena+Kano etc. Now multiply this all main characters and all cameo characters. And you have to be precise (For some interactions milisecond precise) on timing with cameo characters otherwise you will drop your combo. So if you are a casual player you'll end up playing just 1-2 characters most of the time. 

When the game first released, some characters like kenshi, raiden+Cyrax duo, johnny cage was really broken. They fixed some of it but still some characters very weak against others. This is really annoying. For example Johnny Cage doesn't need a guest character at all. His skill kit let him extend the combos on his own with a high damage, lets him make pressure with + on block moves and bunch of 50/50's . So good luck in multiplayer mode.

And the single player mode. AKA "invasions". You need to do same matches over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over again. To get what? a couple skins and items. (BTW They are not actual skins, just same skin with different colours and mostly they are terrible and items are barely noticible in game) Isn't here any good skins? Yes there is. But you have to pay at least five bucks. Anyting looking good is behind a paywall in this game. 

This game made for selling DLC's. DLC caharactes like quan-chi and ermac. They aren't supposed to DLC characters. They are in the main story. And this year Netherrealm put the last nail on the coffin. Chaos Reigns Expansion. A DLC with a same price tag of a main game. What a brilliant idea. Is it worth? Absolutely not. The Story was even worse. Characters acting like bad guys in cartoons. No motive, no meaning. "We are bad guys just because". Even Kronika has a motive. And also DLC characters mostly terrible. They should add at least another 20 characters to put a price tag of 50 bucks.

Long story short Netherrealm studios and WB messed up this game big time with their greed. The game looks very good from the beginnig.  Its fun for a couple hours. Then nothing more. If you  play at least 2-3 hours daily you can have fun some time later in multiplayer mode. Otherwise game is shallow.

Mortal Kombat!

I did play Sub Zero mythologies but that was like Battlefield Hardline in a way, just a spin off. Not an "official" numbered release by them. I played some of the stuff through the years but mostly started playing it again with 9 up till now.

But just like the original Battlefield 1942 which started in 2003 btw, I was there when this franchise began back in the 90s.

Players were immediately wowed at the digitized graphics.

After its initial release, a bit after, came Mortal Kombat 2. The game had been streamlined....optimized.

The controls smoother, the power moves more strategic and effective. This transition was like Windows Vista VS Windows 7................Battlefield 3 VS Battlefield 4................you get the idea.

Then came MK 3. This one added the "run" ability. And there were players that could just ware you out with it and the combos too. Imho I did not like it, I thought it was a wrong direction for the game at the time. Maybe I was just subliminally thinking along the lines of the whole "zombies that run" argument years before it was ever a thing .

I point this out because of the similarity to the current cameo system in the modern MK. It was probably a tough choice the developers made to add that. A feature that really changed the foundation of the core game.

Kind of like side stepping in MK4 and a few on. Mortal 4 was the first outing as a completely 3d MK, completely composed of 3d graphics. I guess that made it a mile stone in ways.

ALL the fighting games that are still being made today seem to be like that. Completely composed of 3d assets. But why do that if the end result is just a 2d canvas? lol

I got back into it with 9. It was a much more streamlined 3d then 4 was. I got 10 and 11 on sale here @ Steam. Something about 11 really reminded me of 2. I thought it was polished, balanced, etc etc. To me that is the best 3d MK they have made.

MK 12 or ONE as they called it in their name revision reboot thing. I did actually like the story a lot. Carrying over from 11, Liu Kang essentially became Raiden and did what Raiden did. And Raiden gave his powers to Liu Kang and he starts the universe over. Now Raiden is essentially Liu Kang in a bit of a time paradox. As a bible believer in the modern day I do believe that Jesus Christ has the power to do such a thing with someone. After all he said in his father's house were "many mansions". What is a mansion? A really big house, many rooms. I guess you could think of that as cities, states, nations, worlds, realities, depending on the size and scope of your imagination.

I thought the controls and graphics were decent, but I still look to 11 as being the 3d peak at this point. As said before I did not like the cameo system but I thought it was really well done, likely a nightmare to program.

MK12 (AKA MK1) does a lot of things right, and a lot of things wrong.

Let's start with the cons:
1. An MTX nightmare. For those of us that have been battling against MTX business practices, this game has all the trappings of a problem. I am not just talking about DLC purchases for story and character unlocks. They have an in game currency bought with real world money that is used to do nothing but buy skins for characters. There is also a semi-lootbox situation (the shrine) but that doesn't seem to be based on real world money
2. Story: I absolutely loath multiverse and time travel. Every IP is doing it. Every IP is failing from including it. It lacks an original idea, just "let me copy your home work"
3. Kameos are just meh. There are two few of them, and honestly? I don't like that the kameos are locked to the small number of kameo characters
4. Lacking in characters: For both story and multiplayer roster I feel like the exclusion of characters is painful. No Sonya Blade and Jax? Really? Fine, no Jax, but you're essentially rebooting the story and include all the usual suspects from MK1 (1992) EXCEPT Sonya? Fail. Scorpion is no longer Hanzo? Fail.

The pros:
1. Gameplay is great. The combos flow nicely, invasions is a nice touch IMO. Lots of modes to play around with. Online, couch, and cpu versus, tournament rules, various tower kombat. It has all I expect at the bare minimum plus some new stuff
2. Graphics are absolutely gorgeous
3. Steam Deck functionality. It works just fine on the deck
4. Character customisation: now while I hate MTX for skins, I do like when the game gives you skins for progression in various modes and story, which MK1 also does. It's fun when they let me customise the character
5. Story: While I have issues with the time travel and multiverse nonsense (as stated above) SOME changes to the timeline are absolutely fun for me. As a Reptile main, I love the implications of him and Ashrah, and I love that he's not a bad guy anymore

Verdict:
Wait for a discount, like I did. While good, not worth the full price.

To everyone on the fence, who played the previous games, I will list the differences here. Mainly between this game and MK11.
1) THEY REMOVED FRENDSHIPS!!!! NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO
To me, personally, this was the worst news that I learned the hard way, by buying and playing. The mere idea of having Friendships in MK11 was a bit wholesome. Now they're gone. But in return, Animalities have made a komeback.
2a) To unlock finishing movies, instead of finding them at random in the Krypt, you get them by winning fights as the fighter and Kameo, as there is a ranking system for each fighter and each kameo, separately. To me, this is the best news that I learned the hard way by playing the game. Which brings me to my next point:
2b) The fighter that you choose and the Kameo that you choose each have their own separate fatalities and brutalities, and you kan use either one to finish off an opponent. BTW, you still get more points by doing brutalities in Towers, so never do fatalities, always try to do brutalities. Which brings me to my next point:
2c) They also got rid of Mercy. So if you f*** up a brutality, you don't get another chance, you have to use a fatality or an animality.
3) To me, so far, the fatalities and and animalities are a lot more forgiving when it komes to how far you are way from your opponent to perform them.
4a) Was Scorpion your favorite fighter in the previous game? TOO BAD! He's now only a kameo kharacter.
4b) Quan Chi is, I believe, both a fighter and a Kameo? Idk how they explain that lore-wise.
4c) Also Motaro has come back, but only as a Kameo.
5) They've gone back to where you use the block button as the special move enhancer. I think MK11 totally missed the mark on this, having you use the stupid interact button to enhance special moves. Pfft.
6) Match-up intros are slightly less cool than MK11's, but they're still nice. For some reason, the intro inkludes one of the kharacters hitting the other and knocking them over. It doesn't subtrakt from your health in the fight, but it still seems a tiny bit demoralizing. 
Potato) Peacemaker, Homelander, and Ghost Face (from the movie series "Scream") are funny.
7) Runs better than MK11, but its file size has more heft to it. 
8) Nitara is back. Step on me pls mommy
9) Madam Bo, too. Would.

Mortal Kombat 1 looked super promising, but yeah‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs kind of dead now. The campaign‚Äôs cool, but super short, and there‚Äôs really nothing to do once you‚Äôre done. Online is pretty much empty ‚Äî barely anyone‚Äôs playing. There are more people active in Guilty Gear XX Acent Core Plus R from 2012.

Honestly, the graphics is amazing and the gameplay's solid, but there‚Äôs just not much keeping you around. Not worth buying

It‚Äôs a shame. I have been a fan of the franchise for a long time. While it seems like they‚Äôve made some improvements over the years Im many respects, it seems like they‚Äôve taken some steps back. 

The gameplay itself is decent, and although Im not a huge fan of the kameo mechanic, it provides a lot of diversity to the games (even though most online games feature the same non-diverse characters). The net code is also awesome, game feels great and actually playable at pings like 180. 

Solo content is abysmal. The towers feel repetitive and just stupid in a lot of respects. I don‚Äôt want to get bullied through silly armour attacks, I want to be beaten by respectable computer brains and modifiers. And the invasions single player mode is very 1 dimensional. Big step back from mk 11‚Äôs towers and krypt mode. 

Fan favourite characters being hidden behind a paywall is also a cheeky marketing strategy. Im all for paying extra money for ghostface or omniman, but paying for beloved characters like quan chi or havik (should have been in the game to begin with) don‚Äôt feel great. Not only that, but a lot of dlc characters and kameos are front runners in the meta. 

All in all, even on special, the game didn‚Äôt feel great to buy. It‚Äôs a good game in a lot of respects, but it‚Äôs sad to see a once beloved franchise falling victim to corporate marketing nonsense. Besides that, it seems like so much is invested into making the game look good, and while the game does look absolutely beautiful, it isn‚Äôt particularly the selling point for mortal kombat games. It feels like we need a game with an arcade feel to it like mkx. Realism is great and all, but it‚Äôs okay for a game to feel like a game still. Customisation options like mk11 was awesome. I loved the dress my character like a Barbie doll feature, and the move customisation was sick, although Im sure it was a logistical balance nightmare. 

I want to love the game, we all do.
