This is a very neutral-rating game. I wouldn't recommend it but I wouldn't tell casual players that it's a terrible game. I think casual & single-players will have a lot of fun and frustration with it, especially focusing on Invasions and towers of time but that's really all it has to offer. 

Story mode is a long cutscene with a sloppy plot trying to retcon everything that's been done without really moving forward to something new. What IS new is the Kameo system, which tends to lock your characters to certain kameos so you can actually use your moveset in a combo, and that really only comes from trial and error. Speaking of kameos, I get the big feeling they were severely rushed as a later idea.. they have minimal cosmetics, no gear, close to no presence on-screen, and an incredibly limited moveset. Some of these kameos were even characters requested as full characters. As for full characters? We got nickel and dimed for every single one, they release with minimal cosmetics, refuse to do anything additional with those characters, and cosmetics people want? they will charge you real money for (MK2/3, deception, deadly alliance, conan skins for example). Then NRS pulled the plug the moment they were finished with the quota AFTER Ed Boon wanted to run his greasy mouth that "MK1 will continue to receive support for YEARS". Literally the next fucking week.. 'On to the next game; here's a sale and a spit to the face of our fans'. But, hey, NRS & WB are doing great financially so I can go fuck myself and buy their next entry and do this again.

I've played MKX and MK11, really loved both those games, but MK11 takes my spot in my heart because as a new, casual, and finger illiterate guy, I was able to obtain rewards with their AI towers/battles and get skins without too much trouble.

My biggest gripe with the game and the company as a whole: greed. I'm sorry, but having to monetize skins in a fighting game with extreme prices just pisses me off a lot. Not just that, content and character customizations got reduced to a small fraction in MK1, and really just disappointed me a lot. There are also skins that I actually want, but they are time gated and made obtaining them virtually impossible. Not just that, their "Palettes" dont really make sense as I don't know what they're trying to achieve with their color combinations, something from MK11 where they missed the point of certain characters with a set tone. As a result, I didn't bother to finish their story mode or even try to do their tutorials, just stopped playing it altogether.

I am genuinely disappointed and let down by their downgrade in terms of customization, game loading times and the amount of content cut compared from their previous entry, and just ruined the experience of truly enjoying the game without micro-transactions and time gated bullshit.

[h3]How the hell can you make a game that has the best gameplay in the series, the best graphics, the best presentation and art direction, but still completely mess up the most basic stuff?[/h3]

The offline content is bafflingly stupid. Like, I wouldn‚Äôt have that much of a problem with Towers of Time and Invasions if I could simply play them normally. What do I mean by that? Well, each match in these game modes has a ‚Äúlevel‚Äù and ‚Äúattributes,‚Äù so the CPU might have more health than you, or you might deal more damage of a certain element‚Äîconcepts that have no place in a fighting game.

If you have even half a brain, these matches end in a single combo, since they don‚Äôt have intros and are only one round long. That‚Äôs not fun. You spend 20 seconds clicking ‚ÄúOK ‚Üí NEXT ‚Üí NEXT‚Äù (the rewards for these matches are so dull and boring that they‚Äôre not even worth paying attention to), and then you go to the next match, spend 15 seconds ‚Äúfighting,‚Äù rinse and repeat.

So for every, let‚Äôs say, minute you spend playing this offline ‚Äúcontent,‚Äù at least 50% of that time is spent loading and clicking through menus.

Why? Why the hell did they design it this way? The gameplay is fun, but the game actively stops you from playing it.

Also, why would you spend so much money hiring famous actors (Yuri Lowenthal, Van Damme, Megan Fox, J.K. Simmons, John Cena, etc.) to voice characters, [i]only for the game to skip the intros in pretty much every single mode besides the Classic Towers and VS mode?[/i] And I‚Äôm not even getting into the seasonal content, battle passes, weekly and daily missions, the way they dropped support in just two years, and how ridiculously dumb the story is.

Half of these issues could be solved by simply adding an option to toggle intros ON/OFF and set how many rounds you want to play in Towers and Invasions‚Äîbut NetherRealm couldn‚Äôt even do that.

MK1 is a great game, riddled with horrendous, excruciatingly dumb decisions that ruined its longevity from day one. I‚Äôve been an MK fan since MK9, but MK1 made me drop the franchise and switch to Street Fighter instead.

Let me start by saying this review is not about online multiplayer. I don‚Äôt play it, I don‚Äôt care about ranked ladders, and I have zero interest in hackers, netcode, or any of that. What you‚Äôll find here is a review focused solely on the core experience of Mortal Kombat 1 from the perspective of a long-time fan‚Äîsomeone who grew up with the franchise and still gets hyped for a good story, memorable characters, and throwing hands in style.

And damn, does this game deliver.

[h2]Story & Presentation[/h2]
The story mode is a fantastic reboot‚Äîa much-needed timeline reset that gives fresh outcomes to familiar characters. Whether you're a veteran or a newcomer, there's a real sense of purpose and direction here, and it all comes wrapped in top-tier visuals, cinematic-quality animations, and epic sound work that makes every moment hit harder.

The new narrative approach reimagines the klassics in a way that feels respectful and exciting, with enough twists to keep you locked in from start to finish. I played the entire main story (non-DLC) on Very Hard difficulty in about 10 hours, and I was hooked the whole way through. No crashes, no lost save files, no bugs‚Äîjust raw MK goodness.

[h2]Gameplay & Mechanics[/h2]
MK1 plays like a love letter to the franchise while still pushing things forward. The mechanics are smooth and impactful, with a greater emphasis on kombos and flow than raw special move spam‚Äîthough both are still very much present. Combat feels balanced and satisfying, and the Kameo system adds an extra layer of strategy without overwhelming the player.

It‚Äôs accessible enough for newcomers but deep enough for veterans who want to master every move and maximize every fight. Even on harder difficulties, the AI is challenging but fair‚Äîencouraging you to actually learn your character instead of just button-mashing.

[h2]Visuals & Art Direction[/h2]
Visually, this game is stunning. The environments are dripping with atmosphere‚Äîespecially Outworld, which looks better than it ever has. Character designs strike a perfect balance between classic and modern, with fantastic reinterpretations that still feel true to their roots.

The animations are easily among the best I‚Äôve seen in 30 years of gaming. Every punch, kick, and fatality has real weight behind it, and it all contributes to making the MK universe feel more alive‚Äîand more brutal‚Äîthan ever.

[h2]A Few Gripes (But Nothing Fatal)[/h2]
Is it perfect? No game is. Some iconic characters are locked behind DLC or only appear as Kameo fighters, and I get why that might turn some fans off. The focus on combos over special moves may also not be everyone‚Äôs cup of tea. And yes, splitting the story into two parts (with the second behind a paywall) is controversial.

But personally? None of that ruined the experience for me. I don‚Äôt care about unlocking every character. I don‚Äôt care about online rankings. I care about a solid Mortal Kombat experience‚Äîand in that regard, MK1 absolutely delivers.

Also worth noting: despite widespread performance complaints, I encountered zero issues on my rig (RTX 4070 Ti Super, Ryzen 5 3600X, 32GB RAM). Everything ran buttery smooth from start to finish, even under ultra high settings, 1440p and no DLSS.

[h2]Final Thoughts[/h2]
If you‚Äôre a long-time fan from the golden arcade era‚Äîor even someone curious about what modern MK has to offer‚Äîthis is easily one of the best (if not THE best) entries in the franchise. Just get the definitive edition if you‚Äôre bothered by DLC content, and you‚Äôll have a complete, satisfying experience from start to finish.

Mortal Kombat 1 is a bloody good time, full of stylish combat, memorable moments, and unapologetic fun. It‚Äôs everything you remember loving about MK, dialed up to 11, and wrapped in the best visuals the series has ever seen.

Highly recommended. 100%.

The game is good, but the practice of microtransactions is simply pathetic, and the absence of the main characters from the franchise creates a sense of estrangement, especially with the narrative focusing on multiverses. The Kameo mechanic could be interesting if it were implemented in a way that added value, which is not the case, simply because it completely unbalances the main roster of the game.

The game has very little base content and manages to be worse in every aspect when compared to its predecessor. The problem with this game was the high expectations surrounding it. An example of this is the Krypt, which was simply cut in favor of a test with the new Invasions mode.

It‚Äôs a good game, and I won‚Äôt deny that I‚Äôve had fun with it, but I also can‚Äôt ignore the mistakes surrounding it.

Finally, in less than two years after its release, support for the game is being discontinued. I feel sad about the wasted potential with this game, and I hope that in the next installment of the franchise, NetherRealm and Ed Boon can bring MK back to its peak.

The online multi-player is has a lot of stuttering and drops frame rates.  Even if that functioned well, the quality of life features for multiplayer are non-existent.  The game almost feels like it's designed to have you spend more time in menus than actually fighting.

You have to run the benchmark every time you play online.  The worst was the king of the hill mode if you wanted to play with multiple friends.  Want to change a setting?  Leave the lobby, go back to main menu, run the benchmark again, then ask the host to exit their existing game and and create a new one to invite you in, because once they start the king of the hill mode, there's no way to add new people into the lobby.

I highly encourage you to only buy this game if it's heavily on sale.  I can't refund the game, but genuinely wish I could.  Instead I'll make it my mission to make sure that it sells as few copies as possible.  I spent more time troubleshooting this game than actually playing it.

You're going to spend 20-30min compiling shaders for this game when you launch it.  If you spend more than $10 on this game you're overpaying.

Mortal Kombat 1 is a bold reboot of the iconic fighting franchise, bringing a fresh timeline crafted by Fire God Liu Kang. The visuals are stunning, with detailed character models and brutal, cinematic Fatalities. The combat is tight and fluid, with the new Kameo fighter system adding strategic depth. The story mode is engaging and packed with fan service, though the online experience can sometimes suffer from balance issues. Overall, it‚Äôs a strong entry that respects its roots while pushing the series forward.

What sucks harder here is that this game's story was given a blank slate, starts off fairly strong and then quickly devolves into member berry multiverse slop. Every time the word "timeline" was uttered and every reference to Deadly Alliance, Deception, and Armageddon made me wish I was playing through those games instead. Also feels like there's less content here than mk11. It might just be how minimal the menus are in this compared to mk11 but there hasn't been an MK game in years not to have a krypt.


The game is still fairly fun to play and during a sale i feel its worth it.

That said, I really like how they continue adding guest characters like Homelander, Omni-Man, and Peacemaker ‚Äî that's a great touch. I'm still hoping the game gets better optimized in the future, ideally prioritizing GPU over CPU performance.

[h1]A Vivid Orgy of Violence, Banned in Three Major Countries[/h1]
It's a damn shame that the aggressive tactics of [i]Mortal Kombat 1[/i]‚Äôs publisher, Warner Bros Games, managed to steal the thunder of who should truly be held up high for this release. I am of course talking about the developer, NetherRealm Studios, and their army of imaginative artists, writers, designers, producers, voice and motion actors, programmers, audio engineers, QA testers and admin people who [i]made[/i] this thing and [i]not[/i] the people merely charged with wringing profit from it. 

Because WB Games‚Äôs greedy shenanigans‚Äîextensive microtransactions, expensive expansion‚Äîhave not only wrongly and destructively eclipsed the utterly [i]astounding[/i] presentation of this and what Unreal Engine 4 looks like in the hands of true talent but also cost us any future content less than two years after release by essentially putting a sour taste in fans' mouths that they won‚Äôt soon forget. Truly, I haven‚Äôt seen so much acrimony surrounding a [i]Mortal Kombat[/i] game than I have here. 

The drama has since passed and it‚Äôs now safe to assume [i]Mortal Kombat 1[/i] (2023) is effectively concluded, with the [i]Definitive Edition[/i] wrapping it all up in a single neat package. What remains, the imagination and creativity on display, should still not be missed by anyone with eyes and a stomach for digital violence. I implore you to get this, on sale or not, as this remains a great value for the dozens of hours of splendorous visuals and fun gameplay you get for the cost of what seems to be a single night of delivery from UberEats these days. 

There really is so much to talk about with this title, more good than bad, but seeing I don‚Äôt get paid to write reviews, brevity be damned. I am only covering the single-player experience because I don‚Äôt play multiplayer games anymore. I am mostly interested in this game‚Äôs merits artistically and gameplay-wise as it‚Äôs what I feel I‚Äôm most qualified to speak to, so if you don‚Äôt care to read such anecdotal takes, stop here.

[h2]Visuals[/h2]
Even being a long-time fan, I jumped at buying this due to its remarkably colorful presentation. Coming off the darker, dustier art direction of the excellent [i]Mortal Kombat 11[/i] (2019), [i]Mortal Kombat 1[/i] clearly dials up the saturation visually in a welcome change of scenery that is in line with the story‚Äôs reboot. Cleverly, I believe this was also done to capitalize on the latest display technology and the vibrant hues now possible on all of our newer TVs and monitors. Classic costumes return in surprisingly bright primary colors, and they work incredibly well alongside vivid projectiles. You‚Äôll see what I mean on the first whizzing fireworks from Li Mei‚Äôs fists, the pretty particle effects, or Liu Kang‚Äôs blazing forearms and glowing eyes emerging from the darkness along with every other spectacular sparkle obviously designed to take advantage of HDR displays. Owners of 4K OLEDs with deep blacks will be rewarded doubly. If you can, witness this up close on a 48‚Äù display or larger. 

(Speaking of hardware, let me take a second to emphasize that to play any [i]Mortal Kombat[/i] game without a fight stick or a lever-less controller totally misses the experience. You need to be quick with your commands to execute and get better and it quickly becomes apparent thumbs are not best for this (but you suit yourself).) 

[h2]Story[/h2]
I found [i]Mortal Kombat 1[/i]‚Äôs story mode to be a slow burn compared to the last game but it does pick up toward the end with a killer climax. It is mighty cool the Deadly Alliance is back in this and we can see their insanity in high resolutions. The character artists sure made Quan-chi look like a creepy crazed conjurer, and the young Shang Tsung is the smarmiest, most punchable face in gaming [i]ever[/i], making it a real treat to pummel to your heart‚Äôs content. 

After this and the last game's story mode, NetherRealm‚Äôs standards are sky high, to the point a live-action feature film is actually a disservice to the franchise, a downgrade in entertainment since a flick is never interactive like this is, nor will it ever be as fully developed, bloody or gory. The expansion, [i]Khaos Reigns[/i], extends on this, and I enjoyed Havik‚Äôs villainous sadism as well as the additional world building on display. The fighting in all this is on par with any kung-fu exploitation films from the 1970s, with seemingly every scene‚Äôs tension building and broiling over into an epic brawl. This is a game that never forgets it‚Äôs a fighting game, and consistently delivers no holds barred throwdowns that make UFC fights look like child‚Äôs play.

[h2]Delights[/h2]
NetherRealm rewards loyal fans, so it‚Äôs an indulgence how many Midway-era 3D characters return, like Mavado, Nitara, Ashrah, Darrius, Sareena, etc. I love that our Elder God Ed Boon and company seemingly leaves no character of this franchise behind. Test Your Might is back, which is certainly nostalgic. Animalities make an encore, and boy are they something, brutalities, too. Fatalities? Still as creative and sickening as ever, especially the classics from [i]Mortal Kombat[/i] (1992).

[h2]Disappointments[/h2]
No stage fatalities. No krypt. No cleavage or big swaying tiddies (I am particularly disappointed Sonya‚Äôs thong from her ‚Äò92 costume was altered to a full-coverage brief). I have a theory that the concealing nature of the getups coincides with Liu Kang's benevolent (read: feminist?) timeline. Apparently, his is to be a respectful male gaze-free zone, not even a gentleman boner to be had, except if you're looking to bathe in the majesty of 1980s Arnold Schwarzeneggar as Conan the Barbarian‚Äîhe seems to be the most naked one in the roster beside centaur Motaro, or Johnny Cage‚Äôs (awesome) Jean-Claude Van Damm skin from [i]Bloodsport[/i] (1988) (A missed opportunity I now realize is we should have gotten an opposing Bolo Yeung (aka "Chinese Hercules") but as a skin for Liu Kang!). Seeing depravity is seeping from every other digital orifice nowadays, I‚Äôm inclined to give NetherRealm a pass on this and I can always throw in [i]Mortal Kombat[/i] (2011). 

Now Kameo characters‚Äîyour teammate who pops in at your command to aid in battles‚Äîcould fall under disappointments in case you were like me and wanted to see Mavado or any of the others fleshed out as fully playable characters. Still, I liked the experiment of this tag-team approach as it‚Äôs novel and different.

Invasions mode is‚Ä¶fair. It provides contrast to climbing endless towers, being seasonal with maps of mesas that you run around in connected by portals, fighting wonky hybrid characters (Quan-chi‚Äôs head on Frost‚Äôs body with Li Mei‚Äôs moves was a trip) and wacky modifiers (I loved Toasty with the toasters shooting rocket bread, and Kashoo, a random, chainsaw-wielding evil squirrel that causes chaos during matches) to unlock that season‚Äôs cosmetics while you master your main and kameo characters. The whole talisman-relic-consumables-forge-shop aspect of Invasions mode I found uninteresting and even almost meaningless as I was able to win most fights without paying direct attention to what I was doing with them. 

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
As a [i]Mortal Kombat[/i] game, this is not the most we‚Äôve gotten for our money, however, it is the best Mortal Kombat has ever looked upon a bedrock of solid gameplay, and I‚Äôll buy that for a dollar. There were some mistakes made but I‚Äôm sympathetic because I‚Äôm a fanboy, and [i]Mortal Kombat[/i] is something that‚Äôs always been there almost my whole life now, like [i]DOOM[/i]. There is so much gameplay here with a big roster and a hugely high skill ceiling that I think this release will still be being played the day [i]Mortal Kombat 2[/i] rolls around. For now, I am excited to hear [i]Injustice 3[/i] is likely NetherRealm‚Äôs next project and hopefully WB Games learns from its strategies and this timeline will right itself.

While I enjoyed the game at the most there are certain issues that it has. Most importantly the amount of micro transactions and additional content that is being gate kept from you because you haven't bought extra packages is insane to me. 

¬£6.50 for a playable character 
¬£4 for a cameo character that doesn't do all that much is ridiculous.
¬£40 Khaos Reigns DLC which is almost the full price of the base game.

The story is pretty decent and funny at times with brilliant voice overs. As always with other Mortal Kombat / Injustice games there are characters that are just better or easier to use than others which might be a concern to some people. The cameo system is not that good, rather great for the devs though as it gives them more sources of income. A rather fast game for completionists as most achievements are rather straight forward and moderate in difficulty. All things aside I did enjoy my experience with Mortal Kombat 1. If you are considering getting a taste of all the Mortal Kombat 1 content I would suggest getting it on sale. 

Prices on sale: Base game = ¬£15 and Definitive Edition = ¬£22

Despite the reputation, Mortal Kombat 1 delivers where it matters.
The game has taken a lot of heat, especially regarding its DLC story ‚Äî and much of that criticism is deserved. However, the core experience is genuinely impressive. The mechanics are arguably the best the series has ever had. There‚Äôs real room for growth, and even months after release, online activity is still strong, with quick matchmaking and active players.
I went in highly skeptical, expecting disappointment ‚Äî but I was wrong. The base game is absolutely worth playing.

As long as Warner Bros is involved, Mortal Kombat will never be what it was in the past. I was always the MK guy instead of Street Fighter...but you can easily see how Street Fighter is still rocking and pleasing fans, and MK just became a paid cash grab gacha.

Shame on you Ed Boon, for working with Warner Bros up to date and for ruining the wonderful job you did in the 90s.

I can understand, even now expect characters to be DLC in fighting games. It's the sad reality of gaming now... but why would you make a system where you can't play half the roster?!? They have a system in place that has the characters appear when you use a special, which means they made the sprites for the characters. Yet you can't play as them or those version of them. What a waste! 
This is it, the last Mortal Kombat game I'll buy. I'll just watch gameplay for the storyline if I get curious. I even got the DLC thinking I'll get a wide variety of characters to go through. There's TWENTY ONE Kameo fighters aka characters/skins you can't play as... the base game has 22 playable characters. Even moreso, you FIGHT AGAINST multiple Kameo fighters, which means they have entire move sets. You can purchase 13 DLC characters at the time of this review. None of them are the Kameo fighters (Cyrax and Sektor are not the same as the Kameo ones). Go back to better games like Ultimate MK Trilogy to get a decent roster. Even Deception wasn't disappointing like this even though the roster was only 26 characters. I wasn't even that upset with MK11 tbh... I guess the gameplay was enough to carry it.
I really think the biggest disappointment is seeing characters you've missed, then you can't even use them! Way to tease us with Stryker. I'm also guessing Nightwolf didn't sell well since he doesn't exist when he was in the last game as DLC. 
I'm done rambling... if you want a storyline like the MK11 campaign and nothing else, including no Krypt, go ahead and disappoint yourself with this cash grab.

Writing this review since recently they announced Mortal Kombat 1 [url=https://x.com/MortalKombat/status/1926020816879206810] no longer getting content updates [/url] and will only be about balancing and fixing bugs. I'll be focusing on mostly offline but there will be mentions of online.

Mortal Kombat 1 despite being enjoyable and fun experience lacks of replayability and worse amount of features than previous game. I'll be going from story first.

[h3] Story: [/h3]
In NRS games, Mortal Kombat had arlight story at best, really bad at worst (looking at you MK 11). Fortunatly MK 1 in my opinion was strongest they have written. I really do like characters that the new era and was enganged on what was happening. I even liked text feature when you lose a fight in a story! I think it was nice small addition to it!

Although MK 1 has strong story writing it unfortently falls down when you reaching end of Act 3. It uses multiverse where the fight against Shang Tsung and Liu Kang in previous game was so strong that it caused to have many universes on 'What If'. Personally after Act 3, i was not fan of where it was going but at least the final chapter of MK 1 was a nice touch of ability to play any character you liked.

Unfortently Khaos Reign expansion story was really terrible. It didn't really added much other than making main villain of Khaos Reign story a wasted potential and nothing burger. I would so far to say that it could be one of the weakest they have written so far.

I mostly liked characters in the game but i find their design to be just plain fine. I didn't liked them, didn't hate them. Some notable things are Reptile which in my opinion has the best design they ever had so far. I love idea that he can shapeshift into human and his own form, and Megan Fox infamous acting skills as Nitara.

[h3] Gameplay: [/h3]
The gameplay for Mortal Kombat 1 is in my opinion big improvement over MK 11. The meters are back! Allowing you to do extend combos with at least 3 bars at max. Breakers also make a return but instead uses 3 bars to break rather than 2 and requiring you to have Kameo avalaible. Fatal Blows also return. Now instead of activating attack immiediently it will activate animation prep-up and succesfully landing it will make Kameo then Main Fighter attack with x-ray pop up to show damage they've done. Imo it's much bigger improvement as previous one gave at time frustrating moments.

Kameos are new unique feature in MK 1. They are fun addition to the game despite not making it to main roster but giving them a chance to appear. They have their own movesets that can help your main fighter, brutalities and fatalities. While i do think they are fun, i doubt that people will want them back in the next installment.

Fatalities, Brutalities make an obvious return to the series and they did a pretty good joob on it. Khaos Reign introduced Animality (For free) which is also a nice way to finish your opponents with it.

[h3] Offline Modes: [/h3]
If you reached this review, i had mostly positive things to say. However after this, there will be many criticism pointed out to the modes, replayability and some of nitpicks and tactics that they have used that is alarming.

Firstly "offline" mode. Unfortently this game still suffers of requiring an internet connection. Meaning if you attempt to play offline without internet. You will get less amount of it.

Invansion was at launch that contained an leveling system and advancing through until you meet a certain character boss themed and defeat them. As much promises it shows, it does nothing much. Invasion gets repetitve quite fast as when you'll be advancing you through more in easy opponents due to AI just not being smart. I didn't find myself finishing some seasons due to skins of characters that i was not interested in playing. There is also a chance to get Ambush, which in my opinion is a waste of time and just there to annoy you more. Invasions also had a towers on there but there wasn't much to do in there since modifiers wasn't that much entertaining.

Tower of Time was reintroduced back in Khaos Reigns, while welcoming addition, it has gotten a downgrade as there is 9 towers total (12 when there is certain events happening like new character release). It still suffers the same issue as the towers are not replayable enough. Challenges were added tower of time to give a point boost and reward (including free premium currency) which is pretty good. The points are now relied on to be on top x%. Which is fine.

Towers are there also, giving you three length towers, two survival modes. As far as i know this is the only mode that you can play without worrying about internet connection (Story Mode should be also fine).

[h3] Online Mode: [/h3]
Online Mode is there. However like the offline it got downgrades but some upgrades. You are no longer able to join or see the rooms which is really shame as i think it was a fun feature. It only contains now Kasual, Ranked and King of The Hill. Ranked uses the same as MK 11, where you reach a certain rank to get rewards and after season ends, everyone goes back to first rank. There is an upgrade though it as you no longer allowed to decide what character you want to choose, locking in with a character + kameo and losing a match only allows you to change Kameos. Previously it required you to play FT3 matches rather than FT2 matches but that changed back FT2 which is better. You can instantly gain rewards upon reaching a rank which is a nice upgrade. Kasaul and KotH is not much to say about it.

[h3] Other, Nitpicks and Scummy Tactics: [/h3]

Essentialy this is the final category that i've decided to make it whole to one.

First things first, the release and Kombat Pack. I find it unacceptable the fact that Pre-Order Character and Kombat Pack contains characters that are in story mode. It screams to me that the game was unfinished and decided to roll out as a buyable dlc character. You can even play as Shang Tsung in the story mode but he is locked as DLC Pre-order Character.

There is no custom slot that allows you to choose what character skin and gear would you want to have. I find it unfortunate that despite the time of it, we'll never get that feature and will have to rely on favorites.

Monetization on the game is bad imo. The skins that you receive for free are lacking and most of them are recolors of the skin. At previous time, the prices for premium skins were bad to the point they had to tone it down. Even they made paid fatalities that got backlash to the point they had to compensate players who bought them with entire bundle of it.

The customazation is arlight, i do feel there is some upgrades and downgrades to it. I do feel there is less ability to customize your character unlike MK 11 but the skins are really nice despite of that. You can also do end of the round animations of your choosing, which is also nice.

Personal nit-pick but i am getting tired of Kombat Pack having 50% of guest characters. While i do find some guests welcoming (Ghostface, T-1000, Omni-Man, Homelander) it just decreases chance of original characters making return which is really shame because it would be sick if we got Tremor or Skarlet as main fighter.

[h3] Final Words: [/h3]

Thank you if you read this review through the end of it! Personally i enjoyed Mortal Kombat 1 with amount of hours i have but unfortently with scummy tactics, less replayability and end of the content updates, i find it not reccomending this game with the full price is asking for (especially with Defenitive Edition). I am sure there will be a sale that will make the game worth your money and time spend on this game.

I‚Äôm experiencing severe lag. I keep getting matched with players who have around 40 benchmark and 260 ms ping. There are frequent frame drops, and sometimes it‚Äôs impossible to connect combos properly. I honestly regret spending 196 hours on this game.
Mortal Kombat, Every release is absolute gold. It maybe ruff at first but it grows on you as long as Mileena is in it.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs in our blood.‚Äù That tagline couldn‚Äôt be more accurate. Mortal Kombat 1, the latest entry in NetherRealm Studios‚Äô long-running fighting game franchise, isn‚Äôt just another sequel‚Äîit‚Äôs a complete timeline reboot. Again. But this time, it feels deliberate, cohesive, and refreshingly bold.

Liu Kang is now a Fire God with the powers of creation, and he‚Äôs reshaped the universe into a more peaceful reality‚Äîor so he thought. What follows is a vicious, dimension-shattering tournament with familiar faces, unfamiliar alliances, and the same satisfying thwack of a perfectly landed uppercut.

Combat in Mortal Kombat 1 is fast, fluid, and gloriously gory. The core gameplay feels tighter than ever, retaining the bone-crunching satisfaction of previous entries while introducing the Kameo Fighter system‚Äîa bold new tag-in mechanic that allows you to summon legacy characters mid-fight to extend combos, interrupt enemies, or save your skin.

It‚Äôs not just a gimmick. Kameo Fighters add real tactical depth. Choosing the right partner complements your main fighter and opens new combo trees and pressure tactics. It rewards experimentation without overwhelming newer players.

Returning fighters like Scorpion, Sub-Zero, and Kitana feel reimagined with deeper lore and rebalanced abilities. Every punch lands with purpose, and the Fatal Blows and Fatalities are as gruesomely creative as ever‚Äîif not even more grotesque in their detail.

Mortal Kombat‚Äôs cinematic story modes have always been guilty pleasures, but MK1 raises the bar. The narrative blends surprisingly heartfelt character arcs with absurd twists and multiversal chaos.

Liu Kang‚Äôs attempt at peace unravels as alliances fracture, and alternate versions of classic characters emerge. The script is campy but clever, and the new dynamics‚Äîlike Mileena and Kitana‚Äôs sibling bond or a noble version of Shang Tsung‚Äîadd emotional weight amidst the flying limbs and exploding skulls.

It‚Äôs a popcorn thrill ride with more lore than you‚Äôd expect from a game that includes finishing moves where your opponent gets impaled by a flying ice dragon.

Mortal Kombat 1 looks stunning. Every character model is highly detailed, arenas are lush with atmosphere (from neon-soaked city streets to lava-drenched arenas), and the gore‚Äîwell, it‚Äôs beautiful in its own twisted way. Blood physics have never been this... artistic?

The sound design deserves special mention. Punches thud with sickening satisfaction, and every Fatality is accompanied by squelches and crunches that make you wince in the best way. The voice acting? Surprisingly solid‚Äîthough still campy, as it should be.

Online play is mostly smooth, thanks to robust netcode, but the progression system and live-service elements may not sit well with all players. Daily challenges, character unlocks, and cosmetics are sometimes locked behind grinds or microtransactions, which slightly dampens the package.

Invasions mode (the new single-player RPG-lite mode) is a clever twist, offering varied challenges, buffs, and loot across themed maps. It adds a layer of long-term replayability beyond ranked matches.

While the Kameo system adds innovation, it can be jarring for newcomers trying to keep track of double the threats on-screen. The tutorial does a decent job, but some deeper mechanics remain unexplained.

Also, not all characters feel equally balanced‚Äîearly metas have shown a few clear frontrunners‚Äîand the roster, while iconic, feels a bit safe compared to past entries. No wild newcomers or real oddballs yet.

Mortal Kombat 1 is a bold reboot that respects its bloody lineage while embracing change. It‚Äôs gorgeous, punishing, and unexpectedly emotional in its storytelling. While the live-service elements and balance quirks hold it back from flawless victory, it remains one of the most complete and compelling fighters of this generation.

Best Served With: A controller in one hand, a bucket of popcorn in the other, and a stomach strong enough for spine-ripping Fatalities.

A Brutal Rebirth with a Few Bruises

[h3] I wish there was an option to leave a solely informational review, but since there isn't, I'll have to leave a negative one because we're pretty much at the end of the cycle of significant updates despite Ed Boon's promised years of support. I have to say, though. I enjoyed my stay, despite the numerous shortcomings. [/h3]

What MK1 does well:
[list]
[*] Soundtracks
[*] Visuals [/list]

What it doesn't:
[list]
[*] Online component (Lack of online lobbies, the game being inaccessible in regions like Africa)
[*] Character customization (Downgrade from Injustice 2, and MK11.)
[*] Monetization (Mostly in regards to Kombat Pack 2 and 1)
[*] Failing to live up to Ed Boon's promises of years of continued support. [/list]

What MK1 improved upon after its release:
[list]
[*] Fixing the desynchronization issues (overdue fix) and adding crossplay after a few months.
[*] Improving the single player experience, via adding the Towers of Time which give free dragon krystals weekly.
[*] Improving the game balance, and the kameo system, fixing issues like player one advantage, combo infinites, etc. [/list]

With MK1's DLC's coming to an end, here is my complete review of the game. 

Firstly, I would recommend this game on a discount, even while I'm disapointed overall as a fan of the series, I've still had a lot of fun on the game itself and the gameplay can be very fun and has a lot of the great traditional Mortal Kombat tropes which I love about the series. Some great new character designs that add something extra to some less refined characters, and some very cool actual kombat styles which make for fun gameplay to both play and watch. 

I will however go into the many issues this game has, and why the community turned sour on MK1.

- [b] There is no Krypt [/b]: I noticed this when I first loaded up the game, the unlockables area "The Krypt" which has been a recurring element of the MK games since Deadly Alliance in 2002, and had it's biggest showcase in the previous game (MK11) has been reduced to "The Shine" this was previously one small part of what was the Krypt in MK11, so having that direct comparison was a red flag. There isn't really any charm in the shrine, it's a chore to put your coins in and get the unshockable, originally you also had to open each shrine item one by one until they did fix this and allow 10 at a time. Although it's very surprising they even released it in a one item per opening format. 

- [b] Kameos [/b]: MK1 introduced the new "Kameo" system as it's big gameplay shift, and this has some positives, it can lead to some very creative gameplay and has made space for even more characters from the massive universe of MK to make appearences.

However, unfortunately, the gameplay experience for this isn't intuitive, or fun for many people. In higher level play, you'll also be seeing the same strategy with using the most overpowered kameo and pairing in general. While there isn't really an issue with the mode itself, the issue is that they introduced this as the only option of play. There is no single kombat mode, the mode that's existed in every single MK game, we are restricted to playing kameos all the time. It's incredibly simple to remove an assist option from gameplay (the kameos aren't even on screen until you activate them) there isn't much of an excuse here that even with so much community push back, there was never a single kombat mode provided.

- [b] The story [/b]: (Mild spoilers for the general direction of the story ahead)
The story itself is actually okay, at least at first. We get a reset of the timeline again, similar to MK9, and some of the characters are very entertaining, and you get some great chemistry between people also, like Cage and Kenshi. I also enjoyed the depiction of Reptile here, they leaned way too heavy into "lizard" reptile and they manged to meet in the middle here, giving us the human ninja look which is what most people were asking for. 

There are issues with this however. (MK11 spoilers) [spoiler] At the end of MK11, we are given a scene where Liu Kang greets another timelines Kung Lao, this implies the he might be there to guide them into being "The Great Kung Lao". [/spoiler] The Great Kung Lao story is one that's very important to the overall lore of MK, a lot of the main story comes to be based on this history, however we have no actually seen this story directly within an MK game, just those talking about it. So naturally a lot of players were excited about MK12/MK1 giving us this tale finally.

However, they went another direction and Kung Lao doesn't really get that treatment, they're a second player to Raiden, in a role swap with Liu Kang from previous games. The role swap if fine, but it is a repeat of the same story, when we had The Great Kung Lao story right in front of us, ready to be told, Kung Lao is always a great character, and he still is here, but he doesn't get to shine as much as you'd want.

[b] Multiverse: [/b] The multiverse was another key part of the MK11 story, and honestly when the multiverse trope gets added to a story, it's incredibly rare it gets better, no, it's usually gets worse. I think MK11 did a fine job with it overall and with it's ending it was a unique way to lead into another reset, I actually didn't mind it in MK11. 

In MK1 however, we just got a new reset and as you go further in, the multiverse becomes more and more prominent, and other than some funny elements of characters being mixed up into hybrids from other timelines (I enjoyed this) the way that it's such a prominent part of the story, it takes away a lot of the stakes and the actual connection you have with the characters when you're seeing there are tons of the same one.

Further to this though, the MK1 universe is MASSIVE, like I said earlier. You really do not need a multiverse, we already have tons of realms that remain included! One of the coolest parts of the MK story which MK Deception made a great point of was this hierarchy of power with The Elder Gods and The One Being, where it connects all the realms to something under the surface trying to regain power and take over once more. 

We get the reintroduction of Havik, a fan favourite from the Chaos realm. We get NOTHING about the order realm, no Hotaru, where are you gonna have Chaos realm without the Order realm? It just seems like with this focus on the multiverse, they missed what is right in front of them, they have this massive world to craft a great story from, and it's pretty easy to actually put it together when the pieces are already ready to go! I very much hope in MK2 we are over the timelines and back to how MK stories should be.

Finally, I need to address the thing which soured MK fans the most.

[b] WB Microtransactions: [/b] The MK fanbase is very vocal and loyal to the series, and due to this loyalty many purchased the special editions with hefty price tags, thankfully I avoided this as I didn't trust the value of it. One of the perks of buying the special editions was more Dragon Krystals, which are the premium currency in the game. Now, as it turns out, the amount you get and what you can do with them is pretty damn poor. I mean, VERY poor. You can buy perhaps one skin and one other cheaper item. 

The game that you paid full price for, while providing many other skins through gameplay (bare minimum) is locking all of the retro skins, the ones that are the most desireable from the long term fans of the series, behind an additional paywall! What a disgusting way to treat your long-term fans, don't allow them to earn the skins, make them pay even more money! Don't worry though, you can earn the 1000 dragon crystals you need to purchase one single skin. You just need to grind the game, oh but also, they capped the OVERALL amount you can earn if you 100% completed every single character and Kameo (which would obviously take a very long time) You could earn 5700 krystals TOTAL if you did absolutely everything, and even just months into the game if you wanted to grab a few announcer voice changes, and a couple of retro skins with a seasonal fatality, that would actually be impossible to obtain without paying more!

The way WB treated this IP is disgusting, it's absolutely no wonder why people immediately felt like they were being ripped off, i'ts because they were! Now you need to understand it was only months into the games release where you couldn't earn enough currency to buy the retro skins, they kept introducing more and more of these retro skins, you had no chance to earn them through playing your full priced game, they wanted more money. Like this is some free mobile game? Very confusing and the greed is as subtle as a WB rep showing up to your door and asking for you wallet directly. 

In closing I since hope WB are nowhere near this series by the time of the next release. Both Mortal Kombat and it's loyal fanbase deserves so much more than this.

I tried to like this, I really did but it was victim to a deadly combination of factors.
First, it released at the tail end of the multiverse trend, it was getting stale and derivative. There were hints of predeterminism that could've been an interesting conflict for Liu Kang, but thebig twist ruined the chance for something new by clinging to the familiar.
The Kameo system felt half baked, we could've had a bigger roster with a robust tag mechanic (like they had in MK9) but instead we had half a roster and a assist system worse than what they had in MK11.
The guest characters, while well made was dripping with WB interference, who's influence extended to the customization system, which was also much more limited than MK11, and it wasn't even a case of quality over quantity.
This is a bad fighting game.

[b]TL;DR: Reject modernity, return to MKX[/b]

The biggest criticism that many people seem to have about this game is the [b]exuberant amount of money[/b] that needs to be shilled out in order to have access to all the characters, and I have nothing new to add to the conversation in that regard, other than simply state that [b]this is the first Mortal Kombat game I've owned without owning all of the characters[/b].

In terms of the actual game: the gameplay is very fresh for Mortal Kombat, the [b]kameos[/b] add a brand new level of depth to every match played, and the [b]air-combos[/b] are a very unique addition and an interesting way to develop on the pre-determined combo-based fighting that Mortal Kombat is known for. However all these innovations result in MK1 straying from the established Mortal Kombat formula, making it arguably a worse Mortal Kombat game than its predecessor MK11.

The graphics, much like all Mortal Kombat games, are very good in terms of visual quality. However they're starting to piss me off with the way they completely change how the people look with every single game. Liu Kang, the head honcho himself, looks nothing like he did in MK11. And this has been an issue for a while, but I think MK1 does it particularly egregiously. This is almost certainly on purpose, since the game is a "reboot of the universe", but that remains a stupid excuse to completely change how almost every character looks, to the point of unrecognisability for many of them if it wasn't for the power-rangers-esque color coding.

The character roster might be the strongest aspect that MK1 has over its predecessors. Every member seems [b]hand-picked to maximise fan-appreciation[/b]. All the classics are obviously present (Scorpion, Sub-Zero, Johnny Cage, you know the ones...), however some characters which were staples of the franchise have been removed or demoted to Kameo status (such as Jax, Sonya, Kano...) in order to make room for fan-favorites which were denied the spotlight for a long time (such as Havik, Ashrah, Reiko...).
As per usual, the [b]DLC roster is also very strong[/b], mostly composed of very fun and interesting characters, with a few inevitable misses thrown in there probably just because some people in the development team really wanted them in particular (2 Terminators back-to-back? Really??)

Overall Mortal Kombat 1 is a very interesting entry for the Mortal Kombat franchise, bringing many new ideas to the table and standing out as an instalment to really impact the franchise as a whole. However this is also why [b]it is much harder to recommend Mortal Kombat 1 over Mortal Kombat 11[/b].
The biggest factor in MK1 being a better choice than MK11 is the much more active multiplayer that comes with the advent of being the latest instalment of a series. However, for a strictly singleplayer/local gamer, MK11 might be the better choice, given that its Singleplayer mode (Towers of Time) is strictly better than the abomination that is MK1's Invasions.
At the end of the day, they are both equally good options for a Mortal Kombat game (which says a lot about how good MK11 really was that it still holds up to this day), and you should probably decide which one you want based on which roster interests you more.
It's just not good enough.

Story wise this game is bad. The games story seems interesting at first but then it gets ruined by timeline merges and cliches. Game was made to share continuity with older MK games so instead of being the reboot that remedied all the convolution associated with the Mortal Kombat franchise it became apart of that convolution. The gameplay is better than the story but its gameplay is still inferior compared to other fighting games on the market.

Don't get the game. Just watch all the cutscenes or see someone else play the game if you care about story. There are better fighting games to invest time in that came out at a similar time like Street Fighter 6 or Tekken 8 and there are still better fighting games to play with ongoing support. I don't believe the game is fixable but if you ask me what I wanted from the next MK game it would be to stay away from timeline and reality warping shenanigans, make the story more grounded, not make outworld (especially and specifically outworld) or netherrealm the main antagonist again, bring back tag team mode and ring out stages, stop doing sh*tty video game crossovers, make better post game/side game content and stop catering to normies.

Mortal Kombat 1 is hands-down one of the most entertaining entries in the franchise. I can say this remake absolutely delivers.

Yes, the characters can be a bit pricey, but honestly, the overall content makes up for it. From the intense single-player experience to the wide range of online modes, there‚Äôs enough here to keep any MK lover hooked.

What really blew me away was the character design‚Äîespecially Homelander and Omni-Man. Their movements, dialog, and unique fighting styles are just incredible. These aren‚Äôt just guest characters thrown in for hype‚Äîthey feel like fully fleshed-out additions with real weight and personality. The attention to detail in their animations and voice lines is next-level.

This isn‚Äôt just a button-mashing fighter. Every character feels distinct, with a clear fighting style and purpose. And despite the variety, the game manages to stay surprisingly well-balanced.

Finally, the realism in the combat animations and movement is on another level. Whether you're pulling off fatalities or dodging a perfectly timed counter, everything feels smooth and impactful.

If you're on the fence‚Äîit's definitely worth it.

Juggle simulator.

Mortal Kombat 1 has many flaws, some of them more severe then others. 

The fighter roster is a joke, some of the most iconic names in the mortal kombat franchise are either missing completely or only available as "assist charakters".
The strange buddy fighting system is a joke and completely useless.

But heres my main issue with MK1. The whole gameplay is just to throw your opponent in the air and hit him, while he is kind of floating in front of you as much as possible. Thats endgame. You dont have to learn to duck or dodge or counter or anything. If you want to win, you just memorize the juggle supercombos that keep your opponent in the air as long as possible. The game actually has its own training mode for that, choose a charakter, and the game tells you what the 6 best juggle combos are, thats it. now every one of those supercombos has the potential to roughly take 40% of your opponents health away. So MK1 is either doing juggle supercombos yourself and hitting your opponent while hes in the air for 40 seconds or watching yourself get hit while in the air for 40 seconds. Thats the game. You dont want to do the juggle combo bullshit? You are going to lose. No other playstyle is even remotely able to compete with the juggle combo bs. 
This has another negative side effect. People who use controllers with programmable buttons are freaking everywhere in the pvp section. You can easily tell. Some of the Controller brands even have the presets for MK1 charakters for download on their website....

On a sale, sure, I'd recommend it. For $30 UDS you get everything but two characters. Come on guys, you knew you were not going to get everything. It's the 2020's now.

Honestly, I'd almost recommend it at full price, but it is expensive if you want the full package with all the bells and whistles, and besides that, it does have issues. First and foremost is the fact there is time travel and multiverse elements in the story. This is where things go to die, it's never good, nor original. In fact, I'd argue it's cliche as hell, and very very lazy. I'm not even a huge story buff, but I don't enjoy these kinds of things, it just mucks things up for no good reason what so ever.

I'm also not a huge fan of it's Kameo system. It's not the worst thing ever, and I'm still having a blast playing it, but I'd much rather of had a flat out expanded character move set then a tag mechanic, but that's personal preference. I can say that there needed to be more of them. There more than what I'd call a handful sure, but some just seem so much better than others, and at the end of the day, it still really does feel like slim pickings with them.

I guess my biggest gripe, is the reptilian racism. I mean, Reptile has always been my main pick out of the roster, and I'm so happy he's back, but when you test your might and succeed, there is no clapping for him like the other characters. Not even the chirp of a cricket. Okay, this was a joke, but it is strange.

My real biggest complaint is of course the microtransactions. You just never want to see it. Thankfully it's not the worst here, but IT IS here, so I got to say a big resounding BOOOOOOO! A close second to that is the Animalities, were they drunk when they did these lol? I haven't even seen them all yet and I'm just like ... wait ... what? His name is Reptile right? There are lots of Reptiles on Earth ... right? So why did he just turn into a plant? Using Quan Chi, I'm like Oh, this has got to be an Octopus right, will all that Lovecraftian tenticles ... right? Nah, it was a T-Rex ... because, I don't know, maybe because Jurassic Park was cool once? By the way Takeda is an Octopus, you know, the guy who's element aligns with Fire? I mean they all must make sense in a way I'm just not getting. Like Smoke, a super stealth based Ninja turning into a rampaging Gorilla. Alright I got to stop, I could do this for all the one's I've seen save Scorpion. Thank God they didn't mess that one up, if he had turned into a f*ckin butterfly I wouldn't have been surprised by now, but seriously disappointed.

Lastly, the lack of modes. There isn't a whole lot to do apart from story, online, matches, and various arcade towers that seem more lifeless than they were in MK11. It feels rather stripped down without a proper Krypt or some other distraction mode that previous titles used to throw in there. 

All that aside. I really dig this game. Like the character designs, graphics are beautiful, animations are as great as they've ever been, move sets are great, finishers are fantastic, sound is amazing, music is killer, guest characters are enjoyable additions, voice actors did a great job. I mean, it's a good game, it's a beautiful game, but yes, given the flaws, I'd snag it on that juicy sale and enjoy it at a fair price.

I really enjoy playing Mortal Kombat 1. I like the assist characters. I enjoy the arcade mode and character endings. While I find the easiest mode challenging, I don't find it impossible. The variety of characters is nice as well.

I picked up the "full" version for under $40. I play single player arcade. I don't do online multiplayer.

I'm downvoting it as I don't believe most people would enjoy it for the reasons I enjoy playing the game.

There are better fighting games to play online. 

But save King of Fighter XV and Tekken 8, I enjoy this game and it's worth the money I spent buying it.

I just prefer to be honest that as it is most fighting game fans can get better fighting games than this.

A superior Mortal Kombat game.
Now seems like the right time to play it or buy it (on sale for 16‚Ç¨ + DLC 20‚Ç¨).

Because of the ending in Part 11, I was very skeptical about whether it would continue to entertain me.
I'm here for the fights, but the story has been THE central element for me ever since they started building the story cinematically in MK9.

And the story overwhelmed me.
I dare say it's the best story I've ever experienced in a fighting game.
Back in MK9, I was thrilled with the reboot after Armageddon 
and never thought it would happen again after the story chaos in 10 & 11.

The game uses elements ranging from MK 4 to MK 11.
I thought it was a very good decision by the developers to relive some of the dramatic twists and see the origin stories of well-known characters retold cinematically.
It's as if they decided 15 years ago to move towards this very game with this very story.

I played through the main story and the DLC story in one go.
The rest also seems very well-rounded.
The combat system is familiar and works well.
The invasions and towers will certainly keep me entertained for a while.

For me it was a good decision to buy it,
because I've been playing MK since part 1, but only on a casual level. And that's enough for me to rate it as good.

I understand the negative criticisms and 100% agree with peoples disappointment due to the business practices, but in terms of pure game-play, story, character design, and feel, MK1 is a great fighting game, and a solid iteration in the franchise. complaints about balance really make no sense when one considers a Baraka main just 2-0'd sonic fox.

The game is lagging constantly, even offline. I have good hardware, good connection etc. It's most definitly the game. After optimizing my gpu settings it's runs a bit better, but this is not acceptable for a finished product.

Not refunding it yet, will try to get it working.

Update: I changed my settings in Nvidia controll centre.

Go to manage 3D settngs -> programm settngs
-> MK1 (or add MK1)
Then:
Anti Aliassing transparancy to 8x
Power management to maximum performance
Triple buffering: On

This fixed my game completely. Now the game is very good and I really enjoy it. If you know your way around a PC, this game is a amazing fighting game. Can recommend.

Mortal Kombat 1 delivers stunning graphics and a roster of easy-to-pull-off moves that make it visually impressive and accessible for both newcomers and veterans. The game‚Äôs visual design is a significant step forward, with detailed character models, fluid animations, and atmospheric stages that truly bring the fight to life. The intuitive controls and straightforward mechanics allow players to execute signature moves with ease, making matches exciting and engaging.

However, despite these positives, the game feels like it falls short in content. Even with all the available DLC, the overall variety of modes, stages, and characters remains limited, leaving players wanting more after just a few hours of play. The lack of substantial single-player content and meaningful replay value diminishes its longevity, making the experience feel somewhat hollow.

Moreover, the pricing feels inflated considering the sparse content, leading to a sense of overpricing. Fans expecting a comprehensive package might find themselves disappointed, as the game‚Äôs core offering doesn‚Äôt justify its premium price point. As a result, Mortal Kombat 1 ends up feeling like a visually impressive but somewhat shallow experience‚Äîone step forward in graphics and accessibility, but two steps back in content and value.

In summary: Mortal Kombat 1 impresses visually and offers accessible gameplay, but its limited content and high price point overshadow these strengths, making it feel somewhat underwhelming and overpriced.

I was very invested in the early story, where it was a smaller scale, no fatalities, a simpler time for Mortal Kombat. Farmers and failures. And I was hoping that what would happen is we would see how we went from this peaceful time to the first actual Mortal Kombat. Like, I wanted it to be shocking that someone was killed, and I wanted to see an escalation, with both politics and violence until the characters were trapped an inescapable death tournament. 

Instead, we started off with a great story, then allllll the characters got on the crazy bus, and drove it off a cliff of... nostalgia? Or something? I was willing to accept Liu Kang and Raiden basically just changing roles, even tho it was boring. Because it also came with Baraka being a tragic good guy and a bunch of other good stuff! But I just started laughing after we just retreaded tired, old, and frankly bad storylines that didn't work in the 2000s. 

If you also start laughing at this, then you'll probably continue laughing as the story goes full loony tunes at the end and there's a character called John Kahner (Terminator) that is a mash up of Johnny Cage and Shao Kahn. Like, if you get to this point, just stop the game, restart at the beginning where Raiden is a simple farmer and realize they spent like 15 minutes of CGI time on Johnny Cage's fake movie as a gag, and ZERO TIME explaining why John Kahner even exists, or why you are back at the pyramid other than, "I guess by now you realize we are just doing the 2000s game's storylines again, so Armageddon had to show up". It's like the game director and story writer changed half way through. 

Sad. Waste of an opportunity to be quaint and small stakes again like the original Mortal Kombat. And for what, you pushed the storyline all the way back to the end of MK7 (MK8 doesn't exist), and MK9 was a COMPLETE REBOOT. So, you JUST rebooted in 11, and now in "12", we are right back to reboot AGAIN? 

Ok, so I mostly play MK for the single player. But let's talk gameplay. Basically, I didn't like it. I don't like calling in someone on the sidelines to help, I don't like the combo system as much as other games, I don't like how everyone is the same power level all the time, I don't like how I can't do fatalities in the story mode. It was a little bit of fun, but that's it. I keep really hoping for a combo system like MK3, which this KINDA has, but it didn't feel as good.

From Shaolin Monks to this? Never in my life did I think Liu Kang would become some bootleg God of Earthrealm. Childhood memories shattered. Shaolin Monks was pure gold ‚Äî I spent hours trying to unlock playable Scorpion without googling anything, because Googling for cheats always felt pathetic to me. I actually respected the grind back then.

But now? This new game straight-up butchered the entire Mortal Kombat story.

Kuai Liang is Scorpion? Are you kidding me?  Smoke recruiting a young Scorpion? What the hell is even going on? Either that's not Hanzo Hasashi, or Liu Kang destroyed the whole timeline just to play god.

Maybe, just maybe, this is an alternate timeline and the real MK universe still exists somewhere ‚Äî but as of now, it feels like they spat on the original story.

And don‚Äôt even think for one second I‚Äôll sugarcoat this just because the graphics and gameplay are good. Yeah, it looks pretty. Yeah, it plays well. But no amount of ray tracing is going to fix the fact they butchered everyone‚Äôs soul just to make space for new characters nobody asked for.

I give Mortal Kombat 1 a 7/10. The graphics are great, and the character lineup is one of my favourites in the MK series. The gameplay is decent, but there are some issues. My biggest issues with MK1 are the microtransactions, the lack of singleplayer content, the customisation system, and Kameos. The base game costs $70 CAD, but if you want to play as all of the (currently available) characters, you need to pay over $120! The Khaos Reigns bundle includes every DLC fighter except for Shang Tsung for some reason, who you have to buy for an additional $10. I don't blame the developers for this, I blame WB Games. The singleplayer content is also pretty underwhelming. After story mode, the only thing you can play by yourself is Invasions, or the towers of time. There's no Krypt, which was one of my favourite parts of MK11. The character customisation options are pitiful compared to MK11, which I think had the best customisation system in the series. The colour variations between skins are pointless, and you get one gear piece. You also can't make custom presets. I think that the Kameo system adds too much complexity to the gameplay, and should not be included in the next MK game. Many players like the Kameos, but I think they make the game harder for beginners to get into. Long story short, I would only buy this game when it's 50% off (or more).

In all honesty, i thought i would get bored of the game. Bought it so i could practice and beat my friends ass. Now i play it everyday without fail.

However, my laptop barely meets reccomended requirements (2gb less dedicated video ram), and so my gpu gets up to 80* C without fail everytime, which i can deal with, if my benchmark wasnt 45 fps, and an inconsistant 45 at that. constant frame drops. I think the game shouldnt require shaders, as i think thats what makes it unstable for lower end pcs. Not to mention the delay to start. Matches and loading screens take a while. Very annoying! It is honestly a better idea to buy this on your available console, I would even dare to say buy it on switch, and ive played it on switch, the crashing is more bare-able than the lag and fps drop.

Overall, fun game, but make sure you have good pc cooling and EXCEED the reccomended hardware

All things considered, 7/10, fun game, could be more computer friendly, and more optimized.

Mortal Kombat 1 is a phenomenal reboot of the legendary franchise, delivering the perfect blend of nostalgia and modern innovation. The game pays homage to its roots while introducing fresh mechanics and storytelling that feel both exciting and groundbreaking.

The revamped story mode is truly cinematic, with jaw-dropping visuals and an engaging narrative that reimagines the iconic characters in a new light. The fluid combat system, combined with the stunning environmental details, makes every fight an adrenaline-packed experience. And, of course, the Fatalities are as satisfyingly brutal as ever, keeping the series' signature flair alive.


What truly stands out is how accessible the game is to newcomers while still offering enough depth to challenge seasoned players. Whether you‚Äôre diving into the single-player mode or battling it out online, Mortal Kombat 1 delivers countless hours of intense fun and unforgettable moments. It's a must-play for fans of the franchise and fighting games alike!

MK1 is a beautiful game in terms of graphics and character design, but it is clear what direction they aim to take with future installments to the franchise from now on, and I am not sure I like it. The amount of additional transactions one has to make to simply have access to additional characters, cosmetics (which aren't an essential thing i guess) AND to even complete consequent parts of the story was truly not a wise decision to implement into this game. Some of the few pros of the game is that its achievements are far far easier to obtain than previous games (if you even care about that), and Invasions as an "endgame" mode was an interesting and entertaining addition to the franchise. Other than that, the game just feels like a cash grab from every single aspect.

Overall thoughts... I would suggest to just get the game on sale or something. As beautiful as the game is, I do not think it's really worth the price it has, especially if you take in consideration the additional amounts of money you'd have to pay in order to have access to more characters, kameos and even the next story section. Additionally, Khaos Reigns was AWFUL as a DLC: from someone that's been a MK fan for a long time now, completing its story section was truly the biggest waste of time, and those are 6 hours of my life I wish I could take back. If you want to have some fun while playing it (because trust me, you will be bored to death with it), do a drinking game for every time the word "chaos" is mentioned. By the time the story ends, you won't remember any of it, and trust me, that is for the best.

While certainly not my favourite Mortal Kombat, I did really enjoy my time with this game.
The cameo system was quite fun, definitely a change from previous titles, but I found it quite depressing that it was a replacement for what I had come to know, instead of just being its own separate mode.
While not being a huge fan when it comes to some of the character redesigns, and the continuation of the timeline multiverse stuff, the story mode was honestly a total blast, and something I very much enjoyed and can see others having a great time with.
Although I would probably not recommend this game over some of its predecessors, I did still have an incredibly good time, and can easily give it a thumbs up.

Never have I put more than 8-10 hours into any fighting game because at the end of the day, I'm not a competitive player and I don't play Online Versus (I'll get owned). I also feel that fighting games get boring pretty quickly if you play alone.

That being said, I am at 18.5 hours played at the time of this review and I am enjoying the game a lot. This will definitely be the most played game on the arcade cabinet once it's built, and for a solo player like me there is a lot of stuff to enjoy.

Towers of Time are great for earning rewards and taking on challenges, Invasions are fun to explore a map of challenges and unlock chests (more rewards), vs. will be awesome for the arcade, and for whatever reason I keep playing.

genuinely a solid mortal kombat game. sure, the kameos being a permanent feature instead of just be 'tag-team' features like they were in previous games definitely takes a bit of getting used to. but, theyre fairly easy to use and can help enhance your combos. the game is satisfying to look at and play, and theres a decent amount of content to be experienced. one thing i wish they did add to this game was a proper krypt. mk11s krypt was big and explorable and mkx + mk9 both had cool eerie krypts, and it added to the game so much. anyhow, this game is still good. theres plenty of base characters and kameos to choose from to match almost every playstyle, and theres also plenty of cool dlc characters to play as. its definitely slightly different feeling to previous mk games - but its overall a fun 9/10 game for me.

I'm not a competitive player so this review is solely for people who play offline/story/towers. I've played every MK since I was a kid and this one is really good, although I think you need the expansion for the full story and real final boss. The final boss in this is rather lackluster, I wasn't a fan of Kronika but at least she felt like a final boss. I've fought Shang Tsung and Quan Chi so many times, them being the final boss(es) was... meh. I hate multiverse stories but this was pretty well done.. still, so many things don't make sense. Liu Kang recreated the timeline and he chose to make the Tarkatans not a race of humanoid, but made them into a kind of mutant due to an incurable virus, chose to make Bi-Han still a prick, but he felt the need to make Cyrax and Sektor into an african woman and asian american respectively. The DLC characters also make no sense, I want to play as MK characters not Conan. MK has 77+ playable characters across the whole characters but we get OMNIMAN as a DLC character. No thank you. Give me Kintaro please. 
I like it more than the last though, gameplay is fun and the graphics are AMAZING. Story is pretty good, character dialogue can be AWFUL.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]7 - Good[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mortal Kombat 1 is a visually stunning fighter with a genuinely fun core gameplay loop. The switch to Unreal Engine 4 pays off handsomely, and the fighting mechanics are as solid as ever. Unfortunately, this potential is hamstrung by significant drawbacks: a poor online experience due to limited server infrastructure, performance stutters possibly linked to Denuvo, a lackluster story mode, and expensive DLCs.

If you primarily play offline locally and can overlook the campaign's weak narrative and occasional performance hiccups, there's enjoyment to be had. However, players prioritizing online competition or seeking good value for their money should approach Mortal Kombat 1 with caution, fully aware of its substantial flaws.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[h1] MK1 Review  [/h1]

I had a lot of fun playing through the story mode. I really like the new [i]aerial playstyle[/i] combined with the [i]Kameo[/i] system. However, most [i]Kameo[/i] fighters are not playable as main characters, which is a bit disappointing. Kameos are a new feature designed to strengthen your character‚Äôs weaknesses and help you either exploit the enemy‚Äôs weaknesses or defend against them.

The [i]aerial combat[/i] in MK1 feels smooth and well-executed. Besides the story mode, there are solo gameplay options like Invasions, which adds more content. However, this mode alters some of the game‚Äôs core mechanics by introducing elemental types, character upgrades, and other RPG-like features. It‚Äôs a unique addition‚Äîyou‚Äôll either love it or hate it.

[b]The main story[/b] is solid but not particularly long. Unfortunately, the [b]Khaos Reigns[/b] story mode is even shorter, especially when compared to the main campaign. Only get [b]Khaos Reigns[/b] for the action‚Äîotherwise, it's totally not worth the price!

All in all, I would recommend getting the game if you‚Äôre a fan of the [b]Mortal Kombat series[/b] or if you‚Äôre looking for a unique fighting game with a story mode.

[h3] Pros  [/h3]
[list]
 [*] Stunning graphics
 [*] New arial fighting style
 [*] Kameo system is easy to learn but strategic
 [*] Engaging main story
 [*] High-quality cinematics
 [*] Great tutorial mode
 [*] Character-specific tutorials to help you learn combos and playstyles
[/list]
[h3] Cons [/h3]
[list]
 [*] Khaos Reigns story mode is too short
 [*] Small player base
 [*] High ping servers affect online play
 [*] Steep learning curve for newcomers to fighting games
 [*] Not all characters are available for free
 [*] Underwhelming tower system
 [*] No player choice in the story‚Äîyou cannot affect the outcome.
[/list]

I love MK games and anime. This is like watching and participating in an amazing MK anime. The fighting is harder to get used to, in this one. It really relies on combos and combo breakers a lot, which I am not great at. I'm more of a special move and button mash with grace kinda guy. Highlighting a few combos in game is a game changer for me. I went from getting my ass kicked to getting flawless victories.

Anyway, I highly recommend this game for anyone simply looking to enjoy the story options and the tower mode. I use a 3090 and can use ray tracing, max graphics, HDR and 4k. Use the lossless scaling app (like $5 on Steam and works really well for 95% of games I've used it on) to double or triple frame rates. YouTube it, if you need help setting it up and then get smooth & beautiful game-play :)

Outstanding Mortal Kombat release‚ÄîNetherRealm has created an instant classic! Packed to the brim with diverse and engaging game modes, Mortal Kombat 1 delivers endless hours of brutal, beautiful fun. From the moment I started playing, I was blown away by the impressive variety of unlockables, nostalgic callbacks to past games, and stunning visuals that bring every fatality to life in jaw-dropping detail.

The single-player Kampaign Part 1 was an absolute joy, and after finishing it, I sat captivated through the entire Kredits sequence. Seeing literally two million talented people credited showed me just how much passion, effort, and dedication has been poured into making this masterpiece shine so brightly.

This is Mortal Kombat at its absolute finest‚Äîfast-paced, polished, clever, and richly rewarding. If you're even remotely a fan of fighting games, you owe it to yourself to jump into this phenomenal, lovingly crafted experience.

11/10 ‚Äì An ultra-satisfying, flawless victory!
