love the air combos

This might genuinely be the *WORST* Mortal Kombat game of all time. Worse than Mythologies, worse than Special Forces, worse than MK vs DC. The kameo system is unbalanced, unfun, and ruins the experience singlehandedly. That's not even accounting for the god awful story line, horrific character redesigns, pathetic guest characters, sleep inducing bonus modes, and Megan Fox.

Let's start with the story: It begins after timeline number 3 began (right after #2 got ruined once it started to become interesting in the MKX comic) and the Mortal Kombat tournament hosted in Outworld, which is led by Sindel, Kitana, and Mileena. Turns out, Shang Tsung from MK11 has his own timeline where he won the final fight in aftermath and decides to attack Liu Kang's timeline. Sound confusing? You're not the only one who felt this way. Long story short, Pyramid of Argus fight between all the "titans" from the main roster of characters leading to Shang Tsung and Quan Chi being defeated, The End. Or is it? Well Titan Havik didn't like not being involved so he decided to try and destroy the timeline too. 2 hours later of boring as hell story later and he's defeated, Bi Han is Noob but not evil ig because silly god magic or something, and all's well. Or is it? Yeah it is.

Netherrealm decided to redesign several characters. Havik is now Darrius even though Darrius is already in the game. If you're not aware, Darrius was a citizen of Orderrealm (Seido), but is the leader of the resistance, a group trying to take down the oppressive regime of the government. Havik is now that. Ashrah now isn't locked into the Netherrealm due to her demon roots, slaying other demons and other villainous creatures to purify her soul. She's now just able to leave the Netherrealm but somehow still shackled to it? They never explain it very well. Takeda is now Kenshi's cousin, and is also part of the Shirai Ryu, even though the creation of the clan was never shown during any part of the story, even in Khaos Reigns. Cyrax is pretty much what Takeda and Kung Jin were in MKX. Rebellious kids involved in a cutthroat group. Sektor is like her keeper, and is kinda just an asshole, even though Sektor and Cyrax were almost always close allies who trusted one another. Tarkatans are no longer a race, but a disease, which makes little to no sense and really isn't necessary to any part of the story apart from tying Mileena to the Tarkatans while still being a regular person. Scorpion is now Kuai Liang, which makes it down right impossible for Sub Zero to ever exist in another Mortal Kombat game, unless Hanzo is going to just randomly be a cryomancer in the next game (if there is one).

MK9 and MKX focused on horror icons. Freddy, Jason, Leatherface, Alien, and Predator all fit the games fairly well in terms of the themes of MK and the tone/direction the series was going in. MK11 was about action/super hero film main stays that had new projects releasing like Joker, Spawn, Terminator, and Rambo. Terminator, Rambo, and RoboCop were a bit silly and didn't belong in MK in my opinion, but it wasn't THAT bad. Now in MK1 we have random bullshit like 3 characters with a different coat of paint in Omni Man, Homelander, and Peacemaker, Conan the Barbarian, the T-1000, and Ghostface. None of these characters belong, none of them make sense, and half of them have been irrelevant since the 90s. I hate guest characters from franchises that aren't fighting games, because it's just cheap cash grabs, but when I saw KP2's guest characters I gave up hope on NRS to give fans anything good for bonus content post launch.

Invasions is terrible. I really can't explain it all that well. It's kinda like a table top rpg with really easy or brutal fights sprinkled throughout. It's not worth playing unless you want recolor #932. What sucks even more is that the mode was really enticing when it was first shown off, and it was hyped up a lot. Seasonal bonus content? Feels like the 3D era Konquest modes? Expansive rpg elements? Boy was that all lies and deceit. 

Megan Fox is the worst voice actor ever. I did a video series playing the story mode and I had to pause the game because I was dying of laughter from just how god awful she is at voice acting. She's not a great actor by any means, but she's definitely not terrible. However, if you put her in a VO booth get ready for the T-6900 to be reading lines like an illiterate 3rd grader. Just disgusting that NRS thought her performance was acceptable. At least Ronda Rousey gave a shit.

Overall, MK1 just might kill the franchise. I genuinely don't see myself being excited for MK13 when that gets announced, and I make it my job to play this series. Mortal Kombat is my favorite game series of all time. Deception is my favorite game of all time. Hell, most of my top 10 favorite games ARE Mortal Kombat, but MK1 might actually be my least favorite game of all time.

Released way to early, but as of 2025, I think this is a decent Mortal Kombat game. I am a die hard Mortal Kombat fan, and I would rate this game as fair. It certainly did not meet expectations, but I still like it.

I like this game a lot. The visual presentation and sound design are great.

[h3] Campaign [/h3]
The campaign is very cinematic and actually sets up the stakes and character motivations, which is something most games in the genre fail to do.

[h3] Replayability [/h3]
There's plenty of seasonal singleplayer content, but it admittedly has balancing issues, making it mostly a trivial grind if you distribute your stats right.

[h3] Controls [/h3]
The controls are less complex than Street Fighter's and Tekken's and should be easier for new players to get into.

[h3] Online Play [/h3]
Ironically, I'm not very competitive when it comes to fighting games and cannot comment on this major aspect.

[h3] Pricing [/h3]
Many people have rightfully complained about overpriced additional content. However, the base game is enjoyable enough. If you can look past the occasional main menu popup advertising new content, it's fine.

[h3] Performance & Loading Screens [/h3]
You'll want to take the system requirements seriously as stutters etc. can be quite disruptive in this type of game. I did enjoy the game even on my old GTX 1080, but I do not recommend it. I've since upgraded to a 5080.

The worst of it is the shader compiling. After every update, you'll find yourself in a very long loading screen when booting up the game. This is a terrible choice in terms of user experience and it's ironically punishing the people that the content updates are supposed to draw back in.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
A great game at it's core, if you can look past the notable flaws.

Fantastic Game & Great Arabic Support on Steam! But Why Not on Consoles?

Mortal Kombat 1 is absolutely phenomenal! It's easily the best fighting game I've played recently and arguably the peak of the Mortal Kombat franchise. The gameplay is incredibly polished, the visuals are breathtaking, and the overall experience is fantastic.

I was also incredibly pleased and grateful to see that this Steam version includes full Arabic language support! This is a fantastic addition for the large Arabic-speaking player base on PC, allowing us to fully immerse ourselves in the story and navigate the menus in our native language. Thank you to the developers for implementing this on the PC platform.

However, this excellent support on PC makes it even more baffling and quite surprising that the same Arabic language support seems to be missing from the console versions (PlayStation/Xbox) of the game. Why is there this disparity? Many players prefer consoles, and it feels strange that they don't have access to the same localization features that are clearly ready and implemented on the PC version.

It would be great if NetherRealm Studios and WB Games could bring parity across all platforms. I sincerely hope they consider patching in Arabic language support for the console versions as well, so that all Arabic-speaking fans can enjoy the game fully, regardless of their chosen platform.

Overall, Mortal Kombat 1 on Steam is a masterpiece, and the inclusion of Arabic here is highly appreciated and a major plus. I wholeheartedly recommend it. My main point of feedback is the hope that our fellow players on console receive the same language support soon!

Mortal Kombat 1 Review ‚Äì A Brutal and Beautiful Rebirth
Mortal Kombat 1 reboots the legendary franchise with a fresh timeline, offering a cinematic story mode, refined mechanics, and an engaging multiplayer experience that makes it a worthy addition to the series. While it delivers a fantastic core gameplay experience, some of the new features may not fully resonate with longtime fans, and the absence of certain classic elements leaves room for debate.

A Compelling Story with High Production Value
NetherRealm Studios has once again crafted an impressive narrative-driven experience. The story mode is a highlight, blending high-quality cinematics with intense battles to tell an intriguing tale of a reimagined Mortal Kombat universe. The new timeline brings unexpected twists to familiar characters, making even long-time fans question their allegiances. The voice acting and motion capture are top-tier, adding emotional weight to the experience.

Refined and Satisfying Combat
At its core, Mortal Kombat 1 continues the franchise‚Äôs tradition of tight, responsive gameplay. The combat feels fluid, strikes land with satisfying impact, and character animations are polished to near perfection. The balance between accessibility for newcomers and depth for competitive players is well executed. Kameo fighters add an extra layer of strategy, though their implementation may take some getting used to for series veterans.

Smooth and Stable Performance
Technical stability is another major strength. Whether playing on high-end PCs or consoles, the game runs smoothly, with minimal performance issues. Online connectivity is solid, with responsive netcode ensuring fair and enjoyable matches. The visuals are stunning, featuring detailed character models, beautifully designed stages, and gruesomely over-the-top fatalities.

Multiplayer: A Strong Competitive Scene
Online play is an excellent experience, with ranked matches, casual lobbies, and a strong matchmaking system. The rollback netcode ensures fights feel fair and responsive, making it an ideal battleground for both casual and competitive players. The variety of modes helps keep multiplayer engaging, from classic one-on-one fights to tournament settings.

Man, I gotta say, Mortal Kombat 1 (2023) just doesn‚Äôt hold a candle to MK11. I was so hyped for this one, but it‚Äôs been a massive letdown. The pace feels sluggish‚Äîlike, where‚Äôs that snappy, fluid combat I loved in MK11? Everything moves slower, the mechanics feel clunky, and it‚Äôs just not as tight or responsive. I used to rip through fights in MK11 without breaking a sweat, but MK1? It‚Äôs like wading through mud.

And don‚Äôt get me started on the story. I was expecting something epic, but it‚Äôs a total disappointment. It‚Äôs all over the place, lacks the punch MK11 delivered, and honestly feels like they phoned it in. The whole vibe is off‚Äîgameplay‚Äôs a chore, and the narrative‚Äôs a snooze. I had such high hopes after how solid MK11 was, but this? Huge miss for me.

There's a lot to like about this game but the monetization, absolute butchering of customization, and some story/character design decisions get a no from me. look, a lot of people have issues with this game and honestly a lot of them have fair criticisms to offer. if the kameo system seems like SUCH a major turn off, this game definitely isn't for you. if you're an offline player like me, your options are limited. but, in my opinion, this is a solid game that runs pretty well and has a fun cast of characters, with good designs and voice work, and a variety of playstyles. kameos are fun, you can use them to cover a main fighter's weaknesses, or to exemplify their strengths, or hell, not even use them if you'd rather. if you're looking for a single player experience that'll have you hooked for HOURS, then mortal kombat 11 is more your style, but if you like the look and feel of the gameplay here it certainly has a decent chunk of content for you to come back and check on every month or so. hot tip - base game fighters (and shang tsung) offer 200 dragon krystals on certain level milestones (an easy to hit 20 and long to get 31), and the new towers of time mode has a bi-weekly quest for 75 krystals. if, you know. you don't wanna spend money on microtransactions for dlc costumes.
additionally, this game has cross play and cross save with the playstation 5 and xbox series x|s versions (not nintendo switch unfortunately), so if you want to play online with your console loving friends, or if you bought the base game already on those platforms and don't want to unlock all of your cosmetics again, you have no need to worry. this game isn't as bad as people like to say it is online, but i'd stay away from it if what i've mentioned doesn't appeal to you.

On top of that, this game just isn't quite what it should be; it's a step back from MK11 in all the worst ways.
Among other things, they returned to the standard 3-gauge super meter system (although keeping fatal blows as opposed to x-ray attacks), which isn't that big a deal on its own (personally I prefer the dual-meter system MK11 had), but they made executing enhanced specials SIGNIFICANTLY more difficult than in MK11. 
You have to be practically frame perfect in order to execute one. They're even harder than in MK9/MKX, which the system was derived from-- I can fairly consistently proc enhanced specials in MK9, but in MK1, it's a fucking dice roll. This is even more annoying because doing enhances in MK11 was 100% consistent and I can pull it off nearly every time (since the timing is AFTER you input the special, instead of JUST BEFORE you press the face button to execute the move).

The Kameo system is just... Boring, really. I'm not sweaty enough to say whether it's busted or useless, but I can say I spent most of the story mode almost never using Kameos because it just wasn't fun or satisfying to engage with. It feels extremely gimmicky and like a game mechanic the devs would toss in last-minute in a final level, rather than the "redefining new mechanic" it's almost marketed as. I just don't enjoy it at all and think the game would be better off without it.

And now for something completely subjective; I really don't like the redesigns for most of the cast. I do like Reptile's design, at the least, but the other redesigns of Scorpion, Sub-Zero, Raiden, etc. all just kind of blend together into "young eastern fighter guy". I'm also just personally not a fan of Liu Kang's new "fire god" look.

Overall, at least better than MK Mythologies: Sub-Zero.

I haven't put much time into this game but, I'm a long time fan of the series. It's immediately apparent that this game is a complete downgrade from MK11. They took the worst mechanics of MK11 and centered the game on them. Kameo Fighters are kinda annoying but punishable so okay. Stage interactions are gone and stage fatalities are gone, kostumes are sorta gone, moveset customization is gone. You know the pre-fight dialogue, the feature so good that other fighting games started copying? Well, I guess since they ever so slightly slowed competitive matches, they're almost completely gone. The only interactions are at the end of the fighter select in Versus mode.

There's still something here though. The stages may not be that interactable but they have good music and look good. You don't really need to customize your moveset when they gave every fighter all the kombos and specials they could ever want. Kostumes are still bad; you get a lot of gear but no loadouts. You can't change your costume in the fighter selected screen, you have to manually go to 'Kustomize' and equip the gear and palette that you want. That or you can let the game randomly choose for you between each match (why???). 

This game is fine but, it's missing those touches that make Mortal Kombat special. Maybe pick it up with the Khaos Reigns expansion no for more than $30. I'm gonna put some more time on this and maybe my opinion will change but, I doubt it tbh.

I love the game, it's really fun and it's even better with friends. I play it on a daily basis to take a rest most of the time, but why the negative review you may ask?
It's a lot.
1- Most character designs don't look as good as the previous ones, this whole "reset the universe" thing is just a plot to justify this change, especially for women characters.
2- The game is not optimized, with sudden FPS drops and it somehow disconnects me even when I got good wifi.
3- This is something that is genuinely infuriating to look at, literally EVERYTHING costs money, it's as if I am playing a freemium game. I paid 60 dollars, and I should get most of the kontent and not have deals shoved on my face every time I open the game. Kameos, characters even the second part of the story is locked behind a paywall. Guest characters are justified, but locking the MAIN ANTAGONIST of the game behind a paywall is actually insanely greedy. Not only that, you sell skins and even announcers more expensive than some guest characters themselves. The most scummy part is that you somehow try to sell characters that you unlock later on the game and try to pose them as "DLC" but they really aren't, you put a really small icon which nobody would notice that it can be unlocked later, yeah classic scummy tactics. Trying to sell everything in a game that's already expensive on its own is bs and that's why it's a negative review. Corporate greed at its finest.

I first left a good review on this game but nah, I changed my mind. This is truly one of the worst fighting games ever made and it's 60$ like what the hell? I bought it on sale for 16$ with omni-man dlc so it came for 20$ and I feel like that price is still a bit too much. Graphics are... I mean they are good but it's way too much, like you punch the character in the face ONCE and now he's vomiting blood everywhere, all characters are just blood fountains. And Optimization is SO BADDD!!! You know you have to see everything on the screen clearly so you can act quick in fighting games right? Well say goodbye to competitive play if you don't have a high end PC. I can't even perform some combos just because of a slight lag, keep in mind that my Laptop is mid-range and I was running the game on low graphics. Now this is more like a me problem, but game is insanely hard to learn. Look, I like it if it's hard, this is a fighting game afterall. But this is just insane, you can't do sh*t for like first 10 hours. Even playing a street fighter ripoff on a fake gameboy would be more entertaining, I'm serious. You might ask why I have 10 hours on record? That's because my cousin forces me to play just to r*p* me every single round, he doesn't gets out of that room. I'm pretty sure the amount of gore in the game made him believe humans are 99% blood too.

It's a wonderful gore fest. Brutal as ever and extremely satisfying to play. For me it was the sole reason that convinced me to buy the game and I don't regret it.

Character roster is strong, there is plenty to pick from, even if you don't buy any of the DLC. It's fair to note that Shang Tsung can't be played unless you pay for unlocking him (ridiculous decision by NRS). Quan Chi being a DLC is also a bit annoying. But if you decide to spend some extra cash, you won't be disappointed. Guest characters are extremely well done both visually and in gameplay.

Kameo system is alright, I don't have anything good nor bad to say about it. I'm not one of those crazy combo sweats, so I'm mostly using Kameos as block string fillers or long rage poke tools. If the system was removed all of a sudden, I wouldn't even notice.

Singleplayer content is a bit lacking. Story is forgettable and lack a solid hook. Play it to watch some cinematics. Aside from that you have your standard Towers and the new Invasions mode, which I personally played 2 or 3 times before forgetting about it. Some character specific combo challenges, but that's pretty much a standard these days. Ultimately, it's fine but nothing special.

Cosmetics are hit or miss. Some DLC costumes look really cool, but generally most of default ones are uninspired or plain ugly. Add to that the fact that DLC store works on a weekly rotation, showing only around 10 costumes each week. If you're looking for a specific costume for your favourite character, better check in every week to see if it finally appeared. It's like they don't want you to spend money on the game. The currency for buying them can be earned through the singleplayer modes, which is nice.

The game is entirely held by it's brutal presentation and cool cinematic moves. Everything else about it is either mid or just bad. I enjoyed my time with it and I like returning to it every now and then, but don't expect a top class fighting game.

Linux experiences some performance issues while running this game. It's very choppy, especially during cinematic moments. There may be a fix for it, but I couldn't find one. It plays great on Windows though.

I was worried about the reviews, so I've waited to buy it on sale, for 22% of the release price. Honestly even for 50% I wouldn't have regretted the purchase.

For context, I played MK4, 9, 10, and 11.

+ graphics are amazing
+ I really enjoyed the first half of the story (I mean first half of "Part 1", haven't played "Part 2")
= second half of the story is OK, felt a bit chaotic and generic to me but still OK
+ UX is great (with one "but": I would usually leave the game for the day after a given chapter's final cinematics, when the "Chapter X" subtitle appeared, announcing a new chapter with new characters, which seemed like the logical place to do this, but when I started the next session it would make me watch the previous chapter's cinematics again, as apparently they are treated as a single cinematic with the next chapter's opening ones; my advice would be to watch them until the first fight of the new chapter and only then quit the game... but then again, rewatching more cinematics is a good way to bring you back into the story so maybe it's not bad)
+ as for gameplay itself, I've never really played these games competetively (except with friends) so I'm not an expert, but to me it seems pretty similar to MK11 which is OK; I feel like maybe a few classic moves for my favourite characters are missing but then again if I wanted to play the same game over and over again, I would not have bought a new one
+ character selection is decent
= I was worried about being force-fed characters from other universes, as I hate crossovers, but none of that was in the main part of the game (except maybe for an ad popup about T-1000 in the main menu); still though I would prefer it if they weren't in the game at all (like in the character selection) as this breaks the immersion for me if I see the Scream guy there, for example
+ I've recently upgraded so dunno about performance / optimization, but on 7950X + 4080S I've got stable 60 FPS (it's capped at that even without VSync, for gameplay reasons I'd assume)
- as far as I understood it, the negative reviews were mainly for "Warner Bros.' greed"; they mentioned the need to pay extra for "half of the story"; I was wondering what all that was about, but it instantly becomes clear when you start a new game, with a big screen letting you choose between "Part 1" (what you bought) and "Part 2", which is locked until you buy DLC... I mean I'm fine with more content being available, but if I buy a game, I want the whole story, and then maybe some side stories in DLCs... which kinda IS the case here, I guess, as the Part 1 story seems pretty much complete in itself... so maybe it's just the way they put it that triggers something in people... either way, you can always watch Part 2 on YT
+ main story (Part 1) took me about 10 hours (repeated maybe 2 or 3 fights), I think it's fair for the price I payed, plus of course there are Towers, multiplayer, some challenges etc. so there's plenty of content
- the Invasions mode does seem a bit silly to me, as someone mentioned, but maybe I just happened upon a stupid one this season

As someone that is a really big fan of MKX, I really don't find this game that bad. I know a lot of MKX fanboys are calling this game the worse thing ever, but I disagree. MKX is still my favorite, but I think this game is pretty good. I don't really have a lot of hours since I like watching these games A LOT more then playing them, but I still feel like I can form a good opinion.

Pros:
1. The graphics and animations are absolutely stellar (if your computer/console can run it). This is definitely one of the game's highlights; it looks amazing. All the stages are super well detailed, with a bunch of them having time of day options. The stages don't have interactables anymore, though, which is sort of unfortunate since I feel like that was something that defined the NRS fighting games. The animations all pop and look incredible, such as Raiden's electricity, Sub-Zero's ice, and T-1000s mimetic poly alloy. 

2. The DLC fighters are really damn good (not necesarilly in gameplay). They all look great and sport a ton of references to the source material. I was kind of iffy about the lineup this time around, but NRS has certainly proved me wrong. NRS has put a ton of effort into these fighters, especially with Ghostface, T-1000, and Noob Saibot. 

3. The roster is pretty good. I know the roster isn't finished (hopefully), but it already includes a ton of fan favorites that were missing from the previous titles, along with polishing some characters (like Baraka). The only really "missing" characters are Jade, Skarlet, Kabal (reimagined with T-1000), Kotal (reimagined with Conan), and the rest of the combat kids. Some characters also got sidelined as a kameo (will get to that later). I also appreciate how they included a lot of 3D era characters that have been missing for many years. All in all, very solid and a lot of these "missing" characters have been rumored to possibly return (mainly Jade and Cassie).

4. The gameplay is very solid. It strikes a pretty good middle ground between the super fast paced MKX and snail paced MK11. Pokes are actually punishable and moves that are supposed to be unsafe actually feel unsafe and punishable (for the most part, though it really comes down to matchup knowledge). Every character fits their niche well and nothing feels super OP (like unreactable mix in MKX and zoning in MK11). 

5. The game has proper modding support which is always a good thing. You can do stuff like change the character models to whatever you like, which has never been heard of in other NRS titles. 

Cons: (a lot of these will be personal issues)
1. The customizability is a severe downgrade from MK11 (and Injustice 2). They reverted back to singular skins and then added a million color palettes that no one asked for. Yes a lot of the skins do look good, but the MK11 customization would have simply been much better.

2. I personally don't like needing three bars to break. I feel like it encourages you to hold your meter and camp with it, which can be pretty lame. You also need your kameo active to break which is kind of silly in my opinion. If I have the meter I should be allowed to break, no questions asked. I think MKX did it better with the two bar breaker (thank God it's not MK11's garbage breakway at least). 

3. I still don't like fatal blow. I think comeback mechanics are good for fighting games, but not like this. It's scaling can be really strange; it can either do little to no damage or double your combos damage. A lot of them feel cheap in the sense where you can rob your opponent with little to no skill involved, or you can anti-air them for guaranteed damage since they are armored on startup and you can't block in the air in NRS games. I guess it's not the worst thing they could have brought back from MK11 (regenerating bars and breakaway can go to hell). I think DBFZ did it best with the "sparking" mechanic (not really with last stand, though).

4. The game and DLCs are hella expensive. Definitely wait for a good sale if you want to pick this game up. I think I bought it for 50% off. 

Mixed:
Well, here is the elephant in the room: the kameo system. I think it's great in some ways and bad in others. It's good in the sense that it can produce some really sick combos and make some gnarly setups. It includes a ton of different MK characters which is good in the sense that they are IN the game, but bad in the sense that you can't actually play them. I feel that only a few kameos are actually viable for each character, and obviously there's a meta and everything, but the goal is to at least make all of them somewhat viable. When considering no kameo, every character is still pretty viable (except Tanya lol). Playing a character with a bad kameo (for your character) can just feel like straight up losing since they sometimes matter more than your actual character. Some kameos are straight up useless with certain characters. On the other hand, some can feel pretty broken. You can now do grab combos with kameos, which is cool, but it reeks of krushing blow grabs from MK11, which were stupid af in my opinion. MK1 also brings the return of armored launchers, which will give any MKX player a heart attack. Armored launchers are dumb and there's a reason why they were mostly purged from MKX (they still exist but only for a few characters and they are two bars so sort of balanced I guess). You can also confirm mix that normally wouldn't lead to anything to full combos. For example, Havik is super top tier now because his primary mid string is a 50/50 between low and command grab which he can combo both with Mavado kameo. Other characters like Scorpion get near full screen conversions with Ferra and Homelander can confirm his insanely fast command grab also with Ferra (I see a theme). Overall, I commend NRS for trying something new with the kameo system, but I am personally not the biggest fan.

If you're an MK fan, you should definitely check this game out. If you're a general fighting game fan, you will probably enjoy this game, but have more fun with Street Figter or Tekken. I don't think WB should pull the plug on this game, though. It still has a lot of room to grow with new fighters, new story expansions (make Onaga the main villain again please NRS), and gameplay tweaks. If they do pull the plug, though, at least we will have Injustice 3! (yay?)

Edit: I realized I never even spoke about the story. I thought it was pretty good up until the mutliverse bullshit. I know everyone says this, but the mutliverse crap is really that bad. I thought the story would have been a charming kung-fu story with good humor, but NOO. Also, the Khaos Reigns story expansion sucks dick. The only things I liked about it were that they brought the kamidogus back and that khaos realm looks really cool. That's it. The actual story really had no substance since everything basically returned back to where it was at the end. I get Bi-Han is an asshole, but crashing your brother's wedding is top-tier hating. The dragon language stuff was interesting, I guess. Some random multiverse Rain dies, and they clearly tried to make you care, like I don't give a shit we barely got to know him at all lol. Havik throwing a temper tantrum when his kamidogus got stolen really painted him like a little bitch. He also gets packed up by his own creation, which is comedic at best, and then Noob Saibot bascially gets locked in gay baby jail afterwards. Like, ok?? The endings for Sektor, Cyrax, and Noob Saibot obviously hint at more, but they aren't canon at the end of the day. At least Sektor and Cyrax are playable now (I don't really care about the gender swap) and Noob Saibot is cool as fuck, so the DLC was good when ignoring the shitty story.

Briefly put, this is the weakest MK in 20 years. From its wild narrative choices to the one-dimensional Kameo system and the downgraded customization options from previous entries, MK1 is a letdown. The Khaos Reigns expansion is even more lackluster.

A step in the wrong direction by NRS, Mortal Kombat 1 feels like you're playing Mortal Kombat 11 with a tacked on assist feature. We've also hit the second reboot within 3 games, so there's no point in caring about the story given that they're wont to throw away a timeline at any given moment. It looks relatively pretty though and could be fun to play with friends, but as a longtime fan of the series since Midway MK, I just can't recommend getting attached to the game, let alone the series, as it is in its current state.

After spending around 100$ on MK11, and still missing some characters, I learned my lesson and decided to wait till the full / komplete edition of MK1 comes out. And this proved to be a correct decision.

This game is ok, not the best MK, but good at this price for the content it offers. The game is more colourful than MK11, Kameos are fun and there are some new and interesting characters. As someone who plays only the single player mode and no multiplayer, I would say that the story mode is good, and I actually like the invasions mode since it provides a lot of fights with varying parameters. They also kind of mix 2 characters into 1 in invasions, so fights feel fresh. Also the fights and characters change each season (around 60 days) so things are kept fresh. Towers is almost the same as MK11. There is no crypt, something that I loved in MK11 and surely missed here.

The only thing I disliked is the character customization. Most customizations are same looks in different colours, or a slight variation. The good stuff is behind premium currency, which I will never buy.

Overall, I can recommend this game at the current discounted price since it provides enough content to play for 60 - 80 hrs for a single player.

If you have a CPU that has some sort of core parking (E core / P Core Intels, 7900X3D), the game will run like trash because it cannot distinguish between the types of core, so the game jumps from different CCDs continuosly. It's a slideshow that not even Process Lasso can save and the advice is to just go into the BIOS and disable the non gaming focused cores. A truly remarkable achievement for such small indie studio not backed by a giant media conglomerate. Thank you Zaslav, very cool.

Edit: After a whole butt of finagling through task manager, Process Lasso and so on, I could manage to stabilize the fps. Basically you have to not only disable non 3D cache / E cores through Process Lasso for the game's .exe or else it will use whatever core it wants, you have to give it almost realtime priority in CPU, I/O, memory... It's fucking insanity that a high profile modern AAA game not only cannot understand modern CPU standards, it also needs you to give every priority on the system, plus sacrificing a fair virgin on moonlight.

The good. I love MK! I've been playing MK since I was 13 and I'm now 46! 33 years! 33 MFK YEARS! Anyway, I'll probably never stop playing MK unless they mess it up real bad and I'm sorta ashamed to say that. With that being said, for the most part, I actually like this game. The graphics are pretty phenomenal although the optimization was not so great at first (I haven't had any graphical issues in a minute). The series has looked good for awhile now and although imo this looks better than 11, I'm not sure how much better. 11 looked really good. The fatalities, brutalities and animalities were great in this one! Especially the animalities.  I actually like the invasions so those were a plus for me. Other than that it is just ok in comparison with the rest of the series.

The bad. At first I had issues with the optimization. After a few patches, and waiting a significant amount of time for shader building (almost everytime I want to play) the game runs OK. I say ok because for a AAA this pricey it is nothing special. It is what it should be but nothing more. The main story is... bad. Not horrible, imo, but definitely bad. Once again, for the money we are all paying the story should be better and include fatalities or something. I just wanted to get through it to unlock characters. If the story is going to be that bland I though they should at least make it shorter, or funnier? For me the cameos were somewhat bad. Ive gotten used to them but I'm pretty sure I don't like the idea of not being able to fight without them. I wouldn't say the cameos are bad but I do think the implementation was. It's not a bad game but it is not a good game either besides the fact it is MK! MORTAL KOMBAT! Sorry.

The ugly. I am tired, and I mean f$^&*n! exhausted, at this garbage of a crap DLC story and "extra" characters for the price of a full game! What is the deal?!!!! Yeah I want to play crap characters like Conan, Ghostface and T-whatever but only enough times to see all their fatalities. Yeah I could just go watch them on whatever but I actually want to do the moves myself. Then I could give a sh1+! You really want me to pay $50 for that. And wait for the extra content?! Fah Q!! I'll wait... until it drops down to almost nothing to purchase. Not only that but this game has become, like many, a micro transaction nightmare. 

My fatality: back, forward, down, down, front kick. I recommend this game at the low price of$25. If you can get it for that, NIKE. If not, I don't think it's worth it. I think thats what I paid, or close to it. I would never pay $60 or even close and I definitely wouldn't buy the DLC. We all need to stop supporting that garbage. MYSELF INCLUDED

First: Nitara's wings just disappear during Fatalities and Brutalities. Like, where do they go one of a sudden? It's probably a glitch.
Second: In Kung Lao's Brutality "Grind Away" he thwors his has into opponent's chest and stay there, but at the same time Kung Lao already has a hat on his head. Since when he's got 2 hats? I'm really split on this. I LOVE Mortal Kombat, i've been playing since MK1 in 1993 in the Arcades. I really try to support MK i am a big fan of the story and lore, and I pre-purchased the last few releases, only for the game to be on sale at steep discounts a few weeks after. 

But after MK9, MKX and MK11, MK1(23) is for a lack of a better or nicer word, disappointing.
1. The story mode was not as engaging, and there are too many changes to lore. Expansion story was too short, and to me, was just selling and using unwanted / unsold assets from the Season of Khaos in late 2023 / early 2024. I love Havik. As a final boss for the expansion however?  yeah disappointing.
2. DEI infested things littered everywhere. Unnecessary pandering detected. Especially Khaos skins. Unnecessary pink and green hair. Oh god. 
3. Invasions is just a grind. MK11 Konquest (Shang's Island) was MUCH better than this - and it had more easter eggs and things to explore. Invasions - why am I doing this when most of it should be done by an AI bot. I AM NOT AN AI BOT.

There are definitely positives, game is well balanced now, graphics are amazing, roster is good, finishers are imaginative, FLOYD was amazing, OG Sub Zero back as Noob!? YES!  

But as an OG MK fan from the start... 

ugh.     

Can Mr Liu Kang please use the hourglass and reset Netherrealm back to its glory days when they didnt have to pander to DEI or to an overbearing publisher that forces microtransactions and gambling for content, and actually make something us OG fans want?   You didn't need to gender swap Sektor and Cyrax. WHY.  Old MK2 Sub Zero is now Scorpion? and he's married to Harumi?!  WHAT IS GOING ON!?

THE STORY LINE IS NOW JUST MESSED UP.

you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I have been following Mortal Kombat since the release of the Sega Genesis port of the first game (I was 7 at the time and clearly not the age to be playing the game. Thankfully, I didn't know the Blood Code and the Fatalities.). It was the very first fighting game I have ever played. So for a long time, it was tradition for me to play the next main entry in the series (I played the two spin-off titles and avoided any future ones because of how bad they were, however, I do hear good things about Shaolin Monks so I will try that sometime.) The story and lore of these titles kept me playing all of them (not counting Vs. DC Universe as that was a stupid idea to begin with).

Sadly, starting with MK 11 (which is my least favorite in the franchise), a lot of bad corporate decisions showed up in the series and I was starting to lose interest in the franchise. The 2010s trilogy (MK 2011 [no longer available by the way. Thanks WB], MK X and MK11) had good fighting mechanics and excellent guest characters. However, because of my disappointment with MK11, I thought maybe I should avoid the next entry. At some point, I saw a sale on this game along with the Khaos Reigns DLC and thought to myself why not get it.

Okay, so do I think that this game is better than MK11? Yes. Do I think it's the best in the franchise? No. MK 1 has some good and bad things in it.

Let's start with the good. The character roster is way better than MK 11. I was happy to see characters like Reptile, Quan Chi and Ermac again because they were missing in MK 11. While I like characters like Sub-Zero, Scorpion, Noob Saibot, Baraka, Mileena, Sheeva, Sindel, Shang Tsung, and the guest DLC characters; the rest of the roster was kind of weak. I do like the story in this game and made me interested in playing it all the way through. The fighting mechanics are about the same as the 2010s trilogy so not much has changed.

Now for the bad. Oh Boy! The Bad. Like MK 11, MK 1 has the nasty greedy microtransactions that WB Games (who recently shut down Monolith Productions, creators of Blood, Condemned, and FEAR; at the time of this review. RIP Monolith), who has been persistant on encorporating them in every game they have under their catalog. Some of the character roster doesn't seem to be very diverse, which leads me to my next big gripe with this title: Kameo characters. Why is this here? Why can't I just play as these characters (well, maybe not Motaro as he looks tough to program as a fighter) instead of taking a page not only out of Marvel vs Capcom 1, but reminding me of the awful PS1 ports of X-Men vs SF, MSH, vs SF, and the aformentioned Marvel vs Capcom. I mean seriously, why aren't Jax, Sonya and Kano playable characters? I know I didn't play the Aftermath portion of MK 11, but really? Why not just have a Single 1 vs 1 or Tag Team like in MK 2011? I'm not going to mention the DLC guest characters as I know only half of that roster (I never seen The Boys, Invincible, or anything that Peace Maker is in, so I am not familiar with the characters) Oh Yeah, where are the stage fatalities?

A big problem with the game has to be Invasions mode and the amount of grinding to just get a character's 2nd fatality. I put in 41 hours into the game so far and only unlocked 6 characters' 2nd fatality. It's a slog to get through. As for Invasions mode, it's just a bunch of fights and other challenges on a board game-like map. One thing I can't stand about this mode is the fact that I can't control the camera at times when I need to. The camera always faces a specific direction depending on where the character is at. I also hate the clues that the game gives to you when a certain area is locked until you solve said clue. I solved one as Reptile using a specific fatality that the clue required.

Overall, while there's more good and bad, I can only type in so much. In conclusion, I feel that the franchise needs to be in the hand of a different publisher who hasn't had a nasty track record in recent years. WB Games has the rights to everything Midway made and they need to sell them to somebody else. One who can sell DLC, but not be aggressive about microtransations.

I have one last question in the end of this review:
Do I keep going with Mortal Kombat or is Mortal Kombat 1 more like "Mortal Kombat Done" for me? Only time will tell. By the way, MK needs to stop with the time traveling and realm theme. It's getting old.

I miss the krypt but invasions now reminds me of the multiverse thingy of Injustice 2 which was handled pretty pretty gooood. So yeah, imo, MKX and MK1 are the best MKs I¬¥ve played.

But when I picked this up, it gave me a rush of rage, excitement, and chills. I even joined a local MK tournament and ended up winning first place! It‚Äôs frustrating to see so much hate online because some people just follow the internet trend without really giving it a chance. You can‚Äôt call it bad just because you‚Äôre not great at it. The updates have been solid, adding new characters, stages, and balance changes that keep it fresh. I‚Äôm also loving the guest characters and fatalities. The only thing I don‚Äôt like is the Kameo system ‚Äî some people just spam the same combo and win, which is annoying. But overall, it‚Äôs a fantastic game.

A direct downgrade from MK11 in every way imaginable except for graphics. Stiffer gameplay, a far less interesting world and story, lack of game modes, MUCH worse gear system, worse singleplayer experience, and an overall huge lack of replayability. Game performance and load times are far worse, an the game feels obnoxiously unoptimized at times, despite merely having marginally (barely even noticeably) better graphics than MK11. The character interactions at the beginning of each match were downgraded from the last game, and the overall aesthetic of the game hardly even feels like Mortal Kombat. 

You could spend hundreds of hours playing MK11 because you had all sorts of things to work towards like getting new gear, cosmetics, intros, outros, and all sorts of other things to customize. MK1 took all of that away and stripped it down its bare bones. 

Mortal Kombat fans waited an inordinate amount of time  between MK11 and MK1 hoping it would be even more groundbreaking than the last game, and instead what fans got was a game with less flair, less identity, and arguably even less content than MK9 from 2011. 1 step forward 10 steps back. 

This game isn't worth it on sale, and certainly isn't worth the full price many of us paid for the premium edition.

The story mode is a highlight, offering a cinematic experience that reimagines the Mortal Kombat universe. The characters are well-written, and the narrative is packed with twists, betrayals, and epic moments. The gameplay is fast-paced and brutal, with a perfect balance of accessibility for casual players and depth for competitive fighters.

The roster features a mix of classic fighters and new faces, each with unique moves and fatalities that are as creative as they are gruesome. The Kameo Fighter system adds a new layer of strategy, allowing you to call in assists during battles.

The visuals are stunning, with detailed character models, fluid animations, and over-the-top gore that stays true to the series‚Äô signature style. The sound design, from bone-crunching hits to the iconic "Finish Him!" call, is top-notch.

Pros:

Revamped Story: A fresh take on the Mortal Kombat lore with cinematic flair.

Refined Gameplay: Accessible yet deep combat mechanics.

Stunning Visuals: Jaw-dropping graphics and brutal fatalities.

Cons:

Steep Learning Curve: Mastering combos and mechanics can be challenging.

Limited Single-Player Content: Outside of the story mode, options are somewhat limited.

Microtransactions: Some cosmetic items are locked behind additional purchases.

Rating: 8.3/10 - A bloody, brutal, and brilliant return to form for the Mortal Kombat series.

[h1]A True Knockout and Return to Formula [/h1]
 ‚Äì Mortal Kombat 1 is a shining example of how to completely reinvigorate a franchise.  More importantly, MK1 nails the trifecta that makes a fighting game enjoyable for me;  Graphics, Sound, Presentation/UI. 
I‚Äôm 42. I was just a kid when Mortal Kombat came out. It wasn‚Äôt until MKII that the series really grabbed my interest, and awe.  It wasn‚Äôt the gameplay, or gore however.  Sights and sounds had a bigger impact on me.  If a game looked or sounded like crap, I wouldn‚Äôt touch it.  MKII had hugely improved visuals, a new art direction ‚Äì more dark and sinister ‚Äì and massively improved sound quality, full of big impacts, effects, and over-the-top grunts and groans. (nothing has changed by the way. More on that later).  The groans were ridiculous. I loved it.  Every arcade I went to always had MKII turned up, and the above reasons are exactly why. It just sounded cool as hell.  The ports were mostly abysmal relative to the arcade version. Call me a purist I guess. 
MK3‚Äôs gameplay on the other hand did have an impact on me. I‚Äôll never forget the first time I saw someone juggling with the secret unlockable ‚Äúsmoke‚Äù character.  Combos lead me to learn the concept of juggle mechanics. But MK3‚Äôs visuals and sound also impressed me ‚Äì again, arcade being the best way to play it.  But after this, my interest in the series pretty much died. I‚Äôd discovered Tekken on the playstation. I‚Äôd go on to play that series for the next 20+ years. 
Forward the clock 30 years, and here we are.  Mortal Kombat 1.  This is the most impressive game I‚Äôve seen and heard in over a decade, possibly longer.  I‚Äôm a 42 year old gamer who‚Äôs been burned out for years by seeing his favorite game franchises go to the dumps. 
Let start simple; 
Graphics. Yes I‚Äôm that guy.  Wow me with the best visuals I‚Äôve seen in years, and I miraculously manage to overlook many flaws.  This is in full swing I suspect, but I can‚Äôt be certain. MK1 looks so god damn good I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll ever not enjoy playing it.  Check that off the list. Aces.  Just to be transparent, I do also own the PS5 version, which I've sunk additional hours into. PC graphics get a little bogged down, but I run medium 1080p on a modest setup, and it's mostly smooth, so I think they've ironed out most of the issues that people mentioned shortly after launch. moving on... 
Sound ‚Äì Nether Realms has always had, and continues to have, some of the best sound designers in the world. I know this because I am a sound designer ‚Äì well, I was. I‚Äôve moved on to a different career path, but I kept my ears.  While I mostly worked on synthesis for several companies, I know good sound design when I hear it.  MK1 has a cinematic atmosphere. The sounds might be straight out of a sample library ‚Äúsomething something cinema impacts vol 12‚Äù or whatever. Irrelevant. What matters is how you use those sounds. Punching, kicking, dismembering, blasting, teleporting ‚Äì every single sound in this game is satisfying, used to such good effect. I cannot say enough good things about the sound. Music is well-implemented, matches the vibe, and just overall very good. This is in stark contrast to Tekken 8, where by 3 seconds into the character select, I‚Äôm greeted with ‚ÄúOHH!- OHH!- OHH!-Oh! Oh!...FML. It really makes me want to punch someone in the face! The Irony here is they succeeded to some degree in getting me in the mood to fight! But‚Ä¶Getting me into the mood to fight in a video game is NOT the same as making me want to actually fight someone ‚Äì In Tekken‚Äôs case, I‚Äôd punch the music/sound lead at Namco Bandai.  Kudos to Nether Realms for delivering the goods, as they always have.  
Presentation!!!! HOLY S***.  Mortal Kombat 1 won me over completely with this. For years, the experience of playing fighting games for long periods was always somewhat hampered and dragged down by obtuse navigation, repetitive and undeveloped music loops, tinks, tanks, and clicks of menu scrolling and selecting, and excessively long load times. MK1 has none of this bs. There‚Äôs no douche bag announcers saying ‚ÄúGet Ready for the next battle!‚Äù (Tekken 7) past-their-prime obnoxious announcers like Lenne Hardt  (Tekken 8) ‚Äì seriously what the f*** were they smoking at namco hiring her.  No Clich√©‚Äô and idiotic symbolic phrases muttered before every match (GG Strive). It‚Äôs such a relief.  Mortal Kombat 1 sticks with what works. The deep, mean, pitch-altered James Earl Jones-esque announcer.  And the eerie and mystical Liu Kang to narrate the intro and parts of the story mode, with just the perfect amount of Asian accent to keep things feeling more overseas, and less American.  
With MK1‚Äôs presentation, everything moves along without getting bogged down.  There are basically no load times. The devs have figured out how to properly keep the show going without losing pace.  For anyone who hasn‚Äôt yet seen it, watch the intro, and see how it transitions into the main menu. Then select a simple match vs cpu; 2 figures emerge from the brush in front of you, while the camera slowly moves into a closer position, and the rest of the packed roster of characters materializes in the bottom half of the screen. It‚Äôs so sick.  This is how a PS5 game should be like. The menu is evolved, part of the whole experience.  The background behind them is a lake with rolling hills, a sparkling lake, mountains, and colorful Asian forests. Getting from the menu, to anywhere in this game feels natural and seamless. The big point I want to make is that this seamless menu and presentation overall  has a profound effect on my mood; I stay immersed, content with what I see and hear, and I want to stay. This is the only fighting game where I can freely navigate to the different modes without feeling annoyed, distracted, or frustrated.  
In all honesty I haven‚Äôt played the game long enough to give anyone a lot of feedback regarding how good the balance of the fight mechanics is.  I can tell there‚Äôs some ‚Äútiers‚Äù. I can tell there‚Äôs some characters that‚Äôll juggle you until you‚Äôre dead. That‚Äôs ok. I came from playing Tekken for 20 years.  I know juggling can ruin a game. But even on Medium difficulty, the game seems to strike a perfect mix of tactical combat, and brutal punish combos from the CPU. I‚Äôm ok with this, because they‚Äôve found a way to make the AI challenging without feeling cheap. Above all though, the devs of MK1 have put so much thought and effort into so many other aspects of the game, that I frankly I DGAF if it‚Äôs balanced or not. I hate online play, especially for fighting games. Give me a fighting game that plays to the strengths they‚Äôre typically known for.  Graphics! Sound Design! Slick presentation! 
All three of those = FUN!!!  MK1 delivers the goods.  Perfect for deep progression, or just local 1v1 with a buddy, or 1vCPU, It‚Äôs something you‚Äôd think a lot of games would succeed in doing, yet so many fighters in this generation have failed miserably, notably due to the little things that just make it a miserable experience. ‚ÄúHeaven‚Ä¶ or Hell?‚Äù (GG Strive).  Neither. Earth Realm please! 
Massive props to the devs who made Mortal Kombat 1.  For the first time in a long time,  I feel like I‚Äôm playing a game that was designed with my generation in mind. We are video game OG‚Äôs. Nether Realms accomplished this by removing the bs that currently plagues the other franchises, and just delivers an incredible spectacle that I want to keep coming back to.

Last time I bought a NetherRealm game. They killed the series because of greed. Time to move on to other fighting games until the company goes bankrupt I guess...

EDIT: After playing MK1 some more, I can really see why it died. 

Basically, the game is really unfit for casual players. When you play online, almost every hit results in a combo. So unless you can spend a lot of time to learn all the strings, combo launchers, and kameo interactions, you're going to be getting juggled for 30-40% of your health every match, over and over and over again.

Also, many of the paid characters and kameos have extremely weird attacks and abilities that are very hard to read or react to (fighting against Ermac and Quanchi feels like fighting against bosses in some other game). And of course you can't go into practice mode to test them out and learn their attacks unless you cough up real $$$ to buy these characters. 

All of this makes the game super stressful and annoying to play online if you're a casual Andy. So it's no surprise to me that most players bailed early on. 

OLD REVIEW:
MK11 was better, but MK1 is still pretty fun if you enjoy online matches. Crossplay is amazing. I don't particularly like kameos, but they're alright.

Story-wise, this is easily the blandest MK. All of the characters were so much cooler in MK9 and MK11. Everything was Marvel-ized, like they want to make MK story more kid-friendly. Shao Kahn is just a dumb jobber now, Cyrax and Sector are ironmen (ironwomen?), Shang Tsung and Raiden are a massive downgrade compared to MK11, Mileena, Kitana & Sindel are very forgettable, etc. If you're in it for the story mode, it's really better to just watch it on youtube.

This is probably my favorite so far. Just wish they get rid of the midgame fatal moves that would kill someone then you get up with a spike in your head like nothing ever happened. Guess its not the game for realism but it bothers me.

This game is an embarrassment to the franchise. I was so excited for this release after enjoying previous entries in the series but I ended up being severely disappointed. The story was terrible as well as the voice acting, the fatalities were lazy (look at these new animalities for example), and the skins were horribly ugly. As a female gamer I hated the designs for the female characters. It was bad with the men too but they really went out of their way to make the girls look as ugly as possible. They need to bring back sexy to Mortal Kombat because women enjoy that too. The gameplay was extremely boring, especially so in invasions where your progress is reset in every season just so you can go through the same maps again to receive more lazily designed excuses for skins and other cosmetic items. The Krypt was not added to the game so now you are stuck with a half-assed shrine instead where you spend 1k koins each time to receive a randomized reward with no completion tracker so you don't even know what's left to get from the shrine. They've turned this game into a live service game so getting everything 100% is impossible and a waste of your time. If you are an achievement completionist avoid this game, because one of the achievements is locked behind a boss battle that appears once in every season of invasions (which lasts for roughly 6 weeks or so) for only 3 days and they don't announce it anywhere on their social media to try to get you to sink all of your time into this garbage. Getting all of the achievements for this game was a slog and was the worst experience I've ever had playing a game. This game isn't even worth it on sale. You are better off sticking with Mortal Kombat 11.

This game, while it has it's obvious issues with greed - has the best gameplay in Mortal Kombat. The only downside is it's over reliance on the controversial Kameo system. The graphics are absolutely phenomenal. 

The bad? It has a bad problem with greed. There are way too many microtransactions, but everyone should have saw this coming as it started all the way back in MKX, and just slowly evolved into this with each title (including Injustice).

The game's guests, while cool tend to seem slightly unfinished (Homelander and Ghostface's infinites.) I blame this on the crunch time.

Speaking of crunch, this game was obviously not ready for a 2024 release window. The content is being slowly dripfed to us, and for whatever reason that is (NRS, or WB)... it is a problem. The Invasions mode is a massive flop, a boring time consuming 4-5 hour adventure every month and after that it's dry until the next season. This is what replaced the Krypt, a staple.

Overall, this game is good! It has a lot of issues. It's not a bad game, but it's not the best. 7/10.

Unfortunately this game had great potential, but it was rushed out the door with nothing much to show for itself and is a greatly disappointing mess. I bought the Khaos Kollection edition (which I believe contains all content that has and will be made) for ¬£19.99, average saving of ¬£50+, and I still feel shortchanged.

My review in short: Do not buy this game UNLESS it is on sale in the future for ¬£10 or less. It's got enough highs to keep you entertained, but the lows really do sour the experience.

As I have been a MK fan since the 1990s I feel I should give a more in depth review to others who might be in the same position as me:

GRAPHICS/ART DESIGN 5/5
Once again NRS smashes it out of the park, and I cannot fault how the game looks. The New Era looks exactly how it should, and the visual design of the characters and stages really pop. My only grievance is, given how similar the graphics are to MK11, that the facescans of the characters from 11 didn't carry over. Huge fan as always of the art direction. There was stuttering and drops in framerate, but I cannot speak to that being a problem with the game or my ageing rig.

MUSIC/SOUND 4/5
The musical scores really heighten the energy of both gameplay and cutscenes. The meaty SFX of the moves and the environmental sounds really pull you into the moment. However, some of the voice acting felt a little more hammed up/phoned in than previous titles. Megan Fox's performance was abysmal, her character's dialogue was easily the worst part of this already disappointing game.

GAMEPLAY 2/5
Off the bat the return of Fatal Blow is great, a much better system than the cheapening X-Ray moves from 9 and X. The pace of fights doesn't seem all that different to 11, although I am not a competitive player and may be less knowledgeable on mechanical details.
Cameo system adds a new element to kombat, giving players a greater choice of special moves and combos to execute. However, after playing for a short period of time it becomes clear this is a somewhat underbaked feature that only adds more bloat (now you have to remember the moves of all cameo characters to be able to counter effectively) seemingly at the expense of the main roster's movesets. The multitude of combos each character had seems to have scaled down, presumably to give the devs enough time to finish the Cameo characters.
Certain fatalities and Fatal Blows have been ported in from 11, and reuse of assets clearly demonstrates to me this title was rushed by the studio by publisher demands. Likewise the vast customisation options in 11 or even the larger array of skins in X seem to have been cut down for this game, with many characters lacking.
The Krypt was cut in favour of Invasions mode, which amounts to an overly simple boardgame with repetitive fights and frustrating opponents, all for little reward.
Microtransactions return with a vengeance in this game, not as in-depth with the Dark UX as MK11 but certainly tiresome to behold. Unsure what else to say about MTX when they're so ubiquitous now.
Finally the roster feels like a swing and a miss. It somewhat redeems many 3D era characters by giving them more interesting and rewarding movesets or stories, but I have mixed feelings about the included characters. However NRS has pushed the guest characters too far in my opinion, with many other reviews also wishing for a classic character's return in lieu of pandering to comic/TV/movie fans instead.

STORY 1/5
*PARTIAL SPOILERS BELOW*
Here I feel the greatest disappointment. The ending of MK11 provided a perfect setup to a soft reboot (which I'm not entirely sure the state of the setting around MKX warranted, but it at least managed to make it fun) and for the first half of the base game story it works really well.
The New Era characters really are sold to us and some end up being much more fleshed out than previous incarnations. I was quite enjoying seeing things play out in Liu Kang's New Era without the contrivances of time travel or alternate realities.
Unfortunately this more reasonably paced plot gets unstuck when the story decides it needs to return to the climax of MK11 and unleash multiple timelines, rendering all that characterisation utterly pointless and making me not care in the slightest about it anymore. For a small time where only two timelines are suggested to exist I was disappointed, but could buy into. Soon however, it all unravels into slop.
The Khaos Reigns expansion fares no better, with characters being plucked from random timelines and an even greater amount of confusion as to who's who and importantly confusion as to why I should care.
Given the really interesting and (for MK as a franchise at least) unique setup I was very disappointed. MK9 managed to handle rebooting in a really careful and well executed manner, and I'd have preferred to see something with that level of restraint. They took a swing and really missed, which is frustrating as it achieved a great first and second act.

OVERALL RATING 48/100

Give this one a miss.
If you are new to the franchise do not bother, despite signalling itself as a reboot this feels like a tired late instalment rather than a refresh. Try MKX or MK11 instead. If you are an existing MK fan, stick the games you already own.
I could only recommend this game if it drops below ¬£5 at any point, maybe pick it up to breeze through the thin-on-the-ground content to tick it off your list then be on your way.
Otherwise, on balance, avoid it.

I just updated my solution:

Step-by-Step Guide to Set Up Task Scheduler for MK12 Priority Management
1. Open Task Scheduler:
	* Press Win + R, type taskschd.msc, and press Enter.

2. Create a New Task:
	* In the Task Scheduler window, click on Create Task... in the Actions pane on the right.

3. General Tab:
	* Give your task a name, e.g., "Run MK12 Priority Script at Startup".
	* Ensure that the task is set to Run with highest privileges.
	* Choose Run whether user is logged on or not.

4. Configure Triggers:
	* Go to the Triggers tab.
	* Click on New... to create a new trigger.
	* In the Begin the task dropdown, select At startup.
	* Click OK to save the trigger.

5. Configure Actions:
	* Go to the Actions tab.
	* Click on New... to create a new action.
	* Select Start a program.
	* In the Program/script field, enter powershell.exe.
	* In the Add arguments (optional) field, enter the following command to run the PowerShell script: -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -WindowStyle Hidden -File "<YourGamePath>\SetMK12Priority.ps1"

For example, if your game is installed in C:\Games\Mortal Kombat 1, the command would be: -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -WindowStyle Hidden -File "C:\Games\Mortal Kombat 1\SetMK12Priority.ps1"

6. Conditions Tab:
	* Uncheck Stop if the computer switches to battery power if you want the task to run on both AC and battery power.

7. Settings Tab:
	* Ensure that Allow task to be run on demand is checked.
	* Ensure If the task is already running, then the following rule applies: is set to Stop the existing instance.
	* Ensure If the task fails, restart every: is set to a short interval (e.g., 1 minute) and retry attempts are allowed.

8. Save the Task:
	* Click OK to save the task.
	* Enter your user account credentials to allow the task to run with administrative privileges if prompted.

By following these steps, you‚Äôll ensure that the task starts at system startup, keeps running, and manages the MK12 process priorities automatically. This method offers a robust and reliable solution.

Review Title: A Brutal Rebirth Worth Every Punch

Review:

Mortal Kombat 1 is a triumphant reboot that blends nostalgic brutality with modern finesse. From the moment the first fatality lands, it's clear this game is a visual powerhouse‚Äîthe graphics are stunning, with crisp character models, dynamic lighting, and gorgeously grotesque environments that elevate every bone-crunching blow.

The new Kameo Fighter system adds a fresh layer of strategy, allowing for creative combo extensions and tactical assists that keep fights unpredictable and satisfying. While the gameplay feels slightly slower than MK11, it rewards precision and timing, making every victory feel earned.

Single-player content is robust, with a cinematic story mode and the inventive Invasions mode offering hours of solo fun. Customization options are deep and rewarding, though the absence of the Krypt is a minor letdown. Online features are still evolving, but the core experience is solid.

At $70, it‚Äôs a premium price‚Äîbut if you‚Äôre patient, the game often goes on sale for up to 50‚Äì60% off, making it an even better deal. For fans of the franchise or fighting games in general, the value is absolutely there. This is not just a game; it‚Äôs a statement. Mortal Kombat is back, and it‚Äôs more vicious, vibrant, and victorious than ever.

Rating: 9/10 ‚Äì Flawless Victory (almost).

Been playing fighting games since the beginning since I've been alive since the beginning of time. This is easily the best Mortal Kombat to date. It's missing a couple things I wish were there like bosses, stage fatalities, babalities, friendships and even character kustomization is a bit 'meh', but there's tons of gameplay and the actual fighting mechanics are really really fun and fluid this time around with much less restrictions on what strings can combo into what specials than MK11. 

My favorite Mortal Kombats have been 9 and X because they just had the funnest combo systems. Lots of variety and some really long ones with good practice. All the games before that were funny, but come on, MK2 tournaments were annoying. Games were hell to play. 11 felt to me very limited in what will work, making it repetitive and I lasted roughly 6 hours total. Bored Stiff. MK1, or 12, hits on all the sweet spots and the overall quality is pretty triple A while still running clean on my dated, yet uber, PC.

This is generally based on it's asking price, not a sale price, To be quite honest, I'd say it is worth it if you can get the entire bundle for under 40 USD Overall the game is solid, the fighting is fun, the moves are brutal, the combos can be awesome, and I can't recommend it enough if you are planning to play with friends. But my experience devolves to ONLY offline gameplay. I do not play these games online nor do I play any fighting game online unless I am going to play with friends or family, I don't play these games enough to become the very best like no one ever was, nor do I want to become a toxic FGC member.

My main issue lies with these issues: First and foremost The history of Netherrealm Studios and their constant greed, Microtransaction city, and it is mainly due to their success with MK Mobile, which I played maybe once and dropped cuz it got boring to me. But the idea that they would start selling fatality tokens, currency to buy outfits that you can earn in game but PURPOSEFULLY lock it behind you needing to play hours, days, months, and years of progress is disgusting to me too. Look at the greatest fighting game of all time TEKKEN 3, you can beat that game with different characters unlock them with each run you beat in the arcade. Even having access to modes like Tekken Force, and getting Tekken Ball after you put enough time into the game... which didn't take days, months, or years to obtain, and not a single dollar more than what you paid for the game. Season Passes are shitty, but unfortunately too many ("gamers" *cough* pay pigs *cough*) have agreed that this is how fighting games need to be now. But then in this game, if you didn't pre-order the game you have to pay 8 USD for Shang Tsung... you know that character that you get to play as in the Story Mode? And who has been a playable character since MK2 to MK9. Even if you buy the fucking Khaos Edition Bundle, you still need to fish out 8 USD (plus tax btw) to get Shang Tsung on top of that, which I refuse to do so he is still sitting in the Character Select screen Locked, what's even more insulting is that I am UNLOCKING SKINS FOR HIM DESPITE HIM BEING LOCKED! Not to mention selling HOLIDAY FATALITIES?! Charging money for fatalities should be illegal. Hearing all this made me wait for the sale for this game, Although I assumed I'd get Shang Tsung anyway since when you bought MKXL you got Goro. (who was also a pre-order bonus by the way) 

And one big thing I have to bring up is Invasion Mode... HOLY SHIT is this an absolute fucking chore to go through, You don't think much of it at first, you are on a little map and have the camera behind your character in third person and you do fights to keep moving forward and you think "Ohh this isn't so bad" then you hit the realization... "This... Is... Boring..." Continuing forward with Invasion at least after about an hour or two of playing you fight boss type enemies depending on the season, Everyone else you have to beat them once and you can move forward, But these enemies, you have to beat once, then they get up and activate some bullshit abilities, mainly Armor and elemental attacks that they remain invunerable until they are finished with their crap. And they want to claim "This adds difficulty." No this adds to the "I'm going to be as annoying as fucking possible" factor more than difficulty, Difficulty adds a since of challenge, Like the computer being more alert to your attacks, using more combos to wittle your health away instead of just taking hits like a chump. Adding MORE health and more damage reduction to an enemy doesn't make them harder, and I hate that argument because so many people are just so brain dead that they think this equals difficulty, That'd be like in Dark Souls if you defeated one of the first easier bosses, it got back up and had a cutscene of it putting on massive armor then you defeat it again only this time it took you 10 minutes instead of about 3-5 minutes, and then AFTER THAT, it gets up again and hovers in the air and rains down an unholy amount of fire on your ass and if it kills you there, you gotta DO IT ALL OVER AGAIN, Dark Souls can get difficult but their are definetly not bosses like I just described in that game. And the minigames... Ohh my god whoever designed these needs to be punched in the throat then fired, They start off innocently enough, "Use cyrax's bomb to destroy blocks before time runs out" "Escort the creature on a roomba to the other side of the fighting stage while defending it against zombies (which are the easiest ones)" "Dodge elemental orbs until time runs out" etc. But once you keep progressing farther... you get to some of the most difficult ones that could ever exist. They make you want to rip your hair out of your head. And oh of course they are "Optional"... But not if you want 100% completion on the map itself Sonny Jim so YOU BETTER GO FUCKING DO IT, OR YOU AREN'T COMING INSIDE FOR DINNER TONIGHT! It is 110% a boring, undeniable, absolute, slow fucking chore. Fighting games are supposed to be fun, you are supposed to feel accomplished when you complete something like these. But it is just so pointless and so irritating.

All this game has going for it for Single Player, and Local Multiplayer, or Online with Friends is the Story Mode (Not part two, that one sucked my ass) The combat itself, and some of the customization... if you unlocked anything for your characters you like. But this game is 100% not worth it's asking price, you have so many better options to spend money on with gaming right now, Hell, CAPCOM released a big ass bundle of fighting games in one big collection Marvel vs Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics you could buy that and it's cheaper than MK1 and you'd get more dollar value there than you would here. Grab this on sale, and that's it.
