I'll warn in advance that this is going to be a long review.

Whenever I try out a new game in a franchise I always do my best to go into it with fresh expectations, and I did so with this game as well. However this time I was sorely disappointed. I'll start with what I do like about this game:

1. The fatalities/brutalities have definitely been stepped up a notch and I'm glad to see it.
2. The cinematics and graphics are fantastic.
3. While the control scheme is slightly different than it's predecessor MK11, it's a relatively easy thing to get used to.
4. Takeda, Quan Chi, and Reptile are all fantastic additions to the roster.

Now onto the things that I don't like. While the story mode itself is good, it just doesn't feel like it has the same amount of thought behind it as the MK11 campaign did. In fact just about everything about this game feels rushed. 

One of my main complaints about this game is probably more of a personal preference, but I'll say it anyway. The change to the art style and general character skin designs are just boring. They made it too simplistic. I don't like the new art style. The second thing that this game failed to deliver on for me is the kameo system. You rely way too heavily on it in fight, and it just makes it feel like you're not the one really fighting. And on a secondary note, with the addition of kameo characters we also lost things like custom intro/victory cutscenes that were unique to each character like we had in MK11. Instead every time you go into a fight it's the same damn cutscene. 

The third thing that I don't like about this game is the addition of characters like Homelander, Peacemaker, and Ghostface. It just feels like you're turning Mortal Kombat into a goofy superhero mashup game. Which is just not what Mortal Kombat is about. The fourth thing that was upsetting to see is how badly they paired down the character customization abilities. There's nowhere near as many skins or different gear pieces for each character than there were in MK11, making the game feel less personal and honestly less rewarding. In MK11 the reward for being really good and dedicating yourself to the game was gaining the ability to customize your favorite characters to your heart's content, even allowing up to 4 different variation slots per character. So in comparison to it's predecessor MK1 just isn't on the same level.

The last thing is more of a minor gripe but on top of everything else, it just pisses me off. The new menu UI is horrendously boring. In MK11, everything in the menu was stylized, well formatted, and it was interactive. It made just moving through the menu's to do things an enjoyable experience and it's something I miss in this game.

So in conclusion, while MK1 did some things right it also did a lot of things wrong. Maybe with the next game Netherrealm Studios will listen to their community.

This game hurt my right index finger.

In all seriousness, definitely a very good storytelling game, however there are a few plot holes and contradictions in the story. As for the gameplay, it is very fun to learn combos and get used to the characters, however there are a lot of balance issues when it comes to certain character's combos that you cannot escape from without a Combo Breaker because it never ends, such as Scorpion, Reiko, Liu Kang, Ghostface, Smoke, Johnny Cage, and Raiden. But other than that, the gameplay is fun. You will also encounter a lot of input delay due to how the game functions, but you will eventually get used to it. 7.5/10 for me in terms of gameplay. As for the Online community, very toxic individuals who love to say the N word every chance they get and will berate you if you hurt their ego. Met at least 10 in only 25 games played.

Even though there are clearly issues on the balancing side of the characters, I have a good time playing the story, invasions, towers and PvP. I am a GM for now and I do have a great time on Kasual/Ranked matches.

Very dissapointing. Imo, Ed Boon is too stuck in the past, nostalgia is killing this game. I can only call this a half-hearted reboot that soullessly follows the trend of Marvel-esque multiverse stories, that although entertaining enough, keeps on digging the grave of whatever potential this franchise's lore had by never taking it too seriously.

As for the rest, it's a game that failed to learn from the mistakes of MK11 and even doubles down on some of them. The worse aspect in my opinion being the customization part of the game. Like, sure, the Krypt wasn't perfect, but Invasions is infinitely worse and padded in a way that seems to want to kill you from boredom. This game is monetized very heavily and honestly, the free stuff is a drag to get and not worth the hassle, with the exception of the grindiest stuff.

As for the towers of time, they don't seem to have changed as much at first glance, but after playing for a bit you notice how they have no sauce at all compared to the last game. The levels system and making the floors (minus the top one in some cases) one round encounters was not a great idea, not to mention, the loot is pretty boring most of the time.

The multiplayer is dead at this point. It takes ages to find matches and the Kombat League is basically unchanged and as flawed as ever. And don't get me started on the Kameo system or the DLC pricing.

I could keep going but it's just not worth it. Point is, don't buy this game, it makes MK11 look like a masterpiece.

Been a Mortal Kombat fan since the very first one in the 90's and used to go to the Arcade daily for MK3 as a teen. I've completed the campaign for MK1 and what started as a very promising game ended is such disappointment. Let's first talk about the good: 

- The core combat system is really great. It's extremely satisfying, as usual, to complete combos and fatalities. 
- Graphics are crisp, fluid and optimized. The environments are rich in detail and really impressive. 
- It runs great on handhelds. I also played this on my ROG Ally X and it was a treat. 

The bad: 

- Everything seems locked, even after completing the campaign, behind some sort of microtransaction, paywall, or a LOT of grinding. This is a massive let down for me. I've played 10 hours of this game and I stil cannot access almost anything, apart from maybe a couple different skins for characters. This is after already paying $60 for this game. You pay that much.. and you're still faced with a half-game, where the rest is locked behind a paywall, or incessant grinding. Shame on you developers. I will never support another MK like this. 

- The story goes from "pretty damn good" to "wtf just happened". I mean literally, even one of the last achievements is called "What just happened??". The end of the first campaign is an absolute sh*t show. And right after you complete it, you're slapped with another paywall to continue the story further. LOL!

- The grind: In order to even get the juicy gear, skins and other interesting stuff, you have to complete "invasions" mode, which is truly a boring grind. 

All in all.. the core of the game is fantastic, then ruined by pure greed. Not recommended.

I slept on this for quite awhile because of the negative reception, honestly it's much better than I expected. 

Graphics, animations, movement, combat, everything is very polished here. Looks and feels great. I was worried about poor performance due to a lot of complaints about optimization, but I've had no issues at all. RX 6700XT, R7 5700X3D, 32GB RAM and I'm getting 60fps stable on high settings with FS3 enabled.

There's some decent modes here, too. Story is pretty good, towers (modern & classic) and regular old local matches are nice. Character customization seems pretty fleshed out & the roster & maps are good as well. 

The only real downside is the elephant in the room, the micro transactions. Lots of stuff behind a pay wall, the company is hella greedy but the game itself is a good time, just don't let them suck you in to pay more money lol.

I didn't like the Kameo fighter system. Was hard enough trying to master attacks and defend against one character, now I get lit up and juggled by two. Way too much going on, I don't see any skill based moves. The newer fighting games cater more to the instant gratification of the flashy moves with less moves and buttons to memorize. I like more of the old school Tekken tournaments. Every move feels way too committed like a rock / paper /scissors, giving the opponent way too much time to follow up on a slight mistake, leading to a hit for hit, turn based fight. It just wasn't as fun of a fighting game for me as SF6 or Tekken 8, where the fights had more fluid gameplay.

Why so cheap?

So the only similar game to this ive played is Injustice, which set my expectations of this game REALLY low. 

And at first it wasn't fun, i started off with the sand time guy and was getting my ass handed to me because i go for reads instead of combos and he had a lot of low range combo building attacks. But I still had a bit of fun. Then I started up the story.

I had no idea that I was basically in for a movie, all the first where REALLY easy (i played on normal difficulty), except for the final boss who killed me twice before i beat him. Other than that I didn't die except at one strength check when i wasnt looking. 

That being said, the fact the game was so easy only made it more apparent that in that 10 or so hours of story i played through, MOST OF IT WAS FREAKING CINEMATICS. And actually good ones too, This game is basically as much of a movie as lord of the rings, which in its own right is insanely impressive.

Its not easy to sell off a 10-20 hour game at 50$, but I think mortal kombat is an exception, i think its so incredibly fine tuned that it is indeed worth that exhorbitant amount of money.

Not only that, but im still enjoying it, i havent even played online yet but the seasonal events they release are incredibly fun, the skins you can earn look amazing, and even without those its still fun to try out all the different characters, and learn to fight with them.

The controls of mortal kombat are very smooth, and easier to pick up than injustice 2s controls, they also make a shit ton more sense. One of my favorite parts about them is many of the are universal, such as forward+back+x allowing for a ranged attack on most characters. 

My ONLY problem with this game is its too combo based, I haven't played online, but after fighting a few high difficulty bots (and losing), it becomes apparent that a single combo doing up to 500 damage after starting from a light or quick pull-out attack means your fucked after 2-4 hits. 

Other than that, amazing plot, great characters, super fun game mechanics, super easy to learn game mechanics, so much content to keep me engaged once i've beaten the game. Just all around well done Netherealm, you really knocked it out of the park on this one.

Ya'know. MK1 got so much crap early on, it kinda put me off...

But now that I've played it, it's become hands down my favorite form of MK to play.

Do I think some things could be improved? (Kameos having a weird call-in animation that you can SOMETIMES cancel but never feels consistent) Sure.

But do I think it's "Trash" or "Dead"? God no. It's far and away better than MK11 in my eyes, and I'm sure that will get me some hate, but It's just my take. 

I played "Ko-op" through the entire campaign via parsec, as well as some of the towers and invasion mode, and had an absolute blast, and even alone, it's a game I've dumped 14 hours into over two days.

I will say, I'm not a "ranked" guy. I don't lab my ass off, and I don't try to go for the most optimal stuff every single game. I am however, no stranger to fighting games. I've played just about everything under the sun at least some, and am pretty consistently playing SOME sort of fighting game. I've chased the ranked dragon in multiple games, but MK just never was that kind of game for me. It's always been a "with friends" experience, and for that, it's been an amazing ride. I'd say I've more than got my money's worth out of the game and I've only just begun.

Maybe the hate comes from over-optimization in ranked, but that's never bothered me either way. FFS I play Eddy, Lidia and Lee Chaolan in Tekken 8. I'm not here to play top tier, I'm here to play the game, and for what MK1 is, it's a fantastic "Pick up and play" game.

My Ko-op partner had only briefly played one single session of MK11 for maybe....an hour at most? And he was kind of mixed on it. Now with MK1 he's already picking up character Archtypes really well, and making his own strategies around using characters compared to my own, which is really cool to see. There's a lot of freedom at the Low~Intermediate levels. I can't speak for high~Top level play, as I'm not garish or self-centered enough to put myself there (Or delusional.)

Out of the entire roster, there was only one or two characters that didn't immediately appeal to him, and he's no stranger to fighting games either, just mortal kombat. He was able to pick up and play within minutes, and go toe to toe with me who had been playing MK since I was 4 years old, which I think both speaks to the accessability of the game and his prior experience with fighting games (And just in general he's quite good, when he's not in his own head.)

I'll be honest, the game is surprisingly hard and unfun to play on online mode.

The gameplay is cool with bots and all the interactive voicelines too, but you'll most likely go to multiplayer since i did not pay that much of a price to play with NPCs in a multiplayer game. And this is where my love for the game goes down, not even in the first match i already started getting combo'ed without having the ability to break the combo at all, but even if i did do that they would just combo me in the corner again no matter how many keys i press. And additional info is that i was playing on a controller too. I literally couldn't win A SINGLE online match i played, there was one time where some random ass dude literally combo'ed me in the air for 5 and more seconds, and THAT WAS MY THIRD MATCH.

Now this may look like a "skill issue" whine but i am just complaining on how unwelcoming online is for casual players.

To conclude this, i am not saying that the game is bad, in fact, it's fun. But what irritates me is the multiplayer mode, which places me with players with a way skilled level than mine.

its honestly a shame how amazing the character and environment artists did when creating this game. the characters have some of the best designs to date and the stages are breath taking. what really is the issue with mk1 is the lack of content and abandonment of the game after being promised it was going to be their most supported game just for WB to cut the chord of the game and start the next one because they got greedy. No KP3, Khaos reigns was awful, the rushed released with a ton issues and no krypt? The game play is one of my favourite in the series, that netherrealm really delivered on. Its a shame that the game was abandoned as i believe it had so much potential to do well if they just listened to the player and stopped charging so much money for fatalities and cosmetics. This game really fell short because this was WB's cash cow, there was no love or passion behind this game, just another project to pump out money. Games are starting to lose their purpose and its the corrupt companies behind the hardworking developers and artists really ruining it for everyone. If MK can get away from WB and find a different publisher, one that will actually give it the love it deserves,  then maybe it has a chance of redeeming itself, but as of right now, ive never seen such a criticised MK game in the 10 years ive been playing it. I also was NOT  a big fan of the selection of characters we got in KP2. So many other characters were requested, they had Jade, Sonya, Kano, Skarlet being requested and instead we got Conan and a bunch of awful guest characters who no one even wanted. The timeline BS needs to end in this game, im tired of hearing about timelines and dimensions, its getting old and unoriginal. Thats what MK1's story is missing, originality. We were promised that MK1  was not a continuation from MK11, but thats exactly what it was, a continuation from MK11. Its a beautiful game filled with empty promises which really breaks my heart as i love this series, but companies are getting corrupt and greedy and this will be the death of many more games to come.

I also see that the review bombs are mostly complaints of this game being overpriced, and the micro transactions. To me it seems like if you get the content on sale and don't care about cosmetics, this is just a super fun and beautiful looking game.

The studio executives are too afraid to produce anything original, so we end up with this - it feels like regurgitated garbage, like all those 59 assassin's creed games. No wonder the 2nd was the best - they were still taking risks back then.

The fighting's okay I guess? But in 2025, we deserve something better. When this garbage occupies the fhe fighting genre's leaderboard - the entire genre is up for grabs - any game which innovates, will take the 1st place.

The game has great graphics, gameplay is a bit slower compared to mk11 since you can only cap 60fps but it still smooth. I think this is step down from mk11 since most of the characters have this intro before the fight which they talk to their opponent then fight, unlike in mk11 where you can choose your intro per characters which add more options for players especially if they have favourite characters. I tried different characters to play as and I must say they are pretty fun but sometimes they can be confusing especially when the when their list of movesets does not explain much how to pull of their special moves or combo or if there is requirement for those. I think there are easier and hardest character to play as. Some combos are hard to pull off since there is this specific window or timing that you must learn or pay attention to but they are very short of timing or window. Also character design on most character  are downgrade for me compared to mk11 or even street fighter 6 especially the female characters. That being said, it is not a bad game or anything but I wish they did better job for both long time fans and new players. I cannot speak for microtransaction but I heard they are pretty expensive. I suggest get this on sale and avoid expensive microtransactions. I got this on sale like 50% off or maybe more dlc included on that discount.

I've been a Mortal Kombat fanboy for most of my life, but the latest installments of this series have been pretty disappointing and this one seems to take the cake for the following reasons.  This game has bizarre performance issues for being out as long as it has been.  Loading the game takes longer than I like, starting fights in invasion mode takes longer than I'd like, scrolling through characters in the menus even has an excessive loading time.  As far as the game play goes, it is no improvement on the previous game and in fact I feel has less content then previous games in trade of what I feel is a very lazy live service system that seems to be there to primarily sell you skins that you may have missed out on from said live service events.  All in all, I dislike the state of the pc port, Kameo characters, live events, lack of a krypt, and the story.  Very disappointing.

Edit: I did try re-intalling the game on my SSD and this did not help any of my issues

I paid the $120 for MK1 so i could play it 3 days earlier than everyone else. I got a 3 day head start so when I went to play my buddies I whooped them good. I really liked MK1 at first. But then it seemed like it had non-stop updates every single time I went to play it, and not small ones either that would only take a few minutes. I stream my PC games to an arcade machine, that is how i play MK1. Mortal Kombat was meant to play on an arcade machine. The days when I want to quick just turn on my arcade and play MK1, i cant, because its got more updates to install and takes at least 30-60 minutes average. Then after the updates when the game finally starts it take another 10 minutes or so to "recalibrate", how annoying!!! And it's every single time there is an update. You waited an hour plus for the update to download & install. The game finally gets loaded and they make you wait more. Very rarely have I been able to boot it up and just play it. I HATE IT!!! If that wasn't bad enough now today MK12.exe file had a virus or something in it? So after verifying the file, re-downloading, re-installs, patches, ect I've been trying to play MK1 for the past 2 hours at this point. 

Also, these fools want me to pay another $50 to get the DLC for 6 more playable characters - when I purchased the super deluxe bundle. I've already spent enough on this crap. Also with the DLC characters they gender swapped Sector & Cyrax into females. Why? How about you turn Lui Kang black while you're at it? Or turn Raiden into an morbidly obese overweight white woman? Or better yet, make Scorpion & Sub-zero trans-genders. Diversity killed MK1.

I do recommend it, but with a few 'buts'.

It's fun! I think that is what's most important here, and the game looks great. Was really fun seeing a newly imagined story and roles for characters. Fighters feel distinct from each other, which is something NRS struggled with in the past in my opinion. I find myself really wanting to fire up the game and play, which is something I haven't felt since MK9. It's not all sunshine and roses, though.

However, the DLC and micro-transactions are wild. I bought the 'Khaos Reigns' edition on sale, thinking I was getting everything. I didn't. four or five kameos aren't playable still, and I cannot play as Shang Tsung, which is awful. He was a pre-order bonus, that i wasn't aware of. Even worse, he costs $10 CAD!! I know this isn't NRS doing, but rather Warner Brothers, but damn that is shameful. Bring back the Krypt!! Was so much fun unlocking everything with my hard earned koins, instead of paying for everything with a credit card or gambling my in game currency.

Secondly, the Kameo system is just odd. It feels clunky and takes away from the experience. Just a personal knitpick.

Lastly, performance issues on PC are still abundant. Make sure you install this to a SSD for best performance.

So, do I recommend this title? Yes and no. Yes, at a steep discount, but definitely not at full price.

Sure! Here‚Äôs a draft of a review based on your feedback:

Mortal Kombat 1: A Thrilling Return to Pure, Unfiltered Chaos

After finishing the latest Mortal Kombat 1, I can confidently say this game is a wild, beautiful ride. From the moment you dive in, the graphics immediately grab your attention. The attention to detail is absolutely stunning‚Äîthe character models are incredibly lifelike, the environments are rich and dynamic, and the brutal fatalities have never looked better. It‚Äôs clear that the developers have poured immense effort into pushing the visual boundaries of what Mortal Kombat can deliver. The blood, the sweat, the bone-crunching action‚Äîit all looks so vivid, it feels like you're stepping into a living nightmare... in the best way possible.

But more than just the visuals, this Mortal Kombat entry nails what it's all about‚Äîpure, unrestrained fantasy. The story pushes the limits of reality, as Mortal Kombat always does, blending absurdity and spectacle in ways that only a game like this can. It‚Äôs easy to get caught up in the nostalgia, and while there are callbacks to the past, this isn‚Äôt about clinging to history. It‚Äôs about embracing the insanity of the Mortal Kombat universe where, quite frankly, anything goes. The game doesn't ask for your suspension of disbelief‚Äîit demands it. And that‚Äôs exactly how it should be. The world of Mortal Kombat has never been a place for logic or realism; it's a playground for outrageous imagination, where anything and everything is possible.

What really shines through in this new iteration is the energy and chaos that make Mortal Kombat special. Every fight feels like a spectacle, every move has weight, and every finishing blow is as satisfying as ever. Whether you're a diehard fan or new to the series, Mortal Kombat 1 invites you to leave any cynicism at the door. This is a game that thrives on the craziness of its own existence, and it's all the better for it.

Mortal Kombat has always been about pushing boundaries, and this installment is no different. If you‚Äôve ever enjoyed the series for its unapologetic over-the-top action, you‚Äôre going to love what this game delivers. So, let‚Äôs leave the past where it belongs and enjoy the chaos of today. After all, in Mortal Kombat, anything is possible.

This game is so poorly optimized that it would be funny if it wasn't so frustrating, add to that it really seems like roughly 7 out of every 10 players are very blatantly cheating and being toxic yet there's no mechanism that I can find to report players. I really tried to push through and have fun in spite of these issues, but it seems like the more I play, the more cheaters I come across. Combine the near endless onslaught of cheaters with the never-ending framerate issues, the matches that take forever to actually load into and lag spikes in spite of my fairly beefy PC and good internet and you've got the perfect way to suck the fun out of a game that'd otherwise be an absolute blast. I just can't justify spending more time nor more money on this game. The campaign proves this game definitely can be fun, and from what (admittedly little) I've seen of the previous MK games, this is the best and coolest looking one in the whole series, but when applied to the multiplayer, all you get is a very pretty slideshow of your character getting juggled by someone playing a DLC character they probably bought with their mom's credit card.

Have loved every MK previously, and tried my absolute hardest to love this game but cant recommend it at all. Lot's to get into but the main "new" aspect of the game: Kameo's. They offer a baseless slowness to the game, with most player you run into spamming some type of cross map kameo. Fight's get boring, and become much more of a cat and mouse fight.
I've grinded multiple seasons to the top rank, and enjoyed lot's of fights, but this rarely changes other than players playing more and more safe. Good fights are far a few between, with less combo's and more pokes and running, as the game encourages.

Lack of content, and bad content. The DLC Khaos Reigns was priced at $40, close to a full game and offered an extremely bad written "multiverse" story, and 3 fighters who are designed well but not worth $40 regardless. Combos are very minimal, more than MK11 but still a dumbed down version of anything previous like MK9 and MKX. Enemies fall out of the air too quick to combo after doing a chain, or a single combo and you arent able to extend it.

This is painfully obvious with the future DLC support being cancelled, and the player-base dropping.
Again, Tried my absolute best to love this game and defended it when I could but can't anymore and would never recommend it. The worst mortal kombat to date, and disappointing beyond measure. Hope MK returns to it's roots, and to it's core gameplay but I doubt it. Hopes to MK12 being better,

I am a veteran Mortal Kombat player as I have played all Mortal Kombat Games for almost 30 years. I was a bit hesitant to buy this game due to the new mechanics and I wasnt really thrilled at MK11 small combo mechanics. I prefer a much longer combo system like the original Mortal Kombat games. Overall The story is new and fresh and feels pretty good compared to other games I was happy with it. The combos feel a little better than Mk11 which is nice. I still feel Sam and Dean Winchester would have been a great addition to this game since i think its Warner Bros. anyway... also with the tag system it just makes sense if they were going to put them in a Mk game this would be the one. Im not really that thrilled about all the superheros i like the darkness of mortal kombat games and darker characters. Even ares from Injustice i think would have been a better fit but thats my opinion im sure not everyone has the same one. The combos are are a learning curve and some i feel are still very difficult to pull off which is nice for the challenge but almost impossible in online gameplay for some. I also miss erron black so would have been nice to see Stryker at least get his own move set but i guess i can deal with a cameo. Id rate this game an 8 out of ten just for my own personal reasons but the graphics are great moves feel fluent overall a great game if you can get it on sale I would recommend it.

Incomplete and soon to be abandoned.

Let's start with the positives. Obviously this is the best looking Mortal Kombat game of the bunch, it looks stunning when things are working right and it really gives the feeling of a smooth flowing game. The characterization of (some) of the characters also adds a lot to them and makes them more memorable.

Now for the bad. This game basically released incomplete and even two years on it appears unfinished. Compared to MK11 there are

Fewer characters: MK11 released with 25 and ended with 37, while MK1 released with 23 and will be ending with 35. Removing third party characters leaves us with 32 and 29 respectively. MK1 also adds no new characters to the series.

Fewer customization options: MK11 featured 3 customizable item slots, a customizable skin slot, and the ability to change your characters special moves from a list or pick from a preset. MK1 now only features 1 item slot, the skin slot remains but on average has fewer/less diverse choices, and custom moves have been entirely done away with. Furthermore, MK11 showed you items you hadn't unlocked. MK1 no longer possesses this feature, and if it were active it would only reveal just how many items are now relegated to RNG from the shrine or in store purchases.

The krypt, crushing blows, and condition specific brutalities have been entirely done away with.

The kameo fighters system adds little to the game, at best it functions as the name implies, a cameo, while at worst it seems to be an excuse to reuse assets or barely pander to fans who have wanted certain characters to return. In the case of some of these characters, they've been unplayable since 2006. These characters replace one of your throws and half of your fatal blows are taken up by them, though they do have their own brutalities and fatalities that are at the very least deserving of mention. As a feature they can extend or start combos, act as ambushes, or set traps. However this relies on the kameo button which, as will be brought up, has a tendency to eat your inputs (even making a sound when activated) and then not doing anything.

Two years in and this game is horrifically optimized for PC. For context, my machine is capable of running Cyberpunk 2077 with maximum graphics settings and maintain a constant 60+fps. I had to use a third party application to set the best settings for MK1 because the default settings and the recommended ones provided by the game's own system were extremely laggy, sometimes taking multiple minutes to open up a single player match from the main menu and with the screen frequently artifacting. Even now after character intro lines I get to watch them have a staring contest for about 30 seconds before the fight actually starts, and these are in offline battles. Combo inputs are frequently eaten, they will even appear in the practice mode's input showcase without actually going through. This has made some character combos actually impossible (at least in my case) for a controller that is supposedly fully supported. (This is via wired connection on a controller that has little or no input lag in any other game).

I made the mistake of pre-ordering the premium edition of the game. Within days of release my game (a supposedly "premium" edition) was invalidated by the introduction of overpriced, exclusive, limited time skins and fatalities that were then quickly made no longer available for purchase again. A pumpkin head fatality was released and was going for 10-12 dollars, up to 24% the price of the base game's current cost. The team behind this didn't learn from it, and the Khaos Reigns expansion is now the same price as the base game. To no one's shock but the management apparently, selling what should be a 15 dollar dlc with 6 characters and a story add on for the price of a full game didn't sell well. As a result, there are several leaks and reveals that netherrealm studios will soon be dropping support of the game they said would be their longest supported service.

People were scammed, people were lied to. Many (me among them) have tried to get refunds for what is still 2 years on an unfinished and broken mess of a project that's all polish and no substance. 

(Oh and a note to the marketing team: selling a "bundle" that is theoretically cheaper than buying items individually and not allowing you to actually purchase one of said items on it's own is legally dubious and constitutes a scam. You might wanna get on that.)

Let's be honest. 

When I first saw the game, I was like? What is this?! The  character design, the concept, the weirdest  new design of Scorpion and sub-zero.

I bought the game a year after its release. First of all i had to change my mindest that this was completely different from previous Mortal Kombat games. After doing this and taking a new perspective  i was able to start playing it and I was able to form a relatively summary opinion.

The character designs are good, the story is good, the combat mechanics were strange at first but easy to get used to. I like that old characters were bought back. The character skills design are good and the combos are too. I think the Khaos Reigns DLC story turned out fantastic, compared to MK11 Aftermath, It's much more inventive.

BUT!

I think the price of the Khaos Reigns DLC is a bit high. The guest characters.... expect for Ghost face, I think they are unnecessary. The fact that Cyrax and Sektor became women was a bit strange at first and many people think this.

All in all. I think players need to completely distance themeselves from previous Mortal Kombat games and treat Mortal Kombat 1 as something completely new. if they succeed, it could be an enjoyable game for anyone.

Mortal Kombat 1 is a fantastic reboot of the iconic fighting game series. The new Kameo system adds depth to the gameplay, and the improved combat mechanics make fights more dynamic. The story mode is engaging, with impressive next-gen visuals and gory fatalities. However, the online mode is a bit lacking, and the presence of microtransactions can be a drawback. Overall, it's a must-play for fans of the franchise.

### Review of Mortal Kombat 1

**Mortal Kombat 1** came as a pleasant surprise, proving that the series hasn‚Äôt lost its edge even after all these years. The developers managed to preserve the brutal dynamics fans love while introducing fresh features that make the game relevant for today‚Äôs audience.

**Gameplay** remains true to its roots: hardcore combat, spectacular combos, and bloody fatalities. At the same time, the new Kameo character system brings a fresh twist, allowing players to experiment with strategy. This innovation seamlessly fits into the overall style of the game without undermining its core principles.

**The story** is unexpectedly engaging. The reboot offers a fresh perspective on familiar characters while maintaining the signature drama and epic scale that Mortal Kombat is known for.

**Graphics** are impressive: every fight, arena, and character is meticulously detailed. Fatalities remain as inventive as ever, solidifying their status as the franchise's hallmark.

Minor drawbacks, such as a somewhat unfair monetization model in places, don‚Äôt detract from the overall enjoyment of the game.

### Score: 8.5/10  
Mortal Kombat 1 retains its key strengths, proving that the series is still in top form. It‚Äôs an excellent continuation of the legendary franchise.

Best Fighting Game Ever!

Pros:
         - Best Base Roster since MK9
         - Kameos being a unique way to familiarize newer fans with more 3D & obscure characters
         - The return of Animality (Last seen in MK3)
         - Good Visuals/Graphics
         - Invasions Mode's mini games & arcade styled cinematics
         - Seasonal Fatalities
         - Air Kombat 

Cons: 
          - Megan Fox
          - Dominic Cianciolo is a terrible writer (Story-wise, franchise has been flopping since the MKX game)
          - Limited character customization
          - Overpriced DLC/Skins
          - Guest Characters shouldn't take up half a Kombat Pack, in a trend where fans are left to argue & debate which of their favorite characters should instead return for the other 3 DLC slots. 

Overall, I recommend MK1. The Kameo system is a bit odd at first glance, but ultimately feels like a universal variation system that helps keep you invested in your main fighter. Personally, the main thing NRS did right was finally listen to their 3D era fanbase. It's awesome seeing the likes of Reiko, Ashrah, Li Mei, Nitara & Havik return after 17 years of their absence in the mainline titles!

I personally like this entry to the point I bought this game two times. Is it the best MK game? Not under many aspects, but gameplay wise it is definitely my favorite out of the 4 (or better yet, three since MK9 is no longer available) both to play casually and watch on a competitive level. 

Story: 6/10.

For being set in a new universe, a new timeline, a change for most of the characters origins story are expected so the devs tried to introduce new players to a new setting, however old fans like me might not like most of the characters backstories. Unfortunately, the story is also a rushed mess and most things just happen for the sake of it. There are some good things but unfortunately they don't hold a candle to all the flaws it has such as making some characters disappear for no reason at all or, in the case of the story expansion, do things that lead to nothing and finish with a massive plothole. I already forgot most things about the story, something that unfortunately even MK11 suffered from personally.

Graphics: 10/10

Simply beautiful, models look great. Not much to be said other than everything looking great, from the details of the stages to the likeness of the characters. I literally jumped when I saw Van Damme and Skeet Ulrich!

Gameplay 8-9/10

I am stuck between giving this game an 8 or a 9 because I genuinely enjoy it, however the Kameo mechanic is something not everyone likes and in this game, that is a core mechanic. If we were given a chance to play solo (possible with mods) or add tag team it would get a much higher vote.

Sound 9/10

The soundtrack is amazing, especially the Khaos Reigns stages which sorta give DOOM vibes, voice acting is great... Save for the voice acting of THAT character, but I hope mods will fix that in the future lol

Mods: 9/10

The game has a lot of support from the community since day 1, some mods are actually cool ranging from old school announcers, to skins for characters and kameos, Camera mods (my personal favorite) and many others. Definitely the main reason why I picked this game a second time

DLCs: 7/10

Unfortunately this is where MK1 sorta fails. I am giving it a 7 mainly because some characters are fun to play as but most either don't fit MK1's setting or they have been nerfed to the ground to the point not many play them.
First of all, my main complaint is about Kombat Pack 1, most specifically Quan Chi and Ermac: Are they cool? Absolutely. But do they deserve to be DLC? Absolutely not. They were in the story, they were fightable too, and worst of all, in the past someone leaked the select screen which included them both as part of the base roster, only to be used as a cash grab for a DLC pack. I think they shouldn't have been there. Takeda is the only exception to the rule where he is just great. Peacemaker turned from being strong to not being used by anyone, and this is also the game where Homelander bodies Omni-Man lol. The second pack has pretty interesting characters but honestly Ghostface is the only one that stands among them as well as Noob Saibot. 

Microtransactions: 3/10

This game has a lot of them, from crystals which are needed to buy skins, from skins themselves, announcers and gears for some characters, except that some may be deceiving as they sell stuff that can be unlocked in game if you're patient enough. The last straw was the Seasonal Fatalities which if I am not wrong costed around 1000 crystals or so, fortunately they didn't repeat that as of now, but that's just typical WB stuff.

Overall... I'd give the game an 8/10 because I genuinely enjoy it.

Also, give me Konquest and get rid of Invasion mode, that thing is so boring.

Not very happy with this game, story mode was fun while it lasted but as a casual player online servers are poor and invasions is unbalanced and full of slop. Aside from final boss rewards, skins/palettes/gear available in invasions store & earned in invasions mode also often look awful and aren't effective motivators to play. I have only ever reached the final boss twice and both times were a gruelling slog & hurt me psychologically. Reward skins look amazing but definitely not worth the time invested and i did not have fun doing it.

While this is one of the most visually gorgeous games i've ever played (when running on my pc), I prefer to game on steam deck where it eeks out maybe 35-40 fps tops with FSR on performance profile & lowest settings which looks blurry and a little bit plastic. MK11 performed much better on deck, while backgrounds are definitely less detailed than MK1, MK11 hits 60fps at (iirc, either high or i think) highest settings without upscaling, which hints that MK1 is poorly optimised.

This game is also a 100+ gb download and i haven't played it in a few months because it takes a full day to download. Keeping my system on all day during my day off just to download one game instead of playing anything is dumb as hell, and chokes the bandwidth for my whole household. I've uninstalled the game and don't intend on installing it back at any point.

At full price, I couldn't recommend this game less. Don't buy it full price. If you're not already a Mortal Kombat fan, maybe don't buy it period.

Mortal Kombat 1 reboots the series, offering nostalgic experiences for longtime fans while introducing modern mechanics to attract new players. The visuals are stunning, with detailed character models and environment designs. The dynamic combat and the grandeur of the Fatality animations make the series more impressive than ever.
The gameplay retains the classic Mortal Kombat feel while adding variety through innovations like the Kameo Fighters system. These new mechanics enhance both strategy and fun. The story mode stands out with its cinematic narrative and fresh reimagining. However, as a Scorpion fan, I would have preferred Hanzo Hasashi to remain in the role instead of Kuai Liang. Hopefully, Hanzo and Rin will reunite in the next game.
Instead of the Invasions mode, bringing back the classic Krypt system from previous games would have made the experience more enjoyable. Mortal Kombat 11‚Äôs Krypt, in particular, was my favorite for its rewarding system and the chance to explore fighting arenas. Additionally, a nostalgic mini-game like Motor Kombat from Mortal Kombat: Armageddon would have been a fantastic addition to the game.
In conclusion, Mortal Kombat 1 excels in visuals, gameplay, and storytelling. Despite some minor shortcomings, it offers a fantastic experience for those seeking a modern take on the series‚Äô classic roots.

[h1]MORTAL KOMBAT 1 ‚Äì A FRESH START FOR NEW AND OLD FIGHTERS[/h1]

[h2]OVERVIEW:[/h2]
As someone new to the Mortal Kombat series, jumping into MK1 felt like the perfect gateway. The reboot not only welcomed me with open arms but also made me curious enough to catch up on the iconic legacy of the franchise. It‚Äôs clear this game was designed to bridge the gap between veterans and newcomers, and honestly, it does a phenomenal job.

[h2]CATEGORY RATINGS:[/h2]

[table]
[tr][th]Category[/th][th]Rating[/th][th]Comments[/th][/tr]
[tr][td]Graphics[/td][td]‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ[/td][td]Incredible visuals with lifelike character designs, vibrant environments, and jaw-dropping fatalities.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Storyline[/td][td]‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ[/td][td]A fresh reboot that balances accessibility for newcomers while paying homage to the original lore.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Gameplay[/td][td]‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ[/td][td]Smooth, accessible mechanics with depth for veterans. Kameo Fighters add a unique twist.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Multiplayer[/td][td]‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ[/td][td]Exciting and competitive, though occasional lag can disrupt the experience.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Replayability[/td][td]‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ[/td][td]A wealth of modes, characters, and challenges ensure endless fun and mastery opportunities.[/td][/tr]
[/table]

[h2]THE BREAKDOWN:[/h2]

Graphics and Presentation:
MK1‚Äôs graphics are absolutely stunning. From the hyper-realistic character models to the intricately detailed arenas, it‚Äôs a visual treat. The lighting, particle effects, and sheer creativity in fatalities elevate the game‚Äôs cinematic feel.

Storyline and Reboot:
The story mode strikes a great balance between welcoming new players and winking at long-time fans. It‚Äôs a bold retelling of classic events, with a fresh spin that made it easy for me to connect with the characters‚Äîeven if I didn‚Äôt know every detail of the original timeline.

Gameplay Mechanics:
This is where MK1 truly shines. The combat system feels tight and rewarding. As a newcomer, I appreciated how intuitive the controls are, but I can see how veterans would love mastering advanced combos. The addition of Kameo Fighters brings an extra layer of strategy, keeping the gameplay dynamic.

Multiplayer Experience:
Online matches are fast-paced and exhilarating. The competition is tough but rewarding, especially when you pull off a killer combo. Some lag issues pop up here and there, but overall, the experience is solid.

Replayability:
From unlocking Fatalities and cosmetics to mastering every character, the grind never feels repetitive. Add in multiplayer, arcade towers, and new DLCs on the horizon, and MK1 has plenty to keep players coming back for more.

[h2]FINAL THOUGHTS:[/h2]
Mortal Kombat 1 has been an incredible introduction to the franchise for me. The rebooted story gave me a chance to jump in without feeling overwhelmed, and the gameplay is a perfect mix of approachable and challenging. Whether you‚Äôre an old-school fan or new like me, MK1 delivers a knockout experience.

Highly Recommended!
too much money for not enough gameplay

This game is incredibly fun, I've found myself playing this game nonstop for hours before and I'm sure I will again, the characters and the gameplay are really entertaining, and the events keep me coming back to this game, but there are just too many issues for me to give it a positive rating as of now, some of the problems in this game just make it unbearable to play at times and honestly kill the vibe whenever I feel like playing. 

The main problem that most people have with this game, including myself, are the micro-transactions which are just waaaay too expensive. Like why do I gotta spend 30 real dollars to give sub-zero a different coloured shirt?

The optimisation on this game is also just awful, majority of the time I play this game it just runs terribly even when the graphics are on lower settings, even on some really good machines it will still run poorly.

And the main problem I have with this game is that every single update this game gets forces me to completely reinstall the entire game, it's not a problem with my computer nor is it a problem with steam. It just gets incredibly annoying to have to redownload over 100 GB of a game that runs like a powerpoint presentation.

If you're willing to put these issues aside and you want to play a good fighting game, I'd say give Mortal Kombat 1 a try, it is an amazing game but it just sucks that there are so many issues holding the ratings down.

Also, compared to MK11, MK1 feels often repetitive due to it's lack of variety in it's characters intros and outros. the Kameo system is just...not balanced, 90% of the best kameos are locked behind a paywall and it's not fun to take 50% damage off getting clipped by a random low or overhead, cause at that point the game just becomes a snowball fest of who has the faster mixup and further reach and it's just annoying, the gameplay is slow and clunky, the kameo system makes it so there's usually 5 characters who are broken and then the rest of the roster is too terrible to win against them, and pretty much all of the soul of mk is removed from this game, the designs are boring, the stages save for a few are cookie cutter and also boring, the lore is too focused on realism, but also somehow time travel (two contradicting things btw) to be interesting so both story modes are poorly written snoozefests, this 70 DOLLAR GAME with a 50 DOLLAR DLC has a cash shop and paid currency which is the only way to get the actually GOOD and ICONIC designs, so now you have to throw upwards of 10 to 100 dollars if you're someone who for example loves all the MKDA skins because most skins save for the UMK3 ones are 10 dollars, iconic and beloved characters got either backseated or completely ignored entirely and not added period, or just outright bastardized (kuai liang being scorpion for example so now hanzo is basically a jobber, the beloved poster boy with years of lore and the most hardcore and die hard fanbase on the roster just got shelved and basically cucked by the guy who's supposed to be sub zero, let that sink in.) Liu Kang being ruined in lore and in gameplay, i mained liu kang since mk9 and i refuse to play him in this game because they made him so boring. basically all of mk's soul and identity just died with this game, all for the sake of that corny ass "new era" bs they're trying to push to us when nobody asked you to change this series in the first place because we loved it as is and we have for decades now, but it is what it is, another franchise i grew up with and loved being ruined by censorship, unnecessary rewrites and greed. it makes me so sad with this one though because my love for mk runs so deep i tried SO hard to force myself to like this game, but it's just not the series i once loved, i miss the old MK. Straight from the go MK. chop up the soul MK. set on his goals MK.

there's a lot that caused this game to suck, but to really break it down for you, i will now open up with point 1: the retcons and now turned awful lore

MK9 and MKX are simple to follow, the same cannot be said for the rest of the series, mk9 introduced multiverses into the story, yes, but this game and mk11 overdid it trying to follow that marvel hype and completely convoluted any sense of a story that Mortal Kombat had left, mk11 had you fight kronika, basically a glorified thanos for control over the realms and time itself, not only does she barely have a character so she's really uninteresting, but if that wasn't bad enough, you now have liu kang fighting dark liu kang while jax fights the future jax who is actually present jax and the jax fighting him is past jax (essentially mirrors between the same character, but apparently from different timeline where the only difference is everyone is dead and evil) and the whole "ending" of it gets thrown out the window for the aftermath dlc, which makes it even worse because the aftermath dlc in mk11 makes the rest of whatever lore mk had left even worse because sindel and shao kahn got retconned to be together thus completely rendering all the other lore she had useless all to force a corny romance plot in the middle of a crisis that could LITERALLY END THE UNIVERSE, but that's just mk11, that's the tip of the iceberg, mk1 releases and undoes everything that was already undone all for a "new era" thus throwing everything in mk11 out the window as well, kuai liang is now scorpion (literally why did anyone think turning hanzo into a jobber was a good idea?)  sub zero is back to being bi han, who is evil and only evil, he has no other personality traits, smoke is an errand boy now and sporting the worst design he's ever had, etc. but if you thought "oh maybe they reset the timeline again to fix the lore issues introduced in mk11" you would be wrong, mk1 throws i think the worst curveball i've ever seen in gaming by confirming that ALL the mk lore is canon because ALL the timelines are real, including the mk11 one we just painted over because mk11 kitana walks out of a portal to another universe to help liu kang at the end of the game, wow what a moment i sure hope this doesn't have dire consequences later.


now onto point 2: the story and  DLC

"Mortal Kombat 1 Khaos Reigns" released and everyone was optimistic this update and dlc would save the game, little did they know it would be what killed it,  the story somehow gets even WORSE in the dlc, similar to how it did with aftermath, Khaos Reigns is all about making Havik so one dimensional i thought the only word he knew was "khaos khaos khaos" because that's all he ever says, no explaining of his plan, no deeper villain origin, just "i hate all of you die" and that's it. this dlc makes the timeline thing even more confusing, because apparently this is another evil timeline but not the same evil timeline from mk11, it's an even eviler timeline where nothing else happens but evil, that's it. the whole timeline is fanservice where you see different styles of different characters and different clones or combinations of characters, with absolutely zero substance outside of looking goofy and making every fight in the dlc boring because it's just clones of the same characters we've already fought, and then you get to the finale of the dlc, noob saibot is here, except it's less shocking because bi han was already so evil that basically nothing changed, but somehow they make him cooperate and together they all beat havik, the end, roll credits on a snoozefest with as much depth as a puddle, and then they ask you to buy EVEN MORE microtransactions after you just paid 50 dollars for the worst dlc in fgc history, congrats from Ed Boon, u just got fucking scammed.



now onto point 3: the design

mortal kombat peaked mk9 and mkx and then Netherrealm proceeded to never make games as good as those two again, another example of something i love being ruined by corporate greed and unnecessary changes, we now live in an era where street fighter and kof are more explicit than mk (in design obviously, they don't do the gore and all that) and mk's entire brand for 20 years was literally being as hyper-risque and hyper violent as humanly possible and now ed boon just got on twitter and said these designs were "unrealistic" but motherfuckers in mk1 liteally survive having their hearts ripped out in fatal blows and fight in heels, i'm not saying this was a requirement to make a good mk game, cause i know that's gonna make me sound crazy, but the difference here is even if these designs were a bit overboard/sexualized, they had FAR more personality than anything in mk11 or mk1, they don't have to have fan-service, just give them personality again, all these characters look too normal now in comparison to how cool they were, some characters who i wouldn't even call problematic (like jax) got his design ruined so bad he's basically a different guy every game, but they built a horror-risque aesthetic and then they essentially gentrified and ruined all the designs randomly and massively slowed down the gameplay and added multiverses into the story trying to appeal to a crowd that never liked or played mk in the first place, so now you shot yourselves in the foot because half your core fanbase is leaving and all the casuals had their fun with the game and are done with it now so you have nothing left, return this series to it's roots of being hyper explicit and unapologetic about it, that is what EVERYONE loves about this series before you ruined it, stop trying to make this series "safe" and "realistic"

Spoilers here!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The short.
For starters this game is overpriced. For the future Komplete edition, it better be 70 AT MOST for both stories and all characters unlocked with some stones to spend on cosmetics on top of that. If its all on sale and youre here for the nostalgia like me, go for it. The content just lacks here for me. And micro transactions really dropped the love even more for me...

The good!

The graphics and customization is great! I love the time you have to put in on a fighter to get pieces and make it your own style. Its a good move to reward hard work and time put in. The top player rewards is another great way to keep the community involved toward a goal of competition for all players. The story has a new direction which allows more diverse thoughts and ideas. But a little too familiar this time. I hope in the future, they look at Deception or Armageddon story and branch out some more. As a die hard fan. Of course they have my money every year to show my support since I appreciate the universe growing up with it.

The Bad (IMO)

Ive loved Mortal Kombat my entire life and have dedicated alot of my younger years to learning combos and loved the stories of Deception, and the idea of Armageddon. I explored every nook and cranny for hidden skins or fighters like the Noob/Smoke fight in deception. Here they have implied the most basic ideas from both and COMPLETELY disregarded the love that went into those games. The story of Shujinko really was unique. And this story felt completely reused, using the hourglass as an excuse to redo the tournament again. Nearly the same exact idea with Raiden's Amulet previously. I really want to pay for the Chaos Reigns but havent since I heard how short it really was with lack of content for the price.

 MK9 had the 2v2 fighter mode which TRUMPS over kameo's here. Fight me, the kameo idea is nowhere near as good. They could have added 2v2 online instead. Fight with your friend against 2 other players. 

All previous games had a Crypt and they completely removed it and got lazy. Making a bowl to melt your gold in. I miss the secrets, the easter eggs and the exploration. Whoever made the call to not put time in here is a bum. Yet another missed mark for exploration and dedication Netherrealm used to give the fans.

The servers for towers of time are terrible. I get removed to main menu after getting close to the top of a 7+ fight tower with hard modifiers and  it is extremely frustrating. Im not sure what to do about this...

 Im sure everyone is tired of the mention of Micro-Transactions. But all my mains were blocked behind a paywall this year. Characters that have been part of the universe for so long. Guest characters I understand, but characters in the story that already had a move set built like Quan Chi and Shang Sung is really low. Characters in the older mk9 were 2.99 ea. They doubled that price. Kinda allows Pay to Win with kameos too since Movado is probably has best support set that you have to pay to have an easier and higher win rate. Not complaining here, but most players wont have that access, 

Cosmetics, sure. Original characters, no.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I'm gonna give this game an true and honest review only based on my opinions on the game, so take whatever I say with a grain of salt. 

I can say that I enjoy playing this game. It has a decent balanced pace in matches where it's not all about speed and combos or just zoning. The game has some unique mechanics that make it stand out from other Mortal Kombat games like:

Up blocking: this mechanic allows you to gain a frame advantage if you block an over head with an up block, not a standard standing block.

Super jump/jump cancel: essentially if you punish your opponents attack with an upper cut you can cancel the upper cut's end lag with a jump allowing for combos.

Kameo assist: you get the option to choose an off hand character that acts as an assist that can allow for some pretty crazy plays or extend combos or add pressure in ways that the base fighter can't do on their own. Alot of people do complain about this system cause it kills the possiblity of some popular characters to return as full fledged fighters, but I think it's a nice since it gives some characters the opportunity to return wether or not they're lamped or standard fighter. 

The game also has its negatives like having alot of expensive micro transactions because.......Warner Bros. of course. And I also don't like the mechanic with the grabs where you have to guess between two buttons to count grab cause it changes depending on the type of grab. I think it's a stupid mechanic cause if you succeed in predicting a grab but you press the wrong button you're essentially getting punished for countering. 

The campaign was a bit disappointing to say the least. I expected more out of it and I was pretty sad to see how it ended up. The games secondary game mode is a bit boring and repetitive with little reward so there's no point in playing it. 

I'd say the game is not beginner friendly at all due to the somewhat complex play style and abundance of characters to learn and also the additional assist characters that add a whole new layer of complexity. The game can be buggy sometimes but otherwise it's a good looking game. 

Sadly, I dont recommend this game to someone who doesn't have the money to spend on it or has any formal experience in fighting games.

I can't recommend this game due to the nonstop screen flickering. However, I did get it to work fine by changing some Nvidia control panel settings. 

Open the NVIDIA Control Panel
Select the "Manage 3D Settings" option
Click on the "Program Settings" tab
Go under the "Select a program to customize" section
Find or add Mortal Kombat 1 to the list
Change the "Max Frame Rate" to 60 FPS
Turn on the "Vertical Sync" option
Change the "Power management mode" to "Prefer maximum performance"
anti aliasing - FXAA on
antialiasing - transparency 8x
triple buffering - on
texture filtering - anisotropic sample optimization on
Press the "Apply" button

**Mortal Kombat 1 Review**

Mortal Kombat 1 delivers a fantastic experience that brilliantly builds on the legacy of its predecessors. The game takes everything fans loved about previous MK titles and dials it up, bringing a fresh spin to the brutal, visceral world of Mortal Kombat. From the graphics to the mechanics, it‚Äôs clear the developers have poured their hearts into capturing the intense energy MK is known for, while also introducing enough new elements to keep both longtime fans and newcomers hooked.

The fatalities in MK 1 are jaw-dropping, and they showcase some of the most creative, gory sequences the series has ever seen. They‚Äôre relentless, gruesome, and perfectly choreographed to keep players engaged and horrified in all the best ways. While another fatality or two would have been welcome to add more variety, the ones here are absolutely top-notch, pushing boundaries with every gruesome detail.

Overall, Mortal Kombat 1 is a *geektastic* game that captures the legacy of Mortal Kombat and drives it forward with passion and excitement. The fights are fluid, the fatalities are next-level gore, and the gameplay is refined and addictive. If you‚Äôre a fan of the franchise, this is a must-play‚Äîand if you‚Äôre new to MK, there‚Äôs no better place to jump in.

Mortal Kombat 1 Review: A Bold Return to the Roots with a New Twist

Mortal Kombat 1 brings the iconic franchise back to its roots while adding fresh and exciting elements to the formula. With its return to the beginning of the MK storyline, players experience a reimagined universe where beloved characters have new roles, alliances, and personalities. NetherRealm Studios has skillfully woven an alternate narrative that feels familiar yet refreshingly unpredictable, making it a must-play for fans and newcomers alike.

Story and Characters

The narrative reboot offers a fascinating reintroduction to iconic characters like Liu Kang, Raiden, Scorpion, and Sub-Zero, but with altered backgrounds and relationships. The plot is filled with twists that keep you engaged, with new alliances and rivalries changing the dynamics between these beloved characters. Liu Kang, now a god responsible for this new timeline, serves as a powerful central figure, guiding the player through a world that‚Äôs both nostalgic and unexpected.

Gameplay and Mechanics

The gameplay in Mortal Kombat 1 has been streamlined but remains brutal and deeply satisfying. Familiar mechanics such as combos, Fatalities, and brutal finishers are still there, yet the game introduces the new ‚ÄúKameo‚Äù system, which lets you summon iconic characters to assist in battle, adding a layer of strategy. Kameo assists add exciting possibilities for chaining combos and give players more control over the pacing of the fight.

NetherRealm has also refined the controls to make moves feel smooth and responsive, making it approachable for new players while still offering depth for veterans. The game rewards skill, timing, and creativity with endless options for devastating combos and over-the-top special moves.

Visuals and Audio

Visually, Mortal Kombat 1 is stunning. The graphics are sharper than ever, with highly detailed character models, dynamic stages, and impressive lighting effects that bring the world to life. The gore and violence are still as intense as you‚Äôd expect, but the presentation is more polished, delivering one of the best-looking games in the franchise‚Äôs history.

The soundtrack and sound design complement the visuals perfectly. Punches, kicks, and Fatalities sound visceral, enhancing the immersive feel of the combat. Voice acting also stands out, bringing personality and depth to each character and grounding the outlandish storylines in believable emotions and motivations.

Modes and Replayability

Mortal Kombat 1 offers multiple game modes to keep players engaged, from the story mode to online multiplayer and the classic Towers. The addition of the Kameo system and the variety of characters also give players a reason to keep experimenting with different combinations, adding a layer of replayability that keeps the experience fresh.

The game does have a few minor setbacks, mainly in the online matchmaking, which could benefit from more robust options and faster load times. However, these issues don‚Äôt detract significantly from the overall experience.

Final Verdict

Mortal Kombat 1 is a triumphant return for the franchise, delivering an exciting reboot with enough fresh content to feel innovative without straying too far from its roots. Whether you‚Äôre a die-hard fan or a newcomer, Mortal Kombat 1 delivers intense, cinematic, and brutally fun gameplay that will keep you coming back for more. NetherRealm has managed to honor the legacy of Mortal Kombat while successfully forging a new path, making this a title that‚Äôs worthy of the franchise‚Äôs legendary name.

I'm a bit conflicted about this game.
I don't regret buying it (it IS a good game and was also on discount) but it has some flaws its' predecessor didn't.

I REALLY like some of the new stuff (the new takes on classic characters, letting you explore Johnny Cage's house, etc) and some of the stuff they brought back as well (mini-games and characters like Havik and Ermac).
A few other things are ok but nothing I would miss (characters like Reiko or Li Mei and basically the whole "Invasions" mode once you leave Cage's house).
The graphics have improved enough on a technical level that players going back to MK11 again should at least notice a difference (if you value graphics over gameplay, the newer game is superior).


However, the game's biggest problem (aside from its' price) is all the stuff they removed.

First of all, the customization is very limited compared to the last game. You can get new skins, but not choose special attacks and there's only one type of gear for each character.

I've gotten so used to mechanics like stage interactions and Mercy that it feels like missing a limb. Also, keeping the "change stance" button is a strange design choice, now that it has no practical use outside of certain mini-games.

The Kameo Fighter system is basically just tag-team assist without being able to switch to the other character. This gives you a whole additional roster of characters you can't actually play as.

The "Invasions" mode has you traversing the worlds in a board game style more similar to the map in Super Mario than MK11's Krypt, which gave you full freedom of movement.


And then there's the pricing...

The standard edition of the game has a story mode that takes a few hours and I heard the DLC (which is priced similar to a full-length game, even at a discount) is shorter. After playing the game 3 times or so, I've completed 38% of the achievements without even going for it. I don't see myself spending hours in Invasion mode the way I did in MK11's Krypt and just choosing a skin and a single piece of gear isn't the same as combining different skins, multiple gear and special attacks.

The fact that several DLC characters are present in locked form on the selection screen implies that this is not really the "full" game you're playing, yet it's not called "MK1 light" or anything (My title screen actually claims that I'm playing "Khaos Reigns", despite not having the DLC).

The fact that they recently started putting advertising for this game inside the previous game, along with the temporary discount, suggests that maybe they should have lowered the price to begin with, or included more content in the base game to justify the price.


If you're a fan of the series, you definitely want to check this one out. If you're rich enough to not care about money, you might wanna grab the full edition just to get those extra characters and see what happens next in the story.

It's good on sale. All the extra features and gimmicks beyond campaign and arcade modes are not welcome -- and also don't make sense to me given the title "Mortal Kombat 1" suggests a return to form. I'm not sure if it's paywalled or progression limited or what -- but only 1 fatality per fighter along with an animality that often seems to have nothing to do with the character is not acceptable. I want 3 fatalities, a related animality, a friendship, and some variations in the brutalities out of the box. 

Unlike other reviewers I thought the campaign was fun an engaging. I find it odd that finishing moves are never available in the story, but that's not a big deal. The tutorial and variations are great. 

So many odd choices. What's up with the mansion? That's a half-baked mode. Why are all these weird progression RPG elements (talisman, upgrades, skins, etc) even here? Why are there so many different kinds of in-game currency? I mean I know the answer - it's to try to squeeze money out of diehard MK fans, but the casual player is just left scratching their heads trying to figure out an experience that completely lacks cohesion.

this seems to me to be a pretty big improvement on MK11 (which felt horrible to play after the lightning quick genius of MKX). so that's a great start, but unless there's a *radical* shakeup in the way these giant brands do business with us the consumer, this is still just improvements on a dying boat. lemme tell you how this one sank to new lows for me.

I've got this sort of gaming OCD about notification about new content. these new games keep dropping with hundreds and hundreds of small cosmetics to unlock, and this one's especially bold in how annoying its notification is -- it's a big yellow golden* mark, just like that. it seems that size to the main menu lettering, the notification that you've got some unseen unlocks. and this is all for a reason, this sort of thing doesn't happen by accident.

I unlocked some new scarf or pair of shoelaces or whatever for a character I don't own (and don't plan on ever owning), and I wanted to just get rid* of the notification* that there was unseen crap to be seen and then forgotten about. so I tried to access the character's cosmetic menu (you have to do each one per character select - it's obnoxious as HELL), only it's not a character SELECT for a character you don't own, it changes to Character PURCHASE. takes you straight to a loading online link to buy their overpriced, likely AI-voiced characters. so I can't seem to GET AT the character or its kosmetics unless I buy it. so I've got* a notification* symbol always on my main* menu* that I can't turn off ... until I buy the character. the menu is designed to wreck havoc on itself untill you buy everything they tell you to.

this is bad, bad business. I know they think they're smrt, I know they think they've got it solved, but they haven't. the common, casual dialogue on MTX had turned from annoyed into nearly revolutionary by 2023. and they're planning on trying to wring the last couple thousand bucks they can out of this whole embarrassing shambles. their Mortal Kombat franchise has had its sales cut into a fraction of what it used to sell. I wonder why that is?

just one more thing and then I'll go play MKX or something and scrub this from my brain if I can. (gameplay is much improved, but what does that matter when playing the thing makes you want to take an acid bath afterwards to get the WB stink off? what's it all worth, all this greedy filth?) so they've got their own Street Fighter lame MTX Fighter Koin system, where the stuff you do just casually in game nets you koins for a sort of slot machine to RNG your way to cosmetiks you'd actually use, and I 'cashed' 5,000 of those for a pair of hand wraps and some kosmetik I kouldn't use bekause it's for a karacter I don't own. THAT'S what we're dealing with - you have a strong RNG chance on earning gear you can't even use. unless you buy their overpriced character DLC.

it's just ... buck this. why do they DO this to themselves? seems to me AAA Gaming was doing amazingly well for a decade or so there - from PS2 until the end of PS4. and during that time I guess they found out  they COULD get away with Ubisoft's taktics, they COULD stooge their costumer and they'd keep coming back. well now they don't seem to be doing that anymore, because the customers are realizing they don't NEED the AAA drip anymore. there are much more passionate developers making much more interesting games for either as much or even less money. and MK1, though I like it way better than MK11, is like the perfect storm of making the costumer, who always used to be right, feel like total spit just for buying the base game. 

if you've got a great tolerance for corporate backwash practices (or you're wealthy and can afford everything trhe game's gonna keep throwing at you until the next one comes out), I recommend this game. it's decent. it's not anywhere as good as SF6, but if you're into Mortal Kombat...? the gameplay on this one is better than I've seen people give it credit for. but seriously, probably just get X. that's the best one anyway. be well. we're getting there.

Mortal Kombat 1 is hands down the best fighting game I‚Äôve ever played‚Äîand that‚Äôs coming from someone who used to think blocking was optional. I only got into it because my friend begged me. Like, full-on ‚Äúplease just try it once‚Äù energy. I didn‚Äôt even own the game, so he had to Remote Play me like I was some kind of digital freeloader in the laggy corner of the internet.

At first? I hated it. I don‚Äôt like Tekken. I don‚Äôt like Street Fighter. I barely even like tutorials. But something about MK1 just clicked‚Äîmaybe it was the satisfying crunch of ribs shattering in slow motion. Maybe it was the blood. Maybe I‚Äôve got unresolved issues. Who knows.

Now? I‚Äôm a full-blown MK disciple. I finished the main story like I was watching an epic action movie that someone handed me the remote for. I‚Äôve become that guy‚Äîpreaching Mortal Kombat to strangers at bus stops like, ‚ÄúHave you accepted Liu Kang as your Lord and Savior?‚Äù

The game is brutal, clean, and weirdly beautiful. The animations are crisp, the story is wild in the best way, and the fatalities are so dramatic they make Shakespeare look like a children's book. One minute you‚Äôre uppercutting a dude into space, the next you‚Äôre getting stabbed 47 times by someone with a glowing spine.

And let‚Äôs talk real: Pro tip‚Äîdon‚Äôt get MK1 unless you‚Äôre grabbing the Khaos Reigns Kollection on sale. Because buying characters one by one at full price feels like you‚Äôre paying rent in Outworld. It‚Äôs pain. Emotional and financial.

My favorite part? The game turned me into a fighting game fan. Me. A guy who once lost to a CPU on Easy in Smash Bros. The pacing, the controls, the combos‚Äîit‚Äôs all super satisfying once you get into it. And when you land your first real Fatality? Oh man, it‚Äôs like your brain throws you a surprise party.

Update:
Okay, real talk‚ÄîI don‚Äôt love this game like I used to. I kinda fell out with it after realizing I‚Äôve learned every character, every ability, every trick in the book. At this point, it‚Äôs like being in a relationship where you know exactly how they‚Äôll react to everything. The excitement? Gone. The mystery? Dead. The gameplay? Still good, but let‚Äôs just say the spark isn‚Äôt sparking anymore.

Final verdict: 7/10.
