So, firstly, I will preface this with this will be an in-depth review of this game from someone who doesn't play it competitively. I'm a very casual player and only play online if it's with someone I'm already friends with. I really only play the single player Invasions mode. 

Speaking of, I've been playing the Invasions mode since season 2 and it has most definitely come a long way since then. They've improved upon it, trying to create new mini-games that are now optional which is fantastic. I'm not too big on all of them but thankfully you don't have to do them! I will say, when it comes to come of the mini-games, my game will just straight up crash. Sometimes I'll be able to play it once but if I try to retry if I fail it, I'll crash. That sucks and deters me from trying some of them, even when I'm interested in trying to complete it. Besides that, I really like the little type system for the characters. It's cute, but sometimes I wish there were more playable counters for some of the cast; it's not that big of deal, though. I'm really happy the developers made the decision to cut down on weaker color palette skins and made less skins that are really cool looking. Overall, Invasions is a lot better than how it used to be, but it could still get better.

The reason why I played this game in the first place is because of how good the game looked. As an artist, I absolutely adore all the work put into this game. The lighting and graphics of this game are unbelievable. Some of the shots or frames of characters just straight up look real. The art team did a phenomenal job with this game and I can tell the people working on it do care about it. Genuinely, all the artists involved with this game are so talented its insane. I have a camera mod because I love to go through the fatalities or character screens to get better closeups and the detail is insane. So much of this game is rendered and I can fully appreciate it with the camera mod. I can't get over the way the team was able to animate WRINKLES!!! How did they get the character models to squeeze and stretch like actual human skin?!?! UUUUGGH this game is so beautiful. With the mod, I'm able to look through each map environment and the detail makes me want to explode. I LOVE how pretty this game is I even love collecting the art work in this game and looking through the gallery here because it's all such great work. The story itself is fun but it feels a bit rushed towards the end, though that didn't really stop me from having a good time. Honestly, I could go on and on about how gorgeous this game is to me.

I feel like it's important to bring up the microtransactions this game suffers from. Now, I may be biased considering I was, unfortunately, hyperfixated on Overwatch and this game saved me from spending any more money on that godawful game. The microtransactions are not fun but they could by all means be worse. 5 dollars on a skin that comes with 5 other recolors doesn't sound that bad compared to 20 dollars for a skin on games like Overwatch or Fortnite or Valorant. The fact Shang Tsung has to be bought separately if you didn't preorder the game is scummy though. You even play as him in the story mode and he's treated as if he's not a DLC character, getting skins per season and having the same 35 levels as base game characters do. Also, 40 dollars for the DLC was crazy. Like, at first I hated it, but then I played through it and got a ton of cool skins (WWII Johnny <3<3<3) and the new character pack came with it so I didn't mind it as much. It's just......damn... my wallet...

To sum it up, I think the game is fun and very beautiful and I'm in love with Johnny Cage

Overall Thoughts
Mortal Kombat 1 revitalizes the iconic franchise with stunning graphics and intense gameplay. The visuals are spectacular, showcasing detailed character models and vibrant arenas that enhance the overall experience.

The gameplay is very good, combining classic mechanics with new features that keep battles engaging. It‚Äôs easy to learn for newcomers, but offers depth for players looking to refine their skills. The audio complements the action with solid sound effects and a fitting soundtrack.

The story is well-crafted, taking players on a thrilling journey through the Mortal Kombat universe, complete with memorable characters and engaging narrative arcs. The game runs smoothly on fast PCs, with only minor bugs that don‚Äôt detract from the fun.

With an acceptable price for the amount of content‚Äîoffering 20-30 hours for those seeking 100% completion‚ÄîMortal Kombat 1 is a must-play for fighting game enthusiasts. Overall, it earns a strong 9 out of 10 for its impressive visuals and captivating gameplay.

Mortal Kombat 1 is an absolute blast, and I‚Äôm really impressed with how they‚Äôve rebooted the series. Despite the usual money-grabbing practices we‚Äôve come to expect from WB Games, the game itself is a standout experience.

The gameplay feels incredibly smooth and satisfying, blending classic Mortal Kombat mechanics with fresh updates that keep the action engaging. The graphics are stunning, with crisp detail and fluid animations that bring the brutal combat to life. The roster is filled with badass characters, and the variety of skins and other cosmetics adds a fun layer of personalization for players.

The story mode deserves a special mention‚Äîit's ridiculously fun and over-the-top in the best way, perfectly capturing the chaotic energy that fans love about the franchise.

On the technical side, the game performs excellently on my setup: a Ryzen 9 7950X paired with a 3080 Ti. It runs flawlessly with gorgeous visuals and smooth performance. I‚Äôve also tested it on my Steam Deck, and I was pleasantly surprised. It looks and plays much better than the Mortal Kombat 11 Switch port (if you know, you know). While it doesn‚Äôt quite match the crispness of the PC version, the experience on Steam Deck is still solid, making it a great option for portable gaming.

Streaming the game from my PC to my Steam Deck and displaying it on a bigger TV via Ethernet has also been a fantastic experience‚Äîit runs beautifully and delivers the kind of smooth gameplay you‚Äôd expect from a high-end setup.

If you‚Äôre a fan of the Mortal Kombat series or fighting games in general, I highly recommend giving this one a shot. It‚Äôs a top-tier reboot that delivers on both nostalgia and innovation!

I have a very love/hate relationship with MK1. On one hand, it's an immensely fun fighter with great character variety, amazing visuals, fun combos, etc. All of that makes the game worth it imo... but the other shit makes me fucking despise this game with a firey passion. The overpriced DLC, I'm sorry to say, but I really, REALLY don't give a fuck if it's a new story expansion, $50 for the most mid story ever was criminal, the only reason why I bought it was cause of KP2 and the preorder skins for free. The kameo system, now I personally do like the kameo system, I think it adds a lot of combo potential with ALL characters and they ARE fun imo, but (for most of the game's life cycle), half the roster felt like they NEEDED kameos in order to make it out of F tier and the other half felt like they were ripped straight out of MKX without any fear in the world that they may need to use their kameo to help win the match. Gladly, they have seemed to fix this issue a bit, by making the characters better on the base roster, but it has taken WAY too long for it to be this way, it should've been near the beginning of the game, i.e. Season 1. The overpriced costumes, I fucking hate them. Gladly, we have a feature to earn dragon krystals now, but, FOR THE LONGEST FUCKING TIME, we were stuck with either leveling up characters with the XP bar moving slower than a fucking snail, or pay real money. Having $10 skins for a $70 game is criminal, but again, they fixed it now by making them... 5 bucks. I'm personally sick of the bad customization in the recent NRS games. It was great in IJ2, piss poor in MK11, and imo better in MK1, but the costumes THEMSELVES shouldn't ever reach the ball park of entering the double digits in terms of price. I keep bringing things up that WERE issues, but are NOW fixed, because I played the game day 1 on PS5, and had to wait for a year for the game to get ACTUALLY good, when it shouldn't have to be that way. WB, give NRS more time to develop their games so you mfs can earn more money for your coke parties and diddy brigades. Not giving your developers any time to make a game will mean it's rushed, which will make your product not worth playing, let alone buying. Now, I personally hope that this game doesn't get canceled, cause even through the ramblings of a mad man up there, I DO love MK1, but NRS just needs to be rid of WB so they can get back to making games without needing them to be out by THAT date or else. 
So, tl:dr
Buy the game when it's on a SUPER DUPER sale or don't buy it at all

If you like mortal kombat series you'll love this game. This game has most of the traditional characters in it plus a few new ones. They have added an adventure PvE mode to this game and they still have tower challenges. You earn game coins then you have fights in the game and they can be exchanged for cosmetics. There are some premium cosmetics that cost real money too. I think the premium cosmetics are reasonably priced; I don't buy a lot of the premium  cosmetics because the ones you can get for game coins are so nice. This is a nice game and I'm recommend the premium version to get all the goodies that go with the game but it's pricey, so you might want wait for the game to go on sale but it's a wonderful version of the game. I have not tried the new story DLC yet so I have no review for that but the original story that comes with the game is great. If you do buy the standar version of the game I'd consider at least buying Kombat Pack 1 to go with it: it greatly improves your enjoyment of the game to have more character unlocked to play with. If you are a mortal kombat fan, you'll love this game. It's well done!

Not a bad game, still hard to recommend

The game is good in terms of visuals, sound, fatalities and most importantly gameplay. It is the best MK you can play online right now, and it has a better roster than 11, X or even 9. The DLC characters like Noob, Sektor and Cyrax also gets you closest to the fun you probably had in X. 

But unfortunately there isnt a lot of content in the game if you really dont want to play MP for the moment. They included towers of time after a year, but that took way too long. And Invasions still sucks and will always suck. Also the character customization is a bit lacking. Theres no frequent updates either, if theres no DLC coming out the Devs unfortunately arent very open about whats going on

All in all i would still recommend it, simply because the gameplay and roster are awesome, but the game is not nearly  as good as it could be unfortunately

Mortal Kombat 1 is a bold reimagining of the iconic series, combining brutal combat with fresh storylines and stunning visuals. From the moment you start, the fluid animations and detailed environments draw you into a world where every punch, kick, and fatality feels satisfyingly impactful. The combat system strikes a great balance between accessibility for newcomers and depth for seasoned players, with plenty of room for skill development.

The story mode is a standout, providing an epic cinematic experience that rewrites classic Mortal Kombat lore in surprising and exciting ways. Familiar characters are given new life, and the alternate universe plot makes for some thrilling twists.

Kameo Fighters bring a really fun layer of strategy, adding another dimension to battles, but they don‚Äôt overshadow the core gameplay.

Overall, I felt MK1 delivers an amazing mix of nostalgia and innovation that will keep you hooked for hours. Highly recommended for any fighting game fan!

Fighting games are very very fun, almost like a game of chess. This game is no different from the others... however I have always watched them for YEARS from the outside and this is the first one that i decided to try and learn and actually be able to perform stuff i see on videos/streams, I used the tutorial to learn how this game plays because it differs from other MKs from what i have heard. Let me state here that the tutorials for this game leave you SO much more confused than you would just watching someone play the game at a high level. They almost never indicate when you need to chain everything into one Kombo or if you need to dodge back and avoid or move forward first. They are the most Misleading part of learning this game i have done in my ( at the time of writing this, 42 hours of gameplay.) I have had a better time just running the character kombo trials and messing around in Practice mode than trying to complete the tutorial on the various  aspects of the game. Now with all that said im still having a blast with what is provided gameplay wise and it runs really well on a lower spec pc (mine.) 
TLDR: if you buy. just watch youtube guides on how to play instead of in game tutorial.

I want to start off by saying that the gameplay is good. I have generally have no complaints about that. I am the farthest thing away from being proficient in fighting games, but even without having that experience, I can tell this is quality. Or at least that it's better than MK11. All the characters feel easy to control, the combos are (relatively) simple to pull off, and I've genuinely had a good time playing it.

However, this is where my praise of the game begins to taper out. Because despite the fun I have had with this game, knowing what I know now, I would have saved my money and spent it elsewhere. This is a good game, do not forget that if you continue to read further, but understand that there are series things wrong about this game that you NEED to take into consideration before buying this. Like, oh i dunno, the fact that i got scammed. Literally.

I pre-ordered the Premium version of this game, it came around to about 110 USD. That's not the exact range, it's a ballpark. This was the most I have ever spent on a single game in my entire life. And what did I get for buying the pRiEmIuM eDiTiOn? Only one kombat pack. That's it. Every other Premium Edition of a game I have every bought has included all DLC. Now, you could say it was my fault for misinterpreting what was said on the promotional material and that i should have read the fine print and blah blah blah blah. And I'll give you that, I should have looked into it more. But at face value, it looked like they were including all of the DLCs with the Premium Version of the game. If they said it wasn't included, it was not easily visible. You might also notice something too. About how the version of the game that I am talking about is nowhere to be found. That is because they removed that version of the game, and posted a new version, that is 10-20 dollars cheaper. And it only includes Khaos Reigns and Kombat pack 2. It does not include Kombat pack 1.

And that's not where the complaints end either. Kombat pack 1 is not free from my ire either. Because it only contains 6 characters. (I'll get to the cameo system and it's characters, believe me) And exactly how long did it take them to release these characters? Within 4 months? 2 maybe? How about all at once, like how you'd expect a DLC pack to release it's content? Your wrong, whatever your answer was. Because we had to wait a year for 6 characters to be released. The only compliment I can extend to Netherrealm is that AT LEAST THEY'RE MORE ACTIVE THAN MOJANG. I only learned after the fact that Netherrealm does a release schedual for the DLC characters, but I heard that they released these things within a reasonable time frame. GTA 6 WILL come out before we even hear about confirmation on a Kombat Pack 3.

And Khaos Reigns. All you need to do is just glance at the reviews for it and see that something has gone horribly wrong, and that I am not a lone critic. The actual game itself while i'm writing this review, is 50 USD. The Khaos Reigns DLC is also 50 USD. Price tags set expectations, and with a price tag like that, one would expect the DLC to hold the same amount of quality and the same amount of content as the base game. However Netherrealm is not most people, and they don't expect you to be most people either. Because they expect you to be an absolute bozo who is willing to spend 50 dollars on 3 hours of content that NO ONE EVEN LIKED. I have been reading reviews for 45 minutes, and all i see are thumbs down, and three people who only picked thumbs up as a joke. It's like Netherrealm looked at what Call of Duty did with their overpriced DLC and said, "Hmmm, yes, SOME OF THAT PLEASE!!"

And dear Super Earth, the Cameo system. Listen, i'm not skilled at this game by means. I'm new to fighting games, I have to look up guides on youtube on good combos, I struggle doing air moves, and I still have no idea what frame data is aside from the name. But the Cameo system was second most difficult thing I was struggling with during my time playing this nightmare. It is just so, so, sooooooooo difficult for me to figure out how to naturally use these characters that actually helps me out during the match. Shoot, it's difficult enough to find one that synergies with my actual character without looking up guides and stuff. And that's just my thoughts on using the Cameo Characters. Because I have a whole other complaint with them. Satans Hooves, why the god would you pick such an annoying way to under utilize your characters? Because I want to play as the cameo characters. Straight up, why can I not play as the Cameo Characters?

Like, I understand not wanting to let characters fade away and be forgotten, but i'd rather not know what i'm missing out on honestly. Because you're telling me that Sareena gets put into Cameo status, and not Ashrah? You're telling me that Lei Mei has more of a right on the proper roster than someone like Jax? I want someone from Netherrealm to look me in my eyes and tell me that Tanya is cooler than Shujinko. AND DON'T EVEN GET ME STARTED ON MOTARO, YOU KNOW, THE CYBORG CENTAUR WITH A LASER SCORPION TAIL!! GODDD WHYYY?! WHY WASN'T HE AN ACTUAL PLAYABLE CHARACTER?!?!?!!

And now we finally get to the most egregious thing about this game. The Climax of the show. The final nail in the coffin that got me to say, "screw it!" and actually write up a gods honest review. This is the worst optimized game I have ever played. It takes up 100 something gigs on my computer, refused to load on an external hard drive, crashes every time i load up Towers of Time, takes forever for the shaders to load, EATS my fuggin ram like a hungry HUNGRY HIPPOPOTAMUS, to the point that it will refuse to launch at times, stutters randomly during playing, and takes forever to load during anything, such as booting up the game, online matches, and even something as simple as switching between different costumes for the characters. AND THE WORST PART IS THAT THESE PROBLEMS NEVER LEFT. I PLAYED AT LAUNCH, EXPERIENCED ALL OF THIS, STOPPED PLAYING FOR A YEAR, **GOT A NEW COMPUTER,** AND STILL HAD ALL OF THESE PROBLEMS. 

Maybe it's just a me problem, maybe i'm just cursed, maybe no one else has had the same tech problems I have had with this game like I have. I say wait 10 years, or at least until they drop the price by like 30 dollars, AND THEN BUY THE GAME ON A BARGAIN SALE, IF YOU BUY IT AT ALL. Otherwise, get acquainted with Eiichiro Oda's literature, maybe study up on the filmography of Gore Verbinski, I don't know. That's my advice if you want to buy this game. But if you really want some advice? Want a solid review of the game? Then let me tell you this.

The dumb retcons and reboot is reason enough to reject this game. I've never heard of anything so idiotic as naming at least the 12th game in a series "Mortal Kombat 1". It's stupid and confusing and I hate that they expect us to call it that. It's entirely pointless too because the story makes it abundantly clear that although the timeline has been reset, the other games still happened. The events of the past games still happened and are frequently referred to in this game. Furthermore, the previous timelines basically just end up reasserting themselves through the events of this game, so really nothing changed except for precise chain of events that led to the same rivalries and a good number of characters being deleted to make room for new ones. It's just a dumb marketing gimmick that I don't see as even being successful. The menus all run like crap but at least it doesn't crash constantly like the previous game. The predatory DLC practices continue and are even worse though. The game costs $50 and the price of the first DLC expansion is exactly the same, more actually if you want ALL the content. The individual character packs are ridiculous too. $5 to $10 per character that they planned to include from the beginning, seriously? Playing the towers to unlock everything is repetitive, boring, and stupid. Even worse is the new Invasions which are basically a combination of the Krypt and Towers and equally pointless, repetitive, and stupid. Kameos? ALSO STUPID. It's incredibly frustrating that they took an annoying mechanic from the Towers and forced it into the base game. Just let us fight one opponent at a time, one on one. the way the game was designed for, please. Fatalities have lost all purpose and have somehow become part of the grind. Most of them aren't very entertaining after the 2nd or 3rd time if they even were the first time. Instead of being a cool bonus mechanic for skillfully defeating your enemy, now they are a requirement for EVERY FIGHT, especially if you want to earn points and unlock things - which like past games is going to take you decades to do anyway. Most characters only have one or two unique or special moves, and most of the time they are counterproductive, making you vulnerable as you repeatedly fail to move backward and forward in a way that the controller recognizes.

I'm fighting my way to keep this review positive. 

I never cared for fighting games, I don't like being " competitive "  nor being stressed out, but with Mortal Kombat I find entertaining trying out all the special movements, the fatalities, and just messing around for a while.

For this game I came out straight of a time machine, since I only played the first games from the 90s and after that lost track of the series (or any fighting games) after Mk3.

When Mortal Kombat 1 was announced then, I found the idea of a reboot of the series and probably going back to that first game from the 90s somewhat appealing.
 Those first games were cheesy, stupid, crazy, so bad they were funny, and didn‚Äôt' take themselves up too seriously. Also, they were gory. 

Returning to a fighting game after so long, I had zero expectations and no experience and I was only hoping to have that same casual experience I had with the first games, many years ago.

In that sense I believe the core experience of Mortal Kombat is still here, both in game play and crazy, stupid fun stuff that you can do with each fighter. The graphics have changed and improved a million, but also the gamepads we use today (X box controller at least) are much better than those we used many years ago.

Most importantly, if you have some fond memories of playing with the original fighters (like for example Sub-zero, Scorpion, Johnny Cage, Raiden or Liu Kang) many of them are still here, although not everyone, some of them are secondary characters which you can use in a limited way as a ‚Äú Kameo ‚Äú.

Still, the main single player campaign is fun and plays like a movie, with cutscenes that last several minutes each over the course of 15 chapters with 60+ fights. The cutscenes are probably unnecessary and frankly too long, but hey, It looks great, and again, is stupid fun, except when it takes itself too seriously (which luckily doesn't happen too often).

I understand that fighting games can get very technical and difficult, but that‚Äôs not my interest here, only to have a quick play and that is the main story campaign.

Then comes the other playing modes, sometimes they are ok (Tower even resembles the original Mortal Kombat) but other times they end up being more busy work than fun. Invasion begins barely ok, but it really goes towards being more about using coins and buying and selling stuff than just playing some fights and be done with it. It uses many tactics from free to play games.

It's a shame then that, taking the game as whole, aside from the main campaign at times it seems like Mortal Kombat is more worried about selling you coins than letting you play it.

So, there it is, that's why I'm "fighting" to get to the end of this review soon before turning negative.

The single player main game is there, and it is fun and well done, but there's so much noise around it, that the more you keep playing and trying other modes, the more it brings down what little fun you had with it.

I will " finish " my review here then, and stop playing Mortal Kombat 1 so I can have a nice memory of it and " kill " any thoughts of (not) having to spend any coins...

This is the first review I've written for any game. Let me start off by saying I am likely in the minority here and absolutely love this game. Leagues ahead of MK11 in terms of gameplay, but behind MKX still (even if I personally enjoy it more.) The main mechanic that irks the community is the Kameo system. Personally, I love it. It isn't nearly as good as say MvC's or DBFZ's assist system, but it encourages creativity and it allows for a lot of play styles. Visually it looks amazing (of course) and if you are a fan of the PS2 era of MK, there will be a ton of fanservice that you'll appreciate. The story isn't the best, but it's not the worst. It has some amazing scenes, but the consistency is kinda all over the place. The netcode is also absolutely amazing (most of the time.) The main issue with online is it's just kinda bare bones. It is also a tad inconsistent as patches may just randomly make it not work. Now, on to most of the negatives for me. The customization, while there are a ton of great outfit designs, is VERY limited compared to MK11 and Injustice 2. Also, invasions is straight up just a chore to go through. It's nowhere NEAR as good as the Krypt in MK11. And now, the main reason I'm writing this review. As it stands right now, the Steam version is *almost* unplayable. The reason I say this is because, for some unknown reason, the FPS will freak out whenever anybody lands any hit. When this bug happens, the game is actually unplayable as it will go from 60fps to 10-15fps or basically wherever it wants to go. However, through my testing, it seems as if simply closing the game and opening it back up fixes the issue. Now, if you're like me and can bash your head against a wall and "ignore" the bug, then I think the game is very much worth picking up. But if the performance issue bothers you, then I suggest keeping up with the patches for the game to see when it gets fixed. The last thing I want to add is the premium store and DLC are unreasonably expensive. That's not to say a lot of the stuff isn't high quality (the DLC is amazing), but alternate outfits can be like $10 each which is more than a DLC character. 

TLDR: Game is really good, but it has a number of issues currently

MK 1 once again manages to satisfy that craving for a brutal Fighting Game that lets me rip the spines out of my enemy.

But I have a lot to say about this game, both good and negative

I love (and hate) that the core gameplay has once again seen a drastic shift. Gone is the Defense/Attack Bar from MK11, finally replaced with its much superior 3 Bar approach that both MK9 and MKX had.
Fatal Blows are unfortunately still here and are just as annoying as in MK11.

The Kameo System is considered to be quite contentious among MK1 players but I find it to be a really nice compromise between the old Tag System in MK9 which had you swap between 2 full players, but was quite complex for a Kasual like me, but it still allows you to bring along a "second character" of sorts that have different abilities.
Now what I do HATE about the Kameo System isn't so much its gameplay, but moreso that NRS will just add any character to it when they are too lazy to give said character a dedicated fighter slot.

Instead as actual fighters we want, we get somebody like Nitara, who has to have one of the WORST voice acting performance I have ever seen by Megan Fox. The stark contrast of her lines when compared to ANY OTHER character in the game, especially in the story where you could go from somebody's great performance to the most monotonous, phoned in line delivery I have ever heard, is crazy.
NRS needs to stop hiring celebrities based on their popularity who will phone in a terrible performance and actually get the celebrities back who actually matter and cared about their work. Robin Shou as Liu Kang? Tagawa as Shang Tsung (Who was literally just in MK11 and could have reprised both his role and likeness here!)
What hurts even more is that Megan Fox couldn't even be bothered to act out the screams and hisses Nitara does, instead NRS hired a second Voice Actress! None other than Christina Vee herself who has a LONG LONG resume of outstanding VA performances under her belt and plenty of experience. Why did NRS not just use her to voice Nitara entirely?

Now let me actually talk about the Story Mode!
[spoiler]
Let us start with the good: MK 1 is such a refreshing mixup after NRS wrote themselves into a corner with MK11 and didn't know how to continue anymore. A good chunk of interesting characters up to that point were dead and their ace in the hole was to bring back the OG versions of characters by some contrived means. It made for a fun dynamic between old and developed characters and the young and inexperienced ones from MK1 (Old and young Johnny were cool together).

MK1 resets the timeline. But shaped entirely differently from the get-go with the intent to vastly change the chances that some characters have. For instance Shang Tsung and Quan-Chi were engineered to have a miserable life while characters like Bi-Han (OG Sub-Zero) would not be hunted by Scorpion.
It makes so many characters who were bland before, or whose stories we knew before, so much more interesting. Reptile is now a sympathetic person who ends up becoming a hero, rather than just Shao Khan's lapdog. Kuai Liang is now Scorpion and works together with Bi-Han from the very beginning, but in turn Hanzo Hasashi just...doesn't exist yet and is relegated to a cameo as a child in Smoke's Arcade Ending.
That is a massive shame because Hanzo had one of the best arcs in the previous timeline and was one of the coolest antiheros to me. Scorpion vs Sub-Zero is one of the FIRST things that come to people's mind when you think of MK, and it is just not here!
Raiden is no longer a god, but a humble farmer who ends up becoming the champion of the MK Tournament rather than Liu Kang. And Raiden hands-down has to be one of the best switch-ups in this story.

There is a lot of plus and minus here, and then at Chapter 9 it sadly dawns on me: This is just Deadly Alliance again but with characters in different places, or with different motivations.

Yeah you heard me right! This is just the Story of DA again because all the beads are there: Quan-Chi and Shang Tsung team up, want to resurrect an army to do their bidding etc. etc. but then at the same time, some things happen and some things don't. They take things that we already know about and just subvert them, but not in a way that makes me go "Aha! thats cool" but more in a "Wow, that is boring".
That...is disappointing. And once I realized what was going on my hype for the story came to a stand still.

But all that besides. The story has a bombastic definitive ending that I really enjoyed. It ends on a good note and leaves me very satisfied if this was the last game... If it wasn't for the after credits scene

Obviously the initial story left a bunch of plot holes and also, its 2024, you can't just leave a good story alone and just HAVE to add on to it. And the after credits scene teases what would come next in the story: Khaos Reigns.

The Khaos Reigns story can be summed up with one word: Unnecessary.
Not only is there a new villain, he is incredibly shallow and at this point the timeline nonsense has become too much for me. Its all about merging timelines once again by a villain that just seeks to destroy everything with no real understandable motivation.
But its just a slog. And once again it keeps just enough questions unanswered and enough leeway to make a new game/DLC.
Just play the original story and pretend that the after-credits scene doesn't exist and that Liu Kang's new timeline just chills after that.
[/spoiler]
And now the biggest issue of the game: Warner Bros. Games.
Yes. WB are back to RUIN MK once again by not just chucking all sorts of microtransactions into this game, but by also overpricing the game to hell and back.
I paid 90‚Ç¨ for this game when the Khaos Reigns DLC released to get both the base game and the Story DLC (Apparently that also gave me the Kombat Pack 1 and 2) but like... That is still an unacceptable price for a game that came out over a year ago!
But pricing aside, what truly ruins this game is my very first experience I had after buying it:

Whenever I buy a MK game I jump into a Klassic Tower, pick Liu Kang and just play a little to figure out the game for myself. 3 fights into the tower I lost connection to the Steam servers and my game was paused, a big "The network connection has been lost" message on my screen, and instead of letting me continue playing my SINGLEPLAYER MATCH it threw me back to the Main Menu...

Yes. Always-Online DRM is back...
Changing a Kosmetic for a character? you are greeted by a loading screen checking in with the server.
The game would even get stuck with the loading icon in the bottom right and just get stuck loading, leaving me entirely unable to do anything until I quit the game

This is so bad that I could also not even get into the Invasion Mode after finishing the Story. I already heard that it was a slog to play through from multiple sources and I wasn't even able to get an impression on it because after picking my Fighter, it was just stuck infinitely loading for several minutes before just throwing up a message.

So I try again and actually get in, play the first mission and after finishing this pretty trivial fight it just got stuck again after my win screen AND IT ERRORS OUT AGAIN AND WIPES MY PROGRESS AND THROWS ME BACK TO THE DAMN MAIN MENU

This is modern gaming. You can't just have a game release and just work anymore. It always has to attach MTX, egregious DRM to for the devs to make sure you TRULY own your game, and on top of that PC users get shafted everytime by attaching Denuvo, which is known to absolutely demolish the performance games.

I had so much more to say but Steam is limiting how much you can write into a review so I'll leave it here. I hate seeing this series devolve further. So I'll just not buy them anymore and watch the Story on YT from now on...

Being an ultra-long-time fan of Mortal Kombat in general, I plunged headfirst into 2023's Mortal Kombat 1, knowing full well it promised a bold reboot for the franchise. I knew right away from the very first moment I booted this game up and started playing that this wasn't some rehash of the classic formula but a fresh take that reimagines both the storyline and gameplay. I wasn't disappointed.

Story and Narrative: New Beginnings

Of course, first and foremost was the storyline. Mortal Kombat 1 is set within an entirely different timeline for the fact that Fire God Liu Kang did reset the universe after that chaos which went on in Mortal Kombat 11: Aftermath. Great stuff to see how a few of these very familiar faces fall into new roles and newer relations. More precisely, a storyline of characters that I knew so well had been remade, and I wonder about finding their new dynamic. But for me, the standout feature was in that story mode. The seamless transitioning between the cut scenes and the battles flowed into one another almost as if some sort of ultra-cinematic experience was chosen. It genuinely made me feel like I was right inside the action movie. True to series tradition, it managed to pull out newer dimensions of the characters that I grew up watching, to the point of indulgence in the plot.
There are twists aplenty, but none of them felt like forced fits-they all worked together with the rebooted timeline in a fashion that made sense.

Game-play: Brutality and Strategies

It genuinely does feel like Mortal Kombat 1 has taken everything that I loved about the series and then polished each one of those things to perfection. Controls are tighter, and character movements are much more fluid. Core mechanics remain the same old combo and special move jazz, but with the addition of the Kameo system, it genuinely brings a whole layer of strategy.
The Kameo fighters are like assist characters, and being able to call them in during a match added a lot of depth to the fighting system. There‚Äôs more to consider than just my own character‚Äôs moves‚ÄîI had to think about when and how to use my Kameo fighter for maximum impact.

The deaths are as brutally appealing as ever, and yeah, I'm still wincing and cheering in equal measure. Visually, it's really upped the ante because every hit and finishing move was coming out more viscerally and satisfying. Every single one of the characters' fatalities feels different and grossly creative, which has always been what made this series so unique.

Sight and Sound: A Feast before the Senses

Graphically, this is really great-even the tiniest details of the characters, from the texture of clothes to every single facial expression of theirs in a fight, are highly detailed. Each stage has a thick, dynamic background that seems to pulse with life and atmosphere. Everything from thick jungle to the bottom of the fiery Underworld makes a great difference, adding so much to the experience.
Sound design in Mortal Kombat 1 is but a punch. Literally, every punch, kick, and bone-crunching move has those meaty sound effects that really help sell weight and satisfaction in combat. Voice acting is great, with every character delivering their lines with such great conviction that it really adds an extra layer of immersion into the storytelling and gameplay.

Online Play and Modes: Room to Grow One aspect I was super hyped on diving deep into was its online multiplayer. The matchmaking system is rather decent; I really did not get a lot of lag, which is essential in such a game where timing is key, and one split second can get you defeated. In my experience, though, there's an imbalance with a number of characters, especially against high-level players who would know just how to exploit a certain move in question.

Extra modes of play, such as Towers of Time and Klassic Towers, let me flex my skills a lot of other ways away from the story. Sure, they really add replayability, but man, I just could not help it: I came back to story mode and multiplayer most. It's not a game that actually skimps on content, which, really, is an aspect I highly appreciate since I am a great fan of fighting games. Final Comments Mortal Kombat 1 has been so much better than I set my expectations for in almost every regard, really treading new ground with its respect for the heritage, storytelling, mechanics of play, and presentation. Whether ultra fan or just new and trying to get into the hype of this game, it's worth buying. It's visceral, action-packed, and true to the brutal charm that has made Mortal Kombat a staple of the fighting genre for decades.

The stakes feel empty because there are infinite timelines, so a new villain can just walk out of a timeline portal every day, or every second. Anyone who dies can be replaced with another timeline version, and Liu Kang can just make a new timeline if everything goes bad.
It makes me wonder, why should I bother getting invested?


Other than Baraka, almost every character is a more generic and one-dimensional version of themselves from previous "timelines".¬†
Havik is the worst for this. He went from being an unpredictable, neutral, shit-stirrer. To a generic, angry, villain that just yells all the time. 
Bi-Han is a close second. He's now just an irredeemable dickhead that betrays his family and clan, all because a stranger promised him an army.


Character designs range from pretty good, to painfully bland and boring (The hairstyles for the women are especially disappointing). There are way too many lazy palette swaps. I don't know who'd want to play as Swamp Green and Faded Orange Kitana, or Brown and Maroon Raiden. Why even include these?
The costume slots are filled with upwards of 30 crap pallets and 2 "good" ones.


Invasions is by far the most boring side-mode they've made. At least Deadly Alliance gave you pieces of your characters story from node-to-node. This is just a filler slog that can take hours to complete every season, and the story is about some random timeline that is going to be banished by the end of the season, so why even care?
(They've tweaked the mode so that you can just run past most of the nodes, but it still feels like a chore)

Really bad. Mortal Kombat used to rock. It's my favorite franchise of all time, but now it just sucks. It's unimaginative. I don‚Äôt mind new stuff, but do it in a way that‚Äôs not price-gouging, unimaginative, and still pays homage to the series.

Story: Convoluted as hell with the multiverse nonsense. The expansion feels like it was written for the old 2000s WB channel‚Äîterrible writing. There are so many alternate versions of characters that it‚Äôs hard to care about your favorites, especially since they've all been replaced with the timeline reset. Here's an example of how bad the writing is: A character who can turn into water gets crushed to death after holding up walls to save his wife, Tanya. You can turn into water, dude! That‚Äôs like Raiden dying from sticking a fork in an electrical outlet. It makes no sense.

Design: Really lame design for Khaos Reigns. Almost every alternate Khaos version of a character is the same: a little bit of green, a little bit of gold, add a mohawk. It's supposed to be dark and crazy. Why don't we have Khaos alternates that look ripped up and mutilated like Havik? Why don't they look like badass Cenobites? Slapping on a mohawk is the edgiest design they could come up with?

Paywalled: $50 for Khaos Reigns, which is roughly an hour and a half long. $10 for holiday fatalities. Price-gouged cosmetics? No thanks.

Boring Modes: Seasons‚Äîyawn. Towers of Time is back‚Äîyawn.

No Bosses: And putting the word "Titan" in front of a character doesn‚Äôt make them a boss. What happened to the big baddies like Onaga, Blaze, Moloch, Goro, Kintaro, Shao Kahn, Demon Shinnok, and OG Shang Tsung? Really goddamn lazy, WB/NetherRealm.

No Classic MK Secrets: Stages, fighters, hidden fatalities, hidden Easter eggs? Gone. All the fun mystery is gone.

No Stage Fatalities: Booooo...

No Stage Interactables: Boooo...

No Pit: Where the hell is the Pit?

Overall Look: It‚Äôs too goddamn bright. It feels like they're trying to make James Gunn‚Äôs Mortal Kombat. Terrible. They almost had it perfect with MK11. We need a darker tone.

Stages: A bit ADHD. They‚Äôre detailed and beautiful, yes, but look at the original Mortal Kombat 1 and 2 stages‚Äîhighly imaginative, dangerous, simple but well done. MK11 did a great job replicating that look.

Roster: Great, except due to the multiverse, none of the characters feel like themselves in the story. You want Scorpion? Well, now he's Sub-Zero. Cyrax and Sektor? Totally changed, just body armor. Raiden? Nope, now he‚Äôs Liu Kang. Liu Kang? Nope, now he's Raiden. They basically shell-gamed all your favorite characters because they‚Äôre running out of ideas.

What we need for the next MK: Back to basics (MK as a tournament), focus on fatalities and immersion (secrets, unique stages, lore), less goofy, and less like Guardians of the Galaxy. Make Mortal Kombat dark, brooding, and dangerous. Design it more around Oriental culture like the original games‚Äîthink Big Trouble in Little China, Enter the Dragon, Bloodsport, etc. I‚Äôd love to see a reimagining of the original three games in Unreal Engine 3 with a dark tone. Make Mortal Kombat dark and mysterious again.

I‚Äôm so happy I didn‚Äôt shell out FIFTY GODDAMN DOLLARS for this hunk of crap expansion.

I appreciate fighting game companies that not only focus on innovative combat, but also takes the necessary time to craft a good story around the characters. They have some of the best writers in fighting games in my opinion. I love the new cast of characters, and the game looks awesome!

This is a review for the Khaos Reigns dlc, we all already know mk1 feels lackluster in general.

I will cut it right to the chase, [b]don't buy the Khaos Reigns expansion, get the characters individually[/b]. 
The dlc campaign is the most rushed and uninteresting piece of crap i have ever seen and surely belongs to the list of one of the worst campaigns this franchise had. I would like to begin by saying that the devs still have not learned about good rewards. The expansion rewards you with lame cosmetics, terrible color palettes, artwork, stages which are decent and a couple announcers: Noob and Havik, so you won't be missing much.
The whole story is rushed from the beginning to end, where in certain scenes characters that were fighting will just skip to being captured, downed or just disappear from existence until further notice. Havik as a villain in this story feels odd, there is nothing special about him he is just a lazy re-skinned Havik with an army of lazy re-skinned re-used characters that look cringy af and want to spread chaos.

[i]Seriously, Havik in this dlc feels like a reboot of Meat than an actual Havik. The outfit and all of Havik's powers just scream Meat to me, being able to remove limbs and grow them back is something Meat would do whereas Havik would just crack his bones.[/i]

Anyways, the campaign allows you to play as the three main characters of this dlc: Sektor, Cyrax and later on Noob Saibot. But not just them, the story also wants you to play as alternative versions of characters like Tanya and Rain (which are there to replace what it feels like Jade and Kotal Kahn) these 2 alternative versions are literally what Jade and Kotal (or maybe Sindel and Shao) were supposed to be except Tanya and Rain are together as empress and emperor, they come from a different dimension which is why this would make sense, but that does not mean it is interesting. The story tries to focus on these 2 characters for a bit and tries to make dramatic scenes that end up just being mediocre, to the point that after so much chatter and boring events you end up wanting to beat the sh*tshow of a campaign Khaos Reigns is.

[spoiler]Btw the final boss fight is just Havik with a hadouken move, lazy a$$ devs[/spoiler]

--Mortal Kombat 1 Review: A $120 Cash Grab, Wrapped in 135 GB of Disappointment--

Where do I even begin with *Mortal Kombat 1*? Oh, I know‚Äîhow about the fact that this bloated, 135-GB monstrosity of a game is an absolute disaster, especially if you're playing on PC. For a game that eats up more space on my hard drive than a full season of a Netflix series in 4K, you‚Äôd think it would run smoothly, right? Wrong. It‚Äôs a slideshow masquerading as a fighting game, with optimization so bad it makes you wonder if WB even cares. Spoiler: they don‚Äôt. Why? Because they‚Äôre too busy counting all the money they‚Äôre squeezing out of their fanbase with microtransactions that rival Ubisoft's worst efforts.

------------- Graphics? Sure. But Everything Else? Just No.
Yes, I‚Äôll give it this: *MK1* looks *beautiful*. The visuals are stunning, characters are detailed, and the special effects are downright gory in the best way possible. But you know what? You can slap a fresh coat of paint on a dumpster, and it‚Äôs still a dumpster. That‚Äôs this game. The only thing that works is the graphics, and once you get over that shiny surface, the rot underneath is impossible to ignore.

--------- Microtransactions and Greed: WB‚Äôs Favorite Fatality
Do you like grinding for hours just to unlock a second fatality? Or maybe you'd prefer to drop another $50 on microtransactions after already shelling out for the base game? Because those are your two choices if you want to unlock anything meaningful in this game. Gone are the days when you could play Mortal Kombat and feel rewarded for actually playing. Now it‚Äôs just another soulless cash grab.

The Khaos Reigns bundle is a whole new level of scam artistry. $120 CAD down the drain, and for what? Not even getting the content I paid for. How the **hell** did the Premium edition get overwritten by the Khaos Reigns edition, which costs *less* and offers *more*? Are you telling me I paid extra for an early access ticket to disappointment? **Ed Boon better fly down here and personally apologize**, because WB just mugged me in broad daylight.

--------- The PC Port is a Dumpster Fire
Do you have a gaming PC? Great! You still can‚Äôt run this thing. I‚Äôve got a solid rig that handles *Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3*, *Starfield*, and *Final Fantasy 16* with no problem, but *MK1*? Nah. The moment you pull off a fatality, your game turns into a PowerPoint presentation. The frame drops are horrendous. Forget about buttery smooth finishers‚Äîyou‚Äôll be lucky if you get through the whole match without it freezing like someone pulled the plug on your PC.

Oh, and if you‚Äôre like me and decided to reduce the graphics settings to bare minimum, prepare for the "smooth" stutter to continue. Doesn't matter if you're playing at 720p or looking at the game like it's a 1990s arcade fighter on dial-up internet. 

------------ Story Mode: From Great to Utter Garbage
*Mortal Kombat* has always had pretty decent story modes for a fighting game, and at first, I thought *MK1* was no exception. I was having a blast‚Äîuntil they pulled the old "multiverse" nonsense in the last couple of chapters. Suddenly, nothing mattered. Every decision? Pointless. Every outcome? Meaningless. There‚Äôs no emotional investment when you can just undo everything with some lazy multiverse explanation. WB took what could‚Äôve been a strong narrative and flushed it down the toilet in the last chapters. The story had me, and then they dropped me off a cliff.

------------------ Kameo System: Who Asked for This?!
Ah yes, the new "Kameo" system. Because *clearly* what Mortal Kombat fans have been crying out for is a half-baked assist mechanic that forces you to watch your favorite characters awkwardly tag in, then tag out, with no flow. I don‚Äôt want to see Scorpion team up with whoever‚Äôs available. I want to *play* Scorpion. This new system feels like a gimmick, an unnecessary one that detracts from the core 1v1 combat. It's like they threw it in just because they needed something "new." Well, guess what? It doesn‚Äôt work, and it‚Äôs a massive letdown.

---------------- No Krypt? More Like No Fun.
Remember the Krypt from previous *MK* games? Yeah, they got rid of that and replaced it with loot boxes. Want a skin or some cool gear? Too bad. Now you get concept art‚Äî*concept art*, seriously? If you want anything remotely interesting, get your credit card ready. Loot boxes are the epitome of lazy design. WB isn‚Äôt even hiding their greed anymore.

---------------Customization: From a Gold Standard to a Joke
MK11 set the bar so high with its customization. You could mix and match gear, change colors, and really make your character your own. In *MK1*, customization is such an afterthought it‚Äôs insulting. You can change tiny pieces of an outfit and call it a day, but if you want anything cool? Prepare to grind your soul away‚Äîor better yet, just buy it. Because what‚Äôs the point of rewarding players with content they paid for when you can squeeze a few more bucks out of them, right?

------------------ The Grind is Real‚ÄîAnd Not in a Good Way
If you don‚Äôt want to spend real money, good luck unlocking anything worthwhile. Want that sick fatality or brutality? Be ready to sink hours into the game just to get a few cosmetics, and that‚Äôs if the RNG gods favor you. Otherwise, you‚Äôre grinding for nothing. In previous games, you‚Äôd play and unlock content as you went. Here, you just get frustrated.

---------------------------- Conclusion: Wait for the Komplete Edition (And a Sale)
Honestly, I can‚Äôt recommend *Mortal Kombat 1* to anyone in its current state. Between the ridiculous microtransactions, unoptimized mess of a PC port, the half-baked new mechanics, and WB‚Äôs relentless greed, it‚Äôs just not worth it. Even if you‚Äôre a die-hard fan of the series, do yourself a favor: wait for a sale, wait for the inevitable ‚ÄúKomplete Edition,‚Äù and save yourself the headache of dealing with this overpriced, underwhelming game.

Until then, WB can keep their $60 DLCs and overpriced skins. I‚Äôve already made the mistake of supporting this cash-grabbing, half-baked excuse of a game, and I‚Äôm not doing it again. 

Verdict:     4/10.        And that‚Äôs generous.

I want to like MK1, but the game won't let me. Even on my m.2 drive loading times range from 30 seconds to _6 minutes_. Playing the game is stuttering slideshow, and with all the time it takes to get into matches, by the time I'm into a fight I've lost all desire to play due to frustration. 
Reducing the graphics settings to minimal and lowering the resolution to 720p help, but only a little bit. it's still far from smooth.
No i don't have the best hardware, but if i can run Baldurs Gate 3, Star field, Final Fantasy 16 without issues, MK should be easy. 

As for the game itself, I am not a fan of the kameo system. I just see characters I'd rather be playing directly. And it's so jarring to constantly see teamups of characters that make no sense working together. I like MK as a 1v1 fighter. 

The pre match banter is just awful. The dialogue is fine, but to have the same face off pose in EVERY SINGLE MATCH?? What happened to the character entrances? So much personality is lost that the last three MK games showcased. That just feels shockingly lazy. It won't even make sense for the T-1000 to be doing it when he's released. 

The DLC is ridiculously priced, and the armour customisation from MK11 is completely sidelined. I MIGHT be able to give it more time to click with me, but the technical issues just put me off. 

I do not recommend getting this game unless you have a top end gaming computer, and even then not at full price. Wait for the eventual 'komplete edition' and a good sale.

[/b]

You could modify characters looks and outfits so extensively that it would hardly resemble the original outfit and then paint over THAT gear, it was siiiick!!! But here??? Have fun changing extremely small portions of the outfit that actually matter gear-wise while needing to pay an arm and a leg for damn near everything else... Ranked in other games would likely be wayyy more rewarding (and also 10 times more polished) than this.

Nothing is worse than WB's greed though. Paying 100$+ for the premium edition just to still have to pay a minimum of [b] 50 BUCKS! [/b] if you want the story expansion is an absolutely scummy move. You cant even pay a smaller fee if you want a single dlc character or just the story alone!!! its [b] ALL BUNDLED TOGETHER!!! [/b] It says everything that they even removed the premium edition and replaced it with this khaos reigns BS :/

I would [b] STRONGLY SUGGEST [/b] Doing what any sane person would do and just [b] wait a year or two. I Refuse to give another cent to this predatory monetization Chicanery.

This game HAD a lot of potential, looking at MK11 and what a fun game it was.

Now we have this, I paid 120 dollars for a game edition that is now unavailable....

But what made this game so unappealing?

Well, let's start with the pros:
+ The graphic design is beautiful.
+ The story is interesting to follow and has some very new iconic moments.
+ They brought back older characters that fans have wanted for a long time, while keeping some of the older characters.

The cons:
- The whole game is a cash grab
You see  some characters in the main story, are not playable in the main game.
(Ermac, Quan Chi, Shang tsung)
Which is just embarrassing that you have to buy 3 DLC packs for 24 dollars just to play normal characters.

- The game looks good but runs extremely poorly. 
Don't limit me to 60 fps, I bought a triple A title.

- The new cameo feature is the worst idea ever, it's not fun, it doesn't feel good and it doesn't work well.

- The new combat system is the worst thing imaginable, a simple ground combo and then spam air combos?
I loved about MK11 that you couldn't just do a cheap combo and then completely destroy the person in the air.
It just doesn't feel like MK.

- The crypt is now a slot machine....... with a 1min animation........ from 10/10 in MK11 to 0/10.

-Camos all look the same.... Nothing special about them except the price.

But what really killed me was buying a game before release, waiting for them to finish it and then months later slapping me in the face, calling me a dumb fuck and then releasing a 60 DOLLAR DLC WITH EVEN MORE STUPID SHIT.

I really started loving Mortal Kombat with MK11 and then even played 10, 9 and 2 just because those games were so good.

Now we have WB who just destroyed MK for me.......
I'm sure in 1 year when the game dies, an all inclusive bundle will come out for 10 bucks.

This is a joke, WB is a joke, I'm disappointed and ashamed that I was so gullible and thought paying over 100 dollars for a game was ok.

Long time MK player (since MK Trilogy) . Controversial statement for sure, but my main gripe is excessive juggling verging on parody/pastiche. So if you like this type of gameplay - game is for you. 

MK 1 evolved into ‚ÄûEastern‚Äù style of fighting game with focus on long boring combos. MK had juggling like in MK9/MKX, but now it is intolerable. You can be juggle for up to 25 seconds (!) and then someone may use kameo and fatal blow and you are watching animation for over 30 secodns! Which is nearly 1/3 of whole round! Every round! Do you understand how ridiculous that is? Nearly no one writes about that and it is the worst aspect of MK1. If you are not a good player dont even start KL league. You will be juggled to bordom/death. Single hit in this game should not juggle you up and extend the combo so much. The best example would be Johnny Cage

Horrible uninspiring gameplay with no variation in fighting against players in KL. 

And as there is no content for singleplayer (Invasions are horrible) so you will constantly play against the same characters. Around 5 ‚Äì 7 (not only that the also use the most cancerous Kamoes too): Johny Cage, Smoke, Raiden, Sub Zero, Scorpion, Baraka, Reptile. Most braindead characters I may add. There will be some mix up with dlc character and others, but it is rare. All players use only one combo over and over again. Scorpion knee juggle aerial, Raiden cartwheel, Sub zero overhead/slide, Smoke jugle teleport, Omni man earial punching or Johny Cage braindead pressure with mix up low/up and so on. In MK11/X you at least have some variations ‚Äì here there is none. If you make one mistake then watch unskipable 20 seconds combo animation over and over again. You‚Äôve got one combo breaker, but what is the point. It loads too slow and this game is based only on combos, so you can block or use breaker, but there will be another attempt, and another, and another. So to unskippable juggle carousel you go. 

Kameos

Not a fan. Creators and some players say that they bring great variation into the gameplay and combat, but what is the point of all this kameos when only around 5 are used. Not only that but players in KL force you to use ‚Äûgood‚Äù Kameos, beacuse you will not win with them using Sareena, so what is the point of trying others? Only kameos expanding the combos and air combos are used - rest is thrown into oblivion with exception of some teleports and defensive abilities, but the pale in  comparision to the ‚ÄûSareena ones‚Äù. Sareena, Cyrax, Ferra Tor, Frost, Khameleon. There are specific cancerous/parasitic mix ups like Johnny Cage ‚Äì Kano where you cheat on frames. But mostly you see Sareena. There should be gameplay mode without them and I truely hope Kameos will be no more. 

Moreover: 

No content for singleplayer, no crypt (!), no customization (you cannot even take off a mask from characters ‚Äì compared to MK11 it looks like a demo game), mindless grinding, ugly skins, invasion mode is like a bad joke, horrible PC port, desyncs during gameplay, playing against the same players in KL few times in the row, no 60 FPS for PC for over 8 months, stutter up to 15 seconds in KL where every second is priceless in playing against human player, paid fatalities (ugh!), no nerfs to obviously broken characters, toxic players base, constant harrasment to the point that microphone has to be turn off. And many more. 

For that price and their DLC you can have MK11 or MKX and MK9 (best in the series). I will never buy any MK game on premiere now. NetherRealm forgot that they nearly sunk the franchise and only MK9 saved them from oblivion. Maybe you should remind yourself the roots of the series. Don‚Äôt buy it for full price and do not buy their DLC.


On the plus side:
- Beautiful  stages
- Finnaly great Repitle model
- Very responsive blocking 

That is it. Too little for that kind of money. Can't stress enough buy MK11 or MK9

TLDR: Gameplay is solid. Kameo system and other gameplay mechanics are unique and cool (IMO). Rest of the game is lackluster and lacking severely compared to similar games in the genre.  Strongly recommend not purchasing or at least waiting for it to go on sale for a very reduced price.

Yeah so..... Game released unfinished and took over a year to make the game an actual product worth purchasing. Please keep this in mind when reading the review. This is a product they offered for upwards of $110 USD at launch, which literally was just a pre-order of the DLC and a Jean Claude Van Damme skin for Johnny . That in an of itself is reason enough to recommend not purchasing, but there is actually so much more to discuss.

PROS:
- Gameplay:  The gameplay is actually really solid. I really appreciated NRS going back to their old meter system, where you earn you meter throughout the match and brought back the breaker system, while keeping the flawless block mechanic, while also introducing new mechanics like the 'up block' and 'uppercut jump cancel'. The Kameo system (IMO) is actually pretty cool. Although its not perfect, I still like how kameos add a unique way to approach certain match ups and offers different tech and setups for the main fighters.

CONS:
- Lack of single player content:  Story mode, Towers, or Invasions (which is Towers, BUT DIFFERENT!). That is your MK 1 single player experience. Story mode can be finished in like 2-3 sessions. First half of story was promising but second half was utter trash. It read like they consulted ChatGPT on how to finish the script.  Towers is, well, towers and Invasions... *SIGH* If you know, you know.

- Lack of customization: I'm not big on customizing characters or whatever. But for people who do value it, it is a big step down from what you had in MK 11. Most of the content has to be earned by grinding invasions for hours and hours (ew) or is hidden behind micro transactions.  MK 1 is the Overwatch 2 of fighting games. But even OW 2 is free to play.

- Lack of online features:  There are two subcategories here. 1) Features that were missing at launch and have since been added (at least in some part), and 2) Features that are still not available that reasonably should be. 

1) Cross-play between PC and Console, a way to deny playing against wireless players in ranked, a way to pin moves from the movelist in training mode.

2) An *actual* matchmaking filter system for both ranked and player matches, KOTH room matchmaking, Player room matchmaking, online training mode, an ability to choose a KOTH lobby.

All the features above are present in ALL other big name fighting game titles. I recently purchased Under Night In-Birth 2, which is a small anime fighter produced from a significantly smaller company with way less resources and even that game has more comprehensive matchmaking features than MK1.

- Constant bugs and connectivity issues:  Matchmaking in this game was absolutely horrible on PC only until very recently. There was a period of time (MONTHS of time) where basically every other ranked set you played ended in desynchronization and forced players back into the online main menu, which meant the matches you just played didn't count. During this time you'd be lucky to get one complete set every five/six sets played. The game also launched with 'Player 1 advantage', which basically meant certain combos could only be performed on player 1 side. This advantage hasn't occurred since MK 9. Even in current day, the overall online experience is underwhelming. Even in games that are listed at >50ms, I still run into lag spikes and latency issues, almost every single game. I run wired 700ms down / 50ms up consistently. For a game that runs a funded series for competitive players, they sure seem to be lacking the resources to add sufficient servers for online play (which is where 99.9% of the players actually play).


CONCLUSION:  Although the game play is a huge step up from MK 11 and is fun to play most of the time, the rest of the game is just lacking in so many ways. I've run the cycle of: Uninstall because game is uninteresting atm --> see new DLC and update announced --> reinstall and play for about 3 days --> get bored and repeat step 1. Given NRS's recent track record with MK 11 and now MK 1, its safe to say I would not recommend buying the base game nor buying the upcoming expansion DLC ($50 USD, LMAO). I would recommend you try another fighting game instead or just purchase any of the other previous NRS titles.

I really wanted to have fun with this game, coming from MK11 with probably around 500 hours with my steam and PS4 playtimes combined. Movement, visuals, and combos feel fine. However; the cameo system completely ruined the experience. I just don't like it. You can call in a support character to effectively make strings safe, use ranged abilities, create 50/50s, use attacks that give plus frames, etc. I get that certain aspects like zoning and 50/50s are a part of MK, but I think it becomes quite ridiculous when adding the cameos. "Stop complaining, just get better," yeah very helpful. Look, I'm not a competitive or pro player and just trying to have some fun in my off time, not sweat my balls off into oblivion.

I was expecting something new, a new villain or a real threat. Instead we get Shang and Chi in a weaker deadly alliance role. They are beat on multiple occasions and are shown early to not a threat. I wanted to see someone like onaga come back into this. The set up was there, but no instead we get to have a sloppy end with your character fighting randomized fighters like raden and reptile mixed and gender swapped classic ninjas. Only to fight Shang for the 6th time as the final boss. Havik is in this game for 10 minutes max and is completely over looked.  Shao khan is completely wasted. They turned him into a jobber, he doesn't win a single fight in story mode. Not one. He looks sloppy,  weak and they gave him the stupidest design. Through out this entire story they introduce multiple fighters, just to give them a chapter and move on. Ashrah, Baraka, Kung Lao, Raden. All have little to nothing after they win 3 fights. Classic fighter are referenced only to not be used. Ermac is completely ruined turning him into jarod was the dumbest choice ever! The final fight Is absolutely garbage. It is the worst of this entire franchise.  The DLCs coming won't save this game. I was so excited, I spent 110 dollars on it. I watched all news and trailers for this, I was so invested for months on end. Just for a complete waste of time,  money and energy.  They don't respect the fans, the history and this was a huge money grab. If you wanna buy this game just wait a couple months it will be on sale for 20 or less. Garbage game, fighters either fight the same or are clunky and have 2 moves. Kameos are a cool idea. But suck and don't make any difference. All In all...this game had put a mask up saying it was huge and a completely game changer. Only to have no real threat.  I beat the damn story mode on hard In a few hours no sweat.  Frigging Shujinko isn't even a part of story mode and he got a trailer!!! Not what I was expecting.  Fights are fun and fatalities are good. But man, I am just so disappointed in this game. I hope the next one can bounce back.  Giving a 2 star only because some character designs are amazing, Reptile, Lu Kang, Ashrah and Melina look and play smooth. I really just expected more. I will never pre order a Mortal Kombat game ever again. And I seriously doubt they will ever respect the history of the games at nether studios.

I played MKX and MK11 to death and was so excited for this game. The change in mechanics and the duo system or whatever you want to call it is fun but after 18 hours in the game I've yet to unlock any second fatalities which is just making the game feel boring and repetitive.

Lack of krypt...

There's no Krypt in this game and it's been traded out for just rng lootbox for unlocking just concept art and that's it. Such a loved feature traded out so that if you want any other skin you have to buy micro-transactions. 

Lag to no end...

When I finally get to the enjoyment of using fatalities and finishing blows they just seize up and lag and show. 4 frames of a slideshow and then "you won yay". I ran the benchmark and get full 60fps easily but the second you use a fatality or finishing blow it all goes out the window which just takes the most satisfying part and turns it into the most aggravating...

Story...

I was having fun with the story until it turned into "ooooo mulitverse" and immediately I felt as though nothing mattered anymore as the story just becomes consequence-less. 

I love MK but I've played this so little compared to last titles and coming back to play quick matches here and there just remind me of how disappointing this one was...

In this franchise, especially after the MK1-3 era, they have been replacing previously female characters with transgenders. The reasons for this are unclear, but one possible explanation is a misguided attempt to adhere to diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) principles. However, the absence of female characters contradicts the very concept of inclusivity. Another possible explanation is, perhaps they want to avoid violence against women. This is great news if you want to fight as ladyboys, but if you expect to see hot women as the 90's movies Kitana and Sonya then I'm here to save your wallet.

Despite these issues, the game boasts impressive environmental graphics, effects, and an engaging story line. However, the Invasion mode endgame content failed to captivate me, and I haven't returned to it since completing the story. 

I haven't played multiplayer mode so I recommend checking other reviews if you're interested in it. It should also be noted that this game's button layout is not really hitbox or arcade friendly. It's more designed to be played by a controller. Also there's a need for L3/R3 button in the Invasion mode so your older hitbox would not be able to support it. Additionally, the decision to make some kameos non-playable fighters is a significant disappointment. It should not be difficult to include kameos as playable characters. Inclusion of unrelated characters, superheroes over familiar characters is also a questionable decision.

Another frustrating aspect is the incorrect pronunciations, for example they pronounce "Shirai-Ryu" as "Shirai Ra-yu", and "Liu Kang" as "Liu Keng" and some others. This is a disrespectful mispronunciation that demonstrates a lack of research and respect for the original languages, which could also mean lack of Diversity in their development staff.

While the game's price may be high, it has a lot of contents and it is a game-as-a-service (GaaS) model with no pay-to-win elements.

Directing the best, ultimate Mortal Kombat game ever might seem very simple, straight-forward, easiest job in the world, but sadly over-creative ideas and hidden political agenda makes them stray away and away further from it.

The game isn't nearly as bad as everyone wants to make it out to be. The gameplay is easily some of the most fun in an MK game in a long while, especially after MK11.

Well, I think I can say it now after 72 hours... MK11 is better (I have 411 hours in MK11 btw). In literally every way. Every single aspect of this game is a massive downgrade from MK11, which is already an inferior fighting game to the competition. The roster is WAY worse with a lot of the classic characters missing, the Kameos make the game extremely unfun with the pace of MK games, the designs are really bad in a lot of cases with the new "timeline" thing, the story is bad... the only thing that might be about as good if not a little better would be the soundtrack, but that's about it. 
They also decided to genderswap Sektor and Cyrax for whatever reason (and make them look like MCU Iron Man rejects), and they kinda just wasted three guest character slots on the T-1000, Ghost Face, and... well, Conan sounds cool, but the others could've been WAY cooler. Microtransactions are also ridiculous. The Invasion mode is extremely grindy, tedious, and boring. There is not a single fighting game out there that is worse than this game, especially factoring in price. Just get SF6, Tekken 8, the new Fatal Fury, or the new Capcom collections coming out (provided they don't censor too much stuff). This, I can safely say, is a way worse version of the game before it.

If you liked any of the previous three installments in the MK series, I believe you are going to adore this one. Great combat, invasions, characters, tutorials. In my opinion, this is the best Mortal Kombat game of all time. Highly recommended for the fans of 2D Beat'em up genre. I grabbed it on a sale with 60% discount on the base game here on Steam.

I am a Huge fan of MK since the SEGA days. But i have to say this game is just a big let down. I mean idk how else to describe it other than LAZY. 

THE STORY: They promised this was supposed to be a brand new story and was supposed to be a more thought out less complicated story than the original but its really just a Continuation/remake. As if they took MK11, Deadly Alliance, and Armageddon and just made it into one game, that's basically MK1 and hate to say it but THAT IS LAZY. Whats the point of reshaping a brand new timeline if things are just going to happen the same way they did before but even more complicated. - Make it Make sense

THE GAME PLAY: I am not a big fan of the Kameo system. I just don't find it fun in a sense that i have to rely on a second character to either continue a combo or break out of one but yet cannot play as that second character so like whats the point. Just would seem a lot more fun if it was more like MK9 and be a 2v2 or if you want have the option to play 1v1 just seems like a waste. Not to mention the Kameos are very unbalanced nowadays why use anyone other than Ferra?

CUSTOMIZATION: Not much to say other than they hoed us. The customizing is basically just swapping skins and colors so less options to make different styles or even save them.

The game as a whole compared to previous just seems sad. They had every opportunity to make an amazing fighter game with more options of play modes, characters and a more compelling and reasonable story but as I said it just seemed like they didn't know what exactly they wanted to do and just said F it (AKA) they got LAZY.

Before the DLC trailer I was in mixed feelings, but after this I definitely formed my opinion.

This game is just bad with over price. 
The first part of the storyline seems to be interesting, but in the second part we have second Shang Tsung, second Quan Chi, second Raiden, Sindel, Liu Kang and so on. It used to be interesting refresh of original story with a new vision of the past events of the Mortal Kombat universe, but no. Screenwriters decided that this game should be the sequel but with multiverse like a Marvel style. And it should be not only the Marvel-style multiverse, it should be the Marvel-style multiverse with changed gender original male characters. No twists, no drama, no character's growth - the story is just a genderswap multiverse. It's a very lazy screenwriters work wich hard to watch and boring to play.

The second negative part is that it's awkward optimized port for PC. Literally, I have no idea how to put in the game the one new character and brake the whole f*cking software interaction. My friend plays with me since release the game, but after release of Quan Chi his game crashed. Reinstallation fixed the crash but fps dived to 11-13. And that's end. We tried to repair his software and hardware to reach the better interaction with the game but nothing changed. It was a mirracle when he launchs the game in april-may after update with locked 60 fps and there are no issues. But this shit happens again in the day of release Takeda. 12 fps in game that noone wanna fix.
Btw we have the same configuration.

And the last part is the DLC. I have no suitable words how to describe my feelings. After trailer I sat front of monitor with the stoned face and thought about what the f*ck I've just watched. They promised us that cyborgs will be in the game. That was lie. There will be teenagers in exosuits with names of cyborgs in the game. As gamers we had a greate story of conflicts and betrayal between members of idiological clan, and we could understand characters and situation. But now we will have a story of teenage rebellion insteed. Why? Who knows and who cares. It could be probably on the mark if this game was a rethinking of original story, but it's not. I remember, it is a logical sequel for the previos game with a multiverse. Does we have no teenage characters in the game yet? Do a lot of gamers passionly wait for the another playable Arnold Schwarzenegger with a big bad sword? I guess everybody knows the answer without me.
And, of course, the price. The price of DLC, this lazy empty soulless DLC, is close to the original game. There is nothing to say. I dont' want pay for it.

Verdict is lazy scenario, bad optimization, ridiculously high price for the whole downloadable content. It's not worth any money anymore.
